Face Counting Challenge
</h3><div class="card-date-status"><span>ends in</span></div><div class="card-timer"><div class="jsevent-timer">
345 : 1 : 42
</div><div class="jsevent-timer-text"><span>DAYS </span><span>HRS </span><span>MIN</span></div></div></div><div class="card-overlay"><div class="card-overlay-text"><p class="contest-info-short"><p>The method of face detection in pictures is complicated because of variability present across human faces such as pose, expression, position and orientation, skin colour, the presence of glasses or facial hair, differences in camera gain, lighting conditions, and image resolution.</p>
<p>

Computer Vision Task With OpenCV And Python","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction Data is often defined as raw facts. Information refers to any amounts …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 16px; text-align: justify;\"\u003EData is often defined as raw facts. Information refers to any amounts or quantities of data that have undergone processing and holds more value than the raw facts themselves. The key difference is that decisions can be taken, and actions made, based upon the studying of Information- You should \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Enot\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E base decisions and actions on data, Only information.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F41245Sources_of_data_collection.jpg\" alt=\"Computer Vision With OpenCV And Python image\" width=\"738\" height=\"385\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003ESource: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fstudiousguy.com\u002Fsources-of-data-collection\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EStudiousGuy\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003ERecap\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFollowing our \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fpreview\u002Findex?article_id=7428\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eprevious article\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on Computer Vision, we are now going to further explore the world of Computer Vision in the Python Programming Language, using the OpenCV Python package. This article will show us how to perform a few more of the many operations offered by OpenCV in the Python Programming Language. In the previous article, we examined the below block of code and will now look at a few more aspects to it, in this article.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport cv2\r\n# load it in GRAYSCALE color mode...\r\nimage = cv2.imread(\"\"\"C:\u002FUsers\u002FShivek\u002FPictures\u002F487px-OpenCV_Logo_with_text_svg_version.svg.png\"\"\", 0)\r\ncv2.imshow('Analytics Vidhya Computer Vision', image)\r\ncv2.waitKey(0)\r\ncv2.destroyAllWindows()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F869691_JQofwNWO5ancK5ug2ezDgw.png\" alt=\"recap Computer Vision With OpenCV And Python\" width=\"696\" height=\"445\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003ESource: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fimages-manipulations-using-opencv-numpy-and-python-2e5538d35614\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EMedium\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EUnderstanding CV Basics\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs you may have seen, in our previous article, we have read (loaded) the OpenCV Logo image into our system memory, using the OpenCV library&#8217;s built-in method, imread(). Upon utilizing this method, we passed in two arguments, namely, a filename and a flag. The filename specified the name and location of the file on your personal computer, while the flag could be seen as the color setting for the image. Upon recollection, we remember that we read the image into our memory in a GRAYSCALE color format.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-style: italic;\"\u003ENow, the most crucial aspect to understanding OpenCV\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003E:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EImages are data. When you use the OpenCV imread() method, you are converting that raw image data into another datatype. The new datatype is one that all of us on Analytics Vidhya are very familiar with and that is \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EA NumPy Array Comprising Integers\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. Each element in the array represents pixel color intensity and may have one or more elements within it. Since we have loaded our array in GRAYSCALE color format, one will find that each pixel is represented as a single value that may take on a value equal to, and ranging from, zero (0) to two-hundred and fifty-five (255). As one moves from 0 to higher values, the intensity of a specific pixel increases, hence making it more striking to the eye.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E0 = The Color Black.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n255 = The Color White.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EEssentially what I am trying to convey is as below(I have omitted the source as it is the same as the previous article, and also to allow for the flow of information):\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWe started with the image below:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F65619487px-OpenCV_Logo_with_text_svg_version.svg.png\" alt=\"Computer Vision With OpenCV And Python opencv logo\" width=\"487\" alt=\"\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENow, we shall print the type of the variable image:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(type(image))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe output will be seen as follows:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-82498\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F14.3.png\" alt=\"numpy array\" width=\"170\" height=\"20\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFundamentally, OpenCV has transformed our image into a NumPy array, in which there are values from 0 to 255 representing pixel intensity, that correspond to the colors we see in the GRAYSCALE image. \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003ERemember GRAYSCALE images will always return an array in which each pixel has a single value that ranges from 0 (Black) to 255 (White).\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EReturning The Shape of The Array.\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet us print the shape of the NumPy array to the console.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(image.shape)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe output will be seen as follows:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-82499\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F14.4.png\" alt=\"shape\" width=\"77\" height=\"17\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOur array has 600 rows and 487 columns. In image terminology, one would say that the image has the dimensions 600 pixels (height), by 487 pixels (width).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPrinting The Image Using Pixels\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESince OpenCV has transformed our image pixels into a NumPy array with integers, we may perform NumPy operations on the array containing image pixel values, and manipulate the array.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOur array is 2-Dimensional. This means it has rows and columns. Let us perform a bit of indexing and slicing on the array, and return the contents.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecv2.imshow(\"AV\", image[0:100])\r\n\r\ncv2.waitKey()\r\n\r\ncv2.destroyAllWindows()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf one is familiar with the technique of indexing and slicing, one will be able to see that we are attempting to slice a portion of our image (NumPy) array. \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAgain, it is crucial to understand and be conscious of the fact that OpenCV Library in Python Programming Language represents its images and associated objects as NumPy nd-Arrays\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F98808NumPy-array.png\" alt=\"Computer Vision With OpenCV  Printing The Image Using Pixels\" width=\"640\" height=\"307\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESource: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Findianaiproduction.com\u002Fpython-numpy-array\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EIndian AI Production\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003ECode Explanation.\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003ELine-by-line explanations for the above block of code are as follows:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003Ecv2.imshow(&#8220;Analytics Vidhya Computer Vision &#8220;, image[0:100])\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe imshow() method is used to display an image to the screen employing a GUI. However, in this particular instance we passed in a name for the GUI window, and \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eonly a portion \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003Eof the pixel array, using slicing. Specifically, we wish to return the first 100 rows (height) from the image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecv2.waitKey()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis will wait infinitely for the GUI window to be closed- i.e., user action\u002Finteraction will close this window. You may pass an integer value as an argument representing the duration (in milliseconds), the GUI window should wait before terminating automatically.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecv2.destroyAllWindows()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe above line of code will terminate all active\u002Fopen OpenCV GUI windows. You may pass in the name of a specific GUI window to terminate as a string.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe output will be seen as follows:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F92081Picture1.png\" alt=\"Av CV\" width=\"442\" height=\"120\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThus, we have successfully returned the first 100 rows of pixels from our image. Feel free to experiment with the image, and look at whether the pixel at a particular position, matches that of the color found on the image itself.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis concludes my article on \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb class=\"\"\u003EComputer Vision With Python\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. The Practical Applications of Linear Regression Models!","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction In this article, I will try to give you a basic understanding …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F73337wp3205278-machine-learning-wallpapers_800x400.jpg\" alt=\"Linear regression models applications\" width=\"800\" height=\"400\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2184\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2184\"\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EIn this article, I will try to give you a basic understanding of a Linear Regression model. I will tell you how our system decides what should be the best fit line, what is the error and how it can be minimized, how should we decide when to use this model, etc.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003ELinear Regression, the term itself says &#8220;linear&#8221;, means that we can only use this model when we have a linear relationship among the variables. A linear relationship is a term used to describe a straight-line relationship between two variables.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F25808fig2.jpg\" alt=\"What is linear relationship\" width=\"500\" height=\"376\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EImage Source: http:\u002F\u002Fpubs.sciepub.com\u002F\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EContents\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1) What is Linear Regression?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2) Real-life examples of Regression\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3) Different names of Linear Regression\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4) What kind of relationship can a regression model show?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPositive Relationship\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENegative Relationship\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENo Relationship\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5) Covariance and Correlation\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E6) Least Square Method\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESum of squared Estimate of Errors\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESum of squared Residuals\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESum of squared Total\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E7) How do you do Linear Regression mathematically?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E8) Interpretation of a dataset using Linear Regression\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAnova section\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ER-squared\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAdj. R-squared\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EF-statistic\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EVariables section\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECoefficient\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EStandard Error\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003Et-statistic\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003Ep-value\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E9) Endnotes\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EWhat is Linear Regression?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBefore we jump into the details of linear regression, you might be asking yourself why we are looking at this algorithm.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIsn&#8217;t it a procedure we use in Statistics?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYes, you are right.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELinear Regression was made in the field of statistics, it is used as a model for understanding the association between the independent and dependent variables. These models are utilized to foresee the connection between two quantitative variables where the predictor variables are known as an independent variable and the variable which is being predicted is called a dependent variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose we want to predict the price of a house based on its Area, Garage Area, Land Contour, Utilities, etc. So here \u003Cstrong\u003E&#8220;price&#8221;\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E will be the dependent variable and \u003Cstrong\u003E&#8220;Area, Garage Area, Land Contour, Utilities&#8221;\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E will be the independent variable. It&#8217;s that easy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EReal-life examples of Regression\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EExample #1\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EBusinesses frequently use Linear regression to comprehend the connection between advertising spending and revenue.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EFor example, they might use the Liner regression model using advertising spend as an independent variable or predictor variable and revenue as the response variable. The equation would take the following form:\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003Erevenue = \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E+ \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E (ad. spending)\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EExample #2\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EIt can be used in the medical field to understand the relationships between drug dosage and blood pressure of the patients\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EResearchers may manage different measurements of a specific medication to patients and see how their circulatory strain reacts\u002Fblood pressure responds. They might fit a model using dosage as an independent variable and Blood pressure as the dependent variable.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003Eblood pressure = \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E+ \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E (dosage)\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EExample #3\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EAgriculture scientists frequently use Linear regression to see the impact of rainfall and fertilizer on the number of fruits\u002Fvegetables yielded\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EFor example, scientists might use different amounts of fertilizer and see the effect of rain on different fields and see how it affects crop yield. They might fit a multiple linear regression using rainfall and fertilizer as the predictor variables and crop yield as the dependent variable or response variable. The regression model would take the following form:\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003Ecrop yield = \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E+ \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Ci\u003E (rainfall) + \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Csub\u003E2\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ci\u003E(fertilizer)\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDifferent Names of Linear Regression.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou must be confused between linear regression, multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, etc. There is a wide range of names with a regression word behind them, this is because Linear Regression has been around since 1805 and it has been studied from every possible angle and each angle has a different name. The main aim behind every regression model is to predict a value using some features.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen we have a single independent variable then we call it Linear Regression and when there are more than 2 independent variables we call it Multiple Linear Regression simple as that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELinear regression is a \u003Cstrong\u003Elinear model\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, which means it is only applied when we have a \u003Cstrong\u003Elinear relationship\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E among the variables. Now you might be wondering how do we check the relationship between the variables. For this, we can make a pair plot or scatter plot between the variables, and from the graph, we can decide If we can use Linear Regression or not.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat kind of relationship can a Linear Regression show?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. \u003Cu\u003EPositive Relationship\u003C\u002Fu\u003E &#8211; \u003Cspan style=\"font-style: normal;\"\u003EWhen the regression line between the two variables moves in the same direction with an upward slope then the variables are said to be in a Positive Relationship, it means that if we increase the value of x (independent variable) then we will see an increase in our dependent variable.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. \u003Cu\u003ENegative Relationship\u003C\u002Fu\u003E &#8211;\u003Cspan style=\"font-style: normal;\"\u003E When the regression line between the two variables moves in the same direction with a downward slope then the variables are said to be in a Negative Relationship it means that if we increase the value of an independent variable (x) then we will see a decrease in our dependent variable (y)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. \u003Cu\u003ENo Relationship\u003C\u002Fu\u003E &#8211; \u003Cspan style=\"font-style: normal;\"\u003EIf the best fit line is flat (not sloped) then we can say that there is no relationship among the variables. It means there will be no change in our dependent variable (y) by increasing or decreasing our independent variable (x) value.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F94305YGAcY.png\" alt=\"types of relationships\" width=\"599\" height=\"231\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote style=\"margin: 0 0 0 40px; border: none; padding: 0px;\"\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EImage Source: math.stackexchange.com\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow how do we know what kind of relationship these variables have? Well by using correlation or covariance we can see what type of relationship is there.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECovariance \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Etells us the direction of the relationship between X and Y but it doesn&#8217;t tell us how positive or negative the relationship is. If the covariance value is negative then we can say that if our independent variable (X) increases then our dependent variable (Y) decreases and vice versa.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECorrelation \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eis a statistical measure that tells us the direction of the relationship as well as the strength of the relationship (how much positive the variables are correlated, how much negative the variables are correlated). The range of correlation is between \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E-1&lt;correlation&lt; +1\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E. It will be called perfect correlation if all the points fall on the best fit line (which is very unlikely)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F97257correlation_types.gif\" alt=\"types of corelations | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"814\" height=\"298\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EImage Source: docs.oracle.com\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ELeast Square Method\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe main idea behind the Linear Regression model is to fit a line that is the best fit to data and for this, we use a technique called Least Square Method. In layman&#8217;s terms, the Least square method is the process of fitting the best curve for a set of data points by reducing the distance between the actual value and predicted value (Sum of Squared Residuals). The distance between the actual and the predicted value is often known as Error or Variation or Variance.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe all know the equation of a straight line right? It is \u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003Ey = a + bx\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESimilarly, when we talk about the equation of the best fit line for Linear Regression it becomes:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F227206.png\" alt=\"linear regression\" width=\"177\" height=\"40\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAnd for Multiple Linear regression since we have more than 2 independent variables the equation becomes:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F708734.png\" alt=\"multiple variable\" width=\"444\" height=\"40\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhere \u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is the Y-intercept of the regression line  \u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Csub\u003E   \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cem style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E1  \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003Cem\u003EIs the slope of the regression line\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Csub\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EX\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Csub style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003Ei \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cem\u003EIs the explanatory variable\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENow the question that comes into mind is, what error is this? Can we visualize it? How do we find it? In a linear model or any model we don&#8217;t have to worry about the mathematical part, everything is done by the model itself.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F655211595274151984.jpg\" alt=\"Linear regression models understand\" width=\"1756\" height=\"834\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s interpret the graph above. In linear regression the best fit line will be somewhat like this, the only difference will be the number of data points. To make it easier I have taken a fewer number of data points.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESuppose there&#8217;s a variable Yi, The distance between this Yi and the predicted value is what we call \u003Cb\u003E&#8220;SUM OF SQUARED ESTIMATE OF ERRORS&#8221; (SSE) . \u003C\u002Fb\u003EThis is the unexplained variance and we have to minimize it to get the best accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid medium-insert-active\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F965051.png\" alt=\"sse\" width=\"267\" height=\"102\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe distance between the predicted value y_hat and the mean of the dependent variable is called \u003Cb\u003E&#8220;SUM OF SQUARED RESIDUALS&#8221; (SSR). \u003C\u002Fb\u003EThis is the explained variance of our model and we want to maximize it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F817541.png\" alt=\"ssr\" width=\"249\" height=\"98\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe total variation in the model \u003Cb\u003E(SSR+SSE=SST) \u003C\u002Fb\u003Eis called\u003Cb\u003E &#8220;SUM OF SQUARED TOTAL&#8221; . \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F637751.png\" alt=\"tss | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"267\" height=\"104\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EHow do you do Linear Regression?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESuppose, we want to know to what degree the tip amount can be predicted by the bill studied. So the \u003Cstrong\u003ETip\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is the \u003Cstrong\u003Edependent variable \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E(response variable) and \u003Cstrong\u003Ethe bill\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is the \u003Cstrong\u003Eindependent variable \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E(predictor variable).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F8854117.png\" alt=\"how do you do linear regression\" width=\"210\" height=\"162\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETo fit the best fit line we need to minimize the sum of squared errors, which means the distance between the predicted value and actual value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EStep 1 &#8211; Check if there is a linear relationship between the variables\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EWe know the equation of a line is \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ey=mx+c or y = x*\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E+\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E. Let&#8217;s make a scatter plot and see if we can see any relationship between the variables. Always remember, that the best fit line will always pass through the centroid, which means the intersection of x_bar and y_bar.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F4609814.png\" alt=\"check linearity\" width=\"679\" height=\"415\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe see that there is a positive relationship, as we increase the bill amount, there is an increase in tip amount also. Hence we can use our Linear regression model to predict the response variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EStep 2 &#8211; Check the correlation of the data\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAfter plotting a scatter plot and knowing what type of relationship it has, make sure to calculate the Correlation to know how much strength this direction has. Here in this case the correlation comes out to be 0.866. This tells us that the relationship we see is very strong.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EStep 3 &#8211; Calculations\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow since we know that the relationship is positive and very strong, we can now start with our calculations.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe equation of best-fit line is : \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EŶ = \u003C\u002Fem\u003Ex*\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E+\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\" style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003Ewhere \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1 \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003Eis the coefficient of regression or slope, to predict \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EŶ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E we need to know this coefficient. It will also tell us that if we increase our independent variable by 1 unit then what will be the change in dependent variable. The formula for finding this is:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F3172915.png\" alt=\"calculations\" width=\"304\" height=\"154\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Eand is the constant term is calculated by \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E=\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eȳ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E&#8211;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ex̄\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E*\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F8718716.png\" alt=\"image | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"793\" height=\"181\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe get \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ex̄ = 74 , \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eȳ = 10 , \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EΣ \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E(x-\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ex̄)(y-\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eȳ\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E) = 615 , \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EΣ (\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ex-\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ex̄\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E)^2 = 4206\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPutting all the values in \u003Cem style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E1 \u003C\u002Fsub\u003Ewe get \u003Cem style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E1 \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003Cb\u003E0.1462\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIt means if we increase the Bill by 1 unit the tip amount will increase by 0.1462 unit\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESimilarly \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003Eβ\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0 \u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E= -0.8203, the intercept may or may not have any meaning in real life\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHence the equation of the best fit line is\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EŶ = 0.1462x &#8211; 0.8203\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe see that there is so much calculation here, this is why we use Python libraries to make our work easier. We don&#8217;t need to worry about the mathematical part but we need to know what&#8217;s going on under the hood.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn the next section we&#8217;ll interpret the results of a Linear regression on a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.kaggle.com\u002Fmirichoi0218\u002Finsurance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EMedical cost dataset\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Here is the full \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002FAnshulSaini17?tab=repositories\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EEDA and Code\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F4155121.png\" alt=\"image 2\" width=\"647\" height=\"395\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EInterpretation of Linear Regression Result\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F754455.png\" alt=\"Linear regression models result\" width=\"512\" height=\"504\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETo get this kind of result for your Linear regression model you can do it like this :\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eimport statsmodels.api as sm\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cb\u003EX = sm.add_constant(x)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\r\n\r\n\r\n\u003Cb\u003Emodel = sm.ols(y,x).fit()\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\r\n\r\n\r\n\u003Cb\u003Emodel.summary()\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-family: Roboto, sans-serif;\"\u003EAnova section\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F3763911.png\" alt=\"metrics\" width=\"191\" height=\"196\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECoefficient of Determination (R squared) &#8211; \u003C\u002Fb\u003ER squared states the proportion of the variability explained by our model i.e what per cent of our model represents the real-life model. It is used to know the accuracy of our model. \u003Cstrong\u003EThe range of R square is from 0-1,\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Cstrong\u003Eit can be less than 0 only when the best fit line is worst than the average best fit line\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. Here we can see that it is 0.751 which means that our model could explain 75.1% variance in the data or that our fitted values represent the original values with good accuracy\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA good model has a high R squared value. But how high is high?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ER square &gt; 80% implies the model is a good fit\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E60% &lt; R square &lt; 80% model is an okay fit\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ER square &lt; 60% model needs improvement\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf your R-Squared value is less you may need to check your independent variables again and see if there are any outliers in them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F926977.png\" alt=\"image3\" width=\"402\" height=\"70\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAdjusted R Squared &#8211;\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EEvery time we add a new input variable, there will be an increase in the R square. So, it is not a good approach to use the R square as a deciding quantity as to whether we should add a new input variable or not. Hence, one more quantity is known as &#8220;Adjusted R squared&#8221; is used\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EIt is a modified version of R squared. It is more useful when we add irrelevant variables to our model, which means if we add variables that do not affect the target variable then the adjusted R Squared value will decrease and R squared value will increase. It is always lower than the R square\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EUsually, the value of R squared and adjusted R Squared is somewhat the same but if you see a large difference then you need to check out your independent variables again and see if there is any relationship between the target variable and the independent variable.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F530477.png\" alt=\"adj r2\" width=\"463\" height=\"71\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhere R square &#8211; Coefficient of determination\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EN &#8211; Total sample size\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Ep = number of predictors (independent variables) in our model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EF- Statistic &#8211; \u003C\u002Fb\u003EThe value of F-statistic here reveals to us that not every one of the coefficients of our model may be equivalent to 0. If the overall F-test is significant, we can conclude that R-squared does not equal zero and the correlation between the model and dependent variable is statistically significant.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow your question might be when can be the value of R square be 0. Well, when the slope or say the coefficient of the variables is \u003Cstrong\u003Eequal\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, only then R square will be 0. If it is 0 then it means that there is no benefit gained from doing this regression.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose, we have only one student in a class and the average of weights in the class is 60. What does this mean? This means that the average weight is itself the weight of that student. In this case, our R squared value will be 0.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ENull hypothesis\u003C\u002Fi\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003Ehere is (\u003Cb\u003EH\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E) : the model with no independent variables fits the data as well as our model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EThe Alternate hypothesis\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (\u003Cb\u003EH\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E) : our model fits the data better than the intercept only model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe p-value here helps us to check whether there is enough evidence to accept our Alternate hypothesis. If we are testing at a 95% confidence interval then, if:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EP-value &lt; level of significance (in this case 5%),we reject \u003Cb\u003EH\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Ep-value\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n&gt; level of significance, we cannot reject \u003Cb style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EH\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EVariables Section\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F252121.png\" alt=\"variable section | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"424\" height=\"169\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s interpret this part and see what we can get from this portion. For a better understanding of Machine Learning, an individual must have a rudimentary knowledge of statistics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECoefficient: \u003C\u002Fb\u003EThe coefficient of a variable tells us that if we increase our independent variable by 1 unit holding other variables of the model constant (remember Linear Regression assumes that there is no Multicollinearity in our model, that means the independent variables have no collinearity between them), then our dependent variable will increase by that much value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere we can see that the coefficient of age is 257.4050, this means that if we increase age by 1 year then it will increase our target variable by 257.4050. If there was a negative coefficient. for example coefficient of &#8220;region&#8221;, then we would say that if we increase the value of the region by 1 unit then there&#8217;s a decrease of -353.4491 in our target variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECoefficients can also help us to see how significant the variable is for our model. If our coefficient value is close to zero, we could say that there is no relationship between the variable and the target variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EStandard. Error &#8211;\u003C\u002Fb\u003E o understand what standard error is we first need to know about standard deviation. Standard deviation tells us the variation of the values from the mean or how spread the data is. About 95% of the values lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F224951.png\" alt=\"normal distribution | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"720\" height=\"405\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EImage Source: Google Images\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow in layman&#8217;s terms if I tell you how you can interpret standard error then I would say, suppose we have a population and from this population we pick \u003Cstrong\u003Eenough samples let&#8217;s say 10\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. Now, if we find the mean of these samples and plot them on a standard normal graph, then the standard deviation of these sample means is what we call standard error. It will tell you how accurate the mean of any given sample is from the true population.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F831011.png\" alt=\"se\" width=\"183\" height=\"84\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, in our regression model, the standard error gives the estimated standard deviation of the distribution of coefficients.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EConfusing right? Don&#8217;t worry we&#8217;ll try to break this.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EWe&#8217;ve previously determined that for every 1 unit increase in age, the target variable will go up by 257.4050. Now in case if we ran the model, again and again, the standard error will tell that there may be some variation in this coefficient, suppose here in age the std. the error of 11.878 tells that the coefficient of age may vary by 11.878 if we run this model again.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EJust so you don&#8217;t need to scroll back up again, I will post the result again here 🙂\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F289501.png\" alt=\"fig1 | Linear regression models applications\" width=\"424\" height=\"169\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Et-stat &#8211; \u003C\u002Fb\u003Et-statistic or t-value whatever you like more is calculated by dividing our coefficient from our standard error.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003Et-stat = Coefficient\u002FStd.Error\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EThe value of the t-statistic will help us determine if the coefficient value is really that number or it just happened by chance. If the value of the t-statistic is greater than the tabulated value.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images medium-insert-images-grid\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F716468.png\" alt=\"fig2\" width=\"241\" height=\"43\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThen we will reject the null hypothesis since the value falls under the rejection area.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe null hypothesis here is (\u003Cb\u003EH\u003Csub\u003E0\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E): each of the coefficients at the population level is 0\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe alternate hypothesis (\u003Cb\u003EH\u003Csub\u003E1\u003C\u002Fsub\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E): the coefficients are not 0 at population level\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe higher the value of t-statistic in magnitude, the more significant the variable is.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EP &gt; |t| &#8211; \u003C\u002Fb\u003Ep-value is the probability for the Null hypothesis to be true. Here in this table if we see the p-value of age, we can see the probability that the null hypothesis is True is approximately equal to 0. P-value will tell us that it is very unlikely that there is no relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable, which means that the coefficients are not 0 at the population level.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETypically, a p-value of 5% or less is a good cut-off point. If the p-value is greater than 0.05 (p-value&gt;0.05) then we fail to reject the null hypothesis and say that there is no relationship between the variable and the target variable, if it is less than 0.05 (p-value&lt;0.05) then reject the null hypothesis and say that the coefficients are not equal to 0.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe higher the value of t-statistic, the lower will the p-value, the higher will be the chances that the value of the coefficients are significant and didn&#8217;t happen by chance.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEndnotes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EToday you learned how to interpret your Linear Regression model from scratch, congratulations! It’s always better to know what is happening under the hood, you need to know what exactly these terms tell in this model only then you&#8217;ll be able to proceed and make good predictions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETo check out the full code please refer to my \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002FAnshulSaini17\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGithub\u003C\u002Fa\u003E repository.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThank you and have a nice day, Cheers!!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EAbout the Author\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EHello, I am Anshul Saini from Uttar Pradesh. I am an undergraduate student currently in my last year majoring in Statistics (Bachelors of Statistics) and have a strong interest in the field of data science, machine learning, and artificial intelligence. I enjoy diving into data to discover trends and other valuable insights about the data. I am constantly learning and motivated to try new things.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003EI am open to collaboration and work.\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F84b925d7258b31e681b3a6c6c730fab1?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F84b925d7258b31e681b3a6c6c730fab1?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F84b925d7258b31e681b3a6c6c730fab1?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"94afbf78-34c0-4906-a02f-d2dcb9bcb54f","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:15.539855Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:08.794990Z","resource_id":"82461","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fdetecting-fake-news-with-natural-language-processing\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T11:52:28Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T11:52:28Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Detecting Fake News with Natural Language Processing","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon 1. Introduction We consume news through several mediums throughout the day in our …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E1. Introduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe consume news through several mediums throughout the day in our daily routine, but sometimes it becomes difficult to decide which one is fake and which one is authentic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EDo you trust all the news you consume from online media?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EEvery news that we consume is not real. If you listen to fake news it means you are collecting the wrong information from the world which can affect society because a person&#8217;s views or thoughts can change after consuming fake news which the user perceives to be true.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESince all the news we encounter in our day-to-day life is not authentic, how do we categorize if the news is fake or real?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this article, we will focus on text-based news and try to build a model that will help us to identify if a piece of given news is fake or real.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EBefore moving to the practical things let&#8217;s get aware of few terminologies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E2. Terminologies\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2.1 Fake News\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EA sort of sensationalist reporting, counterfeit news embodies bits of information that might be lies and is, for the most part, spread through web-based media and other online media.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis is regularly done to further or force certain kinds of thoughts or for false promotion of products and is frequently accomplished with political plans.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESuch news things may contain bogus and additionally misrepresented cases and may wind up being virtualized by calculations, and clients may wind up in a channel bubble.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2.2 Tfidf Vectorizer\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETF (Term Frequency):  \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EIn the document, words are present so many times that is called term frequency. In this section, if you get the largest values it means that word is present so many times with respect to other words. when you get word is parts of speech word that means the document is a very nice match.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIDF (Inverse Document Frequency): \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Ein a single document, words are present so many times, but also available so many times in another document also which is not relevant. IDF is a proportion of how critical a term is in the whole corpus.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Ecollection of word Documents will convert into the matrix which contains TF-IDF features using  TfidfVectorizer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E3. Project\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETo get the accurately classified collection of news as real or fake we have to build a machine learning model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETo deals with the detection of fake or real news, we will develop the project in python with the help of &#8216;sklearn&#8217;, we will use &#8216;TfidfVectorizer&#8217; in our news data which we will gather from online media.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAfter the first step is done, we will initialize the classifier, transform and fit the model. In the end, we will calculate the performance of the model using the appropriate performance matrix\u002Fmatrices. Once will calculate the performance matrices we will be able to see how well our model performs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"6299\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EThe practical implementation of these tools is very simple and will be explained step by step in this article.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"c945\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003ELet’s start.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.1 Data Analysis\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere I will explain the dataset.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this python project, we have used the CSV dataset. The dataset contains 7796 rows and 4 columns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis dataset has four columns,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Etitle\u003C\u002Fb\u003E: this represents the title of the news.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eauthor\u003C\u002Fb\u003E: this represents the name of the author who has written the news.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Etext\u003C\u002Fb\u003E: this column has the news itself.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Elabel\u003C\u002Fb\u003E: this is a binary column representing if the news is fake (1) or real (0).\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe dataset is open-sourced and can be found \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.kaggle.com\u002Fc\u002Ffake-news\u002Fdata?select=train.csv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.2 Libraries\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe very basic data science libraries are sklearn, pandas, NumPy e.t.c and some specific libraries such as transformers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport pandas as pd\r\nfrom nltk.corpus import stopwords\r\nfrom nltk.stem.porter import PorterStemmer\r\nimport re\r\nimport nltk\r\nfrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer\r\nfrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import HashingVectorizer\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\nfrom sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split\r\nfrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.3 Read dataset from CSV File\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edf=pd.read_csv('fake-news\u002Ftrain.csv')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre class=\"\"\u003Edf.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eoutput:-\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F97353Screenshot from 2021-06-07 09-37-18.png\" alt=\"dataset | detecting fake news NLP\" width=\"971\" height=\"237\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EBefore proceeding, we need to check whether a null value is present in our dataset or not.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edf = df.isnull()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere is no null value in this dataset. But if you have null values present in your dataset then you can fill it. In the code given below, I will tell you how you can replace the null values.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre class=\"\"\u003Edf = df.fillna(' ')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3.4 Data Preprocessing\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn data processing, we will focus on the text column on this data which actually contains the news part. We will modify this text column to extract more information to make the model more predictable. To extract information from the text column, we will use a library, which we know by the name of &#8216;\u003Cb\u003Enltk&#8217;\u003C\u002Fb\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere we will use functionalities of\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003Ethe \u003Cb\u003E&#8216;nltk\u003C\u002Fb\u003E&#8216; library named Removing Stopwords, Tokenization, and Lemmatization. So we will see these functionalities one by one with these three examples. Hope you will have a better understanding of extracting information from the text column after this.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.4.1 Removing Stopwords:-\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThese are the words that are used in any language used to connect words or used to declare the tense of sentences. This means that if we use these words in any sentence they do not add much meaning to the context of the sentence so even after removing the stopwords we can understand the context.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFor more details click on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@saitejaponugoti\u002Fstop-words-in-nlp-5b248dadad47\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ethis link\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.4.2 Tokenization:- \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETokenization is the process of breaking text into smaller pieces which we know as tokens.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nEach word, special character, or number in a sentence can be depicted as a token in NLP.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETokenization is the process of breaking down a piece of code into smaller units called tokens.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Efrom\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E nltk.tokenize \u003Cstrong\u003Eimport\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E word_tokenize\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Etext \u003Cstrong\u003E=\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \"\u003Ccode\u003EHello everyone. Welcome to Analytics Vidhya. You are studying NLP article\u003C\u002Fcode\u003E\"\r\nword_tokenize(text)\r\n\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe output looked like this:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E['Hello everyone.','Welcome to Analytics Vidhya.','You are studying NLP article']\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3.5 CONVERTING LABELS:-\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe dataset has a Label column whose datatype is Text Category. The Label column in the dataset is classified into two parts, which are denoted as Fake and Real. To train the model, we need to convert the label column to a numerical one.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E**********************************************\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edf.label = df.label.astype(str)\r\ndf.label = df.label.str.strip()\r\ndict = { 'REAL' : '1' , 'FAKE' : '0'}\r\ndf['label'] = df['label'].map(dict)df.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo proceed further, we separate our dataset into features(x_df) and targets(y_df).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ex_df = df['total']\r\ny_df = df['label']\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3.6. \u003Cstrong\u003EVECTORIZATION\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVectorization is a methodology in NLP to map words or phrases from vocabulary to a corresponding vector of real numbers which is used to find word predictions, word similarities\u002Fsemantics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor curiosity, you surely want to check out this article on ‘ \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fwhy-data-is-represented-as-a-vector-in-data-science-problems-a195e0b17e99#:~:text=So%2C%20when%20we%20are%20looking,thought%20of%20as%20a%20vector.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EWhy data are represented as vectors in Data Science Problems\u003C\u002Fa\u003E’.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo make documents’ corpora more relatable for computers, they must first be converted into some numerical structure. There are few techniques that are used to achieve this such as &#8216;Bag of Words&#8217;.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, we are using vectorizer objects provided by Scikit-Learn which are quite reliable right out of the box.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfTransformer\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecount_vectorizer = CountVectorizer()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecount_vectorizer.fit_transform(x_df)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efreq_term_matrix = count_vectorizer.transform(x_df)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Etfidf = TfidfTransformer(norm = \"l2\")\r\ntfidf.fit(freq_term_matrix)\r\ntf_idf_matrix = tfidf.fit_transform(freq_term_matrix)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(tf_idf_matrix)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, with ‘Tfidftransformer’ we are computing word counts using ‘CountVectorizer’ and then computing the IDF values and after that the Tf-IDF scores. With ‘Tfidfvectorizer’ we can do all three steps at once.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe code written above will provide with you a matrix representing your text. It will be a sparse matrix with a large number of elements in a Compressed Sparse Row format.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe most used vectorizers are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECount Vectorizer:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E The most straightforward one, it counts the number of times a token shows up in the document and uses this value as its weight.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cb\u003EHash Vectorizer:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E This one is designed to be as memory efficient as possible. Instead of storing the tokens as strings, the vectorizer applies the hashing trick to encode them as numerical indexes. The downside of this method is that once vectorized, the features’ names can no longer be retrieved.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cb\u003ETF-IDF Vectorizer: \u003C\u002Fb\u003ETF-IDF stands for “term frequency-inverse document frequency”, meaning the weight assigned to each token not only depends on its frequency in a document but also how recurrent that term is in the entire corpora. More on that here.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.7. MODELING\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter Vectorization, we split the data into test and train data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E# Splitting the data into test data and train data\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ex_train, x_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(tf_idf_matrix,y_df, random_state=0)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI fit four ML models to the data,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELogistic Regression, Naive-Bayes, Decision Tree, and Passive-Aggressive Classifier.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter that, predicted on the test set from the TfidfVectorizer and calculated the accuracy with accuracy_score() from sklearn. metrics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\n\u003Cb\u003E3.7.1. Logistic Regression\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E#LOGISTIC REGRESSION\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Elogreg = LogisticRegression()\r\nlogreg.fit(x_train, y_train)\r\nAccuracy = logreg.score(x_test, y_test)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(Accuracy*100)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccuracy: 91.73%\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.7.2. Naive-Bayes\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E#NAIVE BAYES\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.naive_bayes import MultinomialNB\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\r\nNB = MultinomialNB()\r\nNB.fit(x_train, y_train)\r\nAccuracy = NB.score(x_test, y_test)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(Accuracy*100)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccuracy: 82.32 %\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.7.3. Decision Tree\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E# DECISION TREE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\r\nclf = DecisionTreeClassifier()\r\nclf.fit(x_train, y_train)\r\nAccuracy = clf.score(x_test, y_test)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eprint(Accuracy*100)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccuracy: 80.49%\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3.7.4. Passive-Aggressive Classifier\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPassive Aggressive is considered algorithms that perform online learning (with for example Twitter data). Their characteristic is that they remain passive when dealing with an outcome that has been correctly classified, and become aggressive when a miscalculation takes place, thus constantly self-updating and adjusting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E# PASSIVE-AGGRESSIVE CLASSIFIER\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn.linear_model import PassiveAggressiveClassifier\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E  pac=PassiveAggressiveClassifier(max_iter=50)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E pac.fit(x_train,y_train)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E #Predict on the test set and calculate accuracy\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ey_pred=pac.predict(x_test)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Escore=accuracy_score(y_test,y_pred)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E print(f'Accuracy: {round(score*100,2)}%')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOutput:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccuracy: 93.12%\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4. CONCLUSION\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe passive-aggressive classifier performed the best here and gave an accuracy of 93.12%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe can print a confusion matrix to gain insight into the number of false and true negatives and positives\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFake news detection techniques can be divided into those based on style and those based on content, or fact-checking. Too often it is assumed that bad style (bad spelling, bad punctuation, limited vocabulary, using terms of abuse, ungrammaticality, etc.) is a safe indicator of fake news.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMore than ever, this is a case where the machine’s opinion must be backed up by clear and fully verifiable indications for the basis of its decision, in terms of the facts checked and the authority by which the truth of each fact was determined.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECollecting the data once isn’t going to cut it given how quickly information spreads in today’s connected world and the number of articles being churned out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI hope you might find this helpful. You can comment down in the comment sections for any queries.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EAbout the Author\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHi, I am Kajal Kumari.
