for kajal56\"}}]},{\"@type\":\"Person\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#\u002Fschema\u002Fperson\u002F94aa8b2496f699d1b08db9ae12953eba\",\"name\":\"kajal56\",\"image\":{\"@type\":\"ImageObject\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#personlogo\",\"inLanguage\":\"en-US\",\"url\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fbca41093900c80dfc4f87e9989b43a18?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"caption\":\"kajal56\"},\"mainEntityOfPage\":{\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Fkajal56\u002F#webpage\"}}]}\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\n\u003C!-- \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fbca41093900c80dfc4f87e9989b43a18?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fbca41093900c80dfc4f87e9989b43a18?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fbca41093900c80dfc4f87e9989b43a18?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"10b2d930-1172-4c44-9201-115e67d55ed7","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:15.611522Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:08.856078Z","resource_id":"82466","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fgive-hermione-granger-a-cool-pair-of-glasses-by-building-snapchat-filter-using-opencv\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T11:47:38Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T11:47:38Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Give Hermione Granger a Cool Pair of Glasses by building Snapchat Filter using OpenCV","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Who doesn't like spicing up their pictures with some cool effects and quirky …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan id=\"spancomment2162\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2162\"\u003EWho doesn&#8217;t like spicing up their pictures with some cool effects and quirky filters? \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E Be it a silly dog face filter or a huge mustache, a cowboy hat or a pair of cool goggles, even the most boring pictures can turn into the most hilarious ones with the right filters and stickers. The love for filters is quite evident by the increasing popularity of Snapchat and Instagram filters among all netizens!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat if you could build a cool filter just like that completely on your own?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYes, you can easily build one and customize it according to your choice!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESounds interesting, right! So let&#8217;s get started. We shall make our very own filter with the help of OpenCV. In this blog, we shall build a Snapchat-like filter to give Miss Hermione Granger a cool pair of sunglasses!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat is OpenCV?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo before we dive into the code, let us understand what OpenCV is.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003EOpenCV \u003C\u002Fspan\u003Eis an extremely useful open-sourced python library that primarily deals with real-time \u003Cb\u003EComputer Vision\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, Machine learning, and Image Processing. OpenCV has numerous functions that can be used to identify objects, recognize facial features, process images, and videos and even modify them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESome of the numerous fields in which OpenCV finds its application are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EFace Detection\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EImage\u002FVideo search and retrieval\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli class=\"\"\u003ENavigation of Driver-less car\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EMedical image analysis\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EInteractive art installations\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EAlohomora!\u003C\u002Fi\u003E You have now unlocked the doors to the world of Computer Vision using OpenCV! Time to explore further. In order to build our Snapchat filter, we shall focus on the \u003Cb\u003EDetection of Facial Features using OpenCV with Haar Cascade Classifiers.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet us get started with the code. We will need three main libraries:  Numpy, Matplotlib, and OpenCV.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003E\u003Cb\u003EImporting Libraries\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport numpy as np\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\nimport cv2\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we are going to use some Haar Cascades.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat are Haar Cascades?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHaar Cascades is one of the most popular object detection algorithms. It makes use of various features such as Edge Features, Line Features, and Centre-Surround Features to locate similar patterns in the images and hence identify objects. For example, the edges of the lips are generally distinct with the side of the lips being darker than the skin, thus a horizontal Edge feature may be used. Similarly, a vertical edge feature may be used to detect the bridge of the nose.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESome Haar Features are shown below:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F24437Haar Cascades.png\" alt=\"Filter using OpenCV haar\" width=\"354\" height=\"213\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E( Image Source: \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fsds-platform-private.s3-us-east-2.amazonaws.com\u002Fuploads\u002F5_blog_image_6.png\u003Elink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E )\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow that we know what Haar Cascades are, let us use a cascade that will help us detect the frontal eyes in an image. You will need to download the Haar cascades first. You can do that from \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002FTithiSreemany\u002FSnapchat-Filter-using-OpenCV\u002Ftree\u002Fmain\u002FHaar%20Cascades\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ELoading the Cascades\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eeye_cascade = cv2.CascadeClassifier(\"frontalEyes35x16.xml\")\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow let us read our image. We shall read a picture of Hermione Granger and give her a cool pair of goggles!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhen working with OpenCV python, we store the images in the form of numpy ndarray.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimg=plt.imread(\"Hermione1.jpg\")\r\n\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003Eplt.imshow(img)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F50621Output1.png\" alt=\"Filter using OpenCV sample image\" width=\"982\" height=\"653\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E( Image Source : \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fin.pinterest.com\u002Fpin\u002F340232946822321932\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Elink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E )\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe get the above output.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow let us display the image shape of our original image. Since the image has been stored in a numpy ndarray, we can now use ndarray.shape to get the dimensions of the image. This can be done by the following code\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimg.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOutput : (487, 586, 3)  \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe output (487, 586, 3) represents the height, width, and the number of channels in the image respectively.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe must also create a copy of the original image and store it as img1 for displaying the final result.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimg1=img.copy()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow, we shall identify the eyes in the image with the help of detectMultiScale() method using the eye_cascade object defined earlier. We will pass our input image as a parameter. This shall help us locate the pair of eyes in our image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eeye=eye_cascade.detectMultiScale(img)[0]\r\nprint (eye)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOutput : [221, 130, 134, 61]\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis returns the location of the eyes in the format (x,y,w,h). Here\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ex\u003C\u002Fb\u003E stands for the \u003Cb\u003EX coordinate \u003C\u002Fb\u003Eof the bottom left corner\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ey\u003C\u002Fb\u003E stands for the \u003Cb\u003EY coordinate\u003C\u002Fb\u003E of the bottom left corner\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ew \u003C\u002Fb\u003Estands for the \u003Cb\u003Ewidth \u003C\u002Fb\u003Eof the eye region\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eh\u003C\u002Fb\u003E stands for the \u003Cb\u003Eheight \u003C\u002Fb\u003Eof the eye region\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe then store the data obtained in\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nfour different variables as shown. Once the location of the eye is detected we\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nshall draw a rectangle on the initial image to visualize our result. This can\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nbe done by passing the calling the cv2.rectangle method and passing the coordinates of the eye, the color of the rectangle, and the width of the rectangle as parameters.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere, we have passed (225, 225, 255) for the color and 5 for the width so we shall obtain a white rectangle of width 5.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eeye_x,eye_y,eye_w, eye_h= eye\r\nimg = cv2.rectangle(img, (eye_x, eye_y), (eye_x + eye_w, eye_y + eye_h), (255,255,255), 5 )\r\nplt.imshow(img)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F89175Output2.png\" alt=\"Filter using OpenCV select\" width=\"1177\" height=\"755\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow we shall read the image of the glasses and store it in a variable. We then check the size of our input image as shown.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eglasses=plt.imread(\"sample1.png\")\r\nglasses.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOutput : (200, 200, 4)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe observe that the size of the glasses and the image of Hermione are proportional, thus we must resize the glasses so that they fit Hermione perfectly! So let&#8217;s do that and resize the image based on the coordinates of the eyes we had obtained earlier.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIt might take you some trial and error to adjust the values to suit your image. These are the values that give the best results for our image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eglasses=cv2.resize(glasses,(eye_w+50,eye_h+55))\r\nglasses.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOutput: (116, 184, 4)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow for the final step! Since we do not want the rectangle detecting the eyes on our final image we shall deal with the copy image &#8216;img1&#8217; we had created earlier. Now that we have the coordinates of our glasses we simply have to replace the pixels of the image of Hermione with the pixels of the glasses. To do that we use 2 for loops. If the pixel on the glasses image is 0 that means, we want that portion to be transparent, so we do not replace that pixel. In all other cases, we simply replace the pixel of the image with the pixel of the glasses at the desired location.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s see how it is done!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efor i in range(glasses.shape[0]):\r\n  for j in range(glasses.shape[1]):\r\n    if (glasses[i,j,3]&gt;0):\r\n      img1[eye_y+i-20,eye_x+j-23, :]=glasses[i,j,:-1]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.imshow(img1)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F38618Output3.png\" alt=\"Filter using OpenCV output\" width=\"1129\" height=\"719\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVoila! There you have it! We have successfully given Miss Granger a cool pair of glasses!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EResources\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFind the link to the code and the Haar Cascade used \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002FTithiSreemany\u002FSnapchat-Filter-using-OpenCV\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EConclusion\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis particular application of Computer Vision is widely used in applications such as Instagram, Snapchat, PicsArt and various other photo editing apps.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow that we have implemented this filter on a picture of Hermione and you know how it is done, it&#8217;s time to have fun using OpenCV. Feel free to try it out with your own pictures and accessories and create some amazing, fun filters of your own!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAfter all, you don&#8217;t need magic, just the basics of OpenCV!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cu\u003EAbout Me:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHey there, I&#8217;m Tithi Sreemany. Hope you liked reading this article and found it useful.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EYou can reach out to me on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.linkedin.com\u002Fin\u002Ftithi-sreemany\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELinkedIn\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EThanks for reading!\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-buttons\" data-active-addon=\"images\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv discretion.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n","image_url":{"full":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F91004CoverPic.png","large":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F91004CoverPic-850x421.png","medium":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F91004CoverPic-360x206.png","small":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F91004CoverPic-262x141.png","nano":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F91004CoverPic-100x72.png"},"categories":[{"id":"c5db282a-4020-44d2-88fb-c08adbcc6961","title":"Unsupervised","slug":"unsupervised","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"8f6f6259-c7ca-4399-a80a-064c9dc0f77d","title":"Project","slug":"project","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"fba685ad-2b6c-492c-b325-d57d6ebbd9fe","title":"Libraries","slug":"libraries","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"e3c14f97-bb23-4a83-8525-4f07acf399a6","title":"Image Vision","slug":"computer-vision","description":"","permalink":""}],"author":{"id":"418290a4-b23b-4bce-bc89-1da304df9e46","full_name":"Tithi_Sreemany","bio":"","profile_image_url":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F01395ba9c7ea273d3068b10026ba4408?s=96&d=mm&r=g","profile_urls":{"blog":{"id":128514,"permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Ftithi_sreemany\u002F","extra_info":{"id":128514,"url":"","link":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Ftithi_sreemany\u002F","name":"Tithi_Sreemany","slug":"tithi_sreemany","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fusers\u002F128514"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fusers"}]},"yoast_head":"\u003C!-- \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F01395ba9c7ea273d3068b10026ba4408?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F01395ba9c7ea273d3068b10026ba4408?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F01395ba9c7ea273d3068b10026ba4408?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"fb08e5e9-738e-4c6c-866b-3a8fcd6eab72","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:15.684750Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:08.914405Z","resource_id":"82462","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fdeep-understanding-of-discriminative-and-generative-models-in-machine-learning\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T11:32:38Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T11:32:38Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Deep Understanding of Discriminative and Generative Models in Machine Learning","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction In today's world, Machine learning becomes one of the popular and exciting fields …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003EIn today&#8217;s world, Machine learning\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E becomes one of the popular and exciting fields of study that gives machines the ability to learn and become more accurate at predicting outcomes for the unseen data i.e, not seen the data in prior. The ideas in Machine learning overlaps and receives from \u003Cb\u003EArtificial Intelligence\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and many other related technologies. Today, machine learning is evolved from \u003Cb\u003EPattern Recognition\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and the concept that computers can learn without being explicitly programmed to performing specific tasks. We can use the \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003EMachine Learning algorithms(e.g,\u003Cb\u003E Logistic Regression\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, \u003Cb\u003ENaive Bayes\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, etc)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E to \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ERecognize spoken words,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EData Mining, and\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EBuild applications that learn from data, etc.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003EAnd the improvement of these algorithms in terms of accuracy increases over time.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F05\u002FML.png\" alt=\"Discriminative and Generative Models  ML\" width=\"507\" height=\"254\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E                                                      Image Source: \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca class=\"btn\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F06\u002Fcomprehensive-data-science-machine-learning-interview-guide\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMachine learning models can be classified into\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003Etwo types of models &#8211; \u003Cb\u003EDiscriminative\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and\u003Cb\u003E Generative\u003C\u002Fb\u003E models. In simple words, a discriminative model makes predictions on the unseen data based on conditional probability and can be used either for classification or regression problem statements. On the contrary, a generative model focuses on the distribution of a dataset to return a probability for a given example.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F1000\u002F0*TXI_h4llG-SmdwYY.png\" alt=\"Discriminative and Generative Models 2\" width=\"500\" height=\"322\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E                                                  Image Source: \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca class=\"btn\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fbetterprogramming.pub\u002Fgenerative-vs-discriminative-models-d26def8fd64a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003EWe as a human can adopt any of the two different approaches to machine learning models while learning an artificial language\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E. These two models have not previously been explored in human learning. However, it is related to known effects of causal direction, classification vs. inference learning, and observational vs. feedback learning. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003ESo, In this article, our focus is on two types of machine learning models &#8211; \u003Cb\u003EGenerative\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and \u003Cb\u003EDiscriminative,\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and also see the importance, comparisons, and differences of these two models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETable of Contents\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EProblem Formulation for Understanding Discriminative and Generative Models\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EWhat are Discriminant Models in Machine Learning?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EWhat are Generative Models in Machine Learning?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EDifference between Discriminative and Generative Models\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EComparison between Discriminative and Generative Models\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EProblem Formulation\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESuppose we are working on a classification problem where our task is to decide if an email is a spam or not spam based on the words present in a particular email. To solve this problem, we have a joint model over\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELabels: \u003Cstrong\u003EY=y\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, and\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EFeatures: \u003Cstrong\u003EX={x\u003Cem\u003E1\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, x\u003Cem\u003E2\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, …x\u003Cem\u003En\u003C\u002Fem\u003E}\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ETherefore, the joint distribution of the model can be represented as\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E p(Y,X) = P(y,x\u003Cem\u003E1\u003C\u002Fem\u003E,x\u003Cem\u003E2\u003C\u002Fem\u003E…x\u003Cem\u003En\u003C\u002Fem\u003E)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow, our goal is to estimate the probability of spam email i.e, \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y=1|X)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. Both generative and discriminative models can solve this problem but in different ways.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"3d12\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003ELet’s see why and how they are different!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe approach of Generative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"3800\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EIn the case of generative models, to find the conditional probability\u003Cstrong\u003E P(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, they estimate the prior\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eprobability \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E and likelihood probability \u003Cstrong\u003EP(X|Y) \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Ewith the help of the training data and uses the Bayes Theorem to calculate the posterior probability \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y |X):\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"3800\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F1400\u002F1*l-3JCT9qwxWyLP_iVbzBmA.png\" alt=\"Discriminative and Generative Models approach\" width=\"700\" height=\"73\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe approach of Discriminative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"3800\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EIn the case of discriminative models, to find the probability, they directly assume some functional form for \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y|X) \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eand\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Ethen estimate the parameters of \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E with the help of the training data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat are Discriminative Models?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe discriminative model refers to a class of models used in \u003Cb\u003EStatistical Classification\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, mainly used for supervised machine learning. These types of models are also known as \u003Cb\u003Econditional models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E since they learn the boundaries between classes or labels in a dataset.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EDiscriminative models (just as in the literal meaning) separate classes instead of modeling the conditional probability and don&#8217;t make any assumptions about the data points. But these models are not capable of generating new data points. Therefore, the ultimate objective of discriminative models is to separate one class from another.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf we have some outliers present in the dataset, then discriminative models work better compared to generative models i.e, discriminative models are more robust to outliers. However, there is one major drawback of these models is the \u003Cb\u003Emisclassification problem\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, i.e., wrongly classifying a data point.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"f075\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F1400\u002F1*sY8G6iI6mr5mOy592A7WkQ.png\" alt=\"What is Discriminative and Generative Models \" width=\"700\" height=\"507\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"f075\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E                                                      Image Source: \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca class=\"btn\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@data_datum\u002Fdeep-learning-in-5-minutes-part-3-discriminative-vs-generative-models-8b27c616b8af\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EMathematical things involved in \u003Cspan style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EDiscriminative Models\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"592d\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Training discriminative classifiers involve estimating a function\u003Cb\u003E f: X -&gt; Y\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, or probability \u003Cb\u003EP(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"39cc\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EAssume some functional form for the probability such as \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"8e76\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EWith the help of training data, we estimate the parameters of \u003Cstrong\u003EP(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome Examples of Discriminative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"5650\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Logistic regression\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"cdd4\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EScalar Vector Machine (SVMs)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"ddd9\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Traditional neural networks\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"70b7\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Nearest neighbor\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"13b9\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EConditional Random Fields (CRFs)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"13b9\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EDecision Trees and Random Forest\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat are Generative Models?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EGenerative models are considered as a class of statistical models that can generate new data instances. These models are used in unsupervised machine learning as a means to perform tasks such as\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EProbability and Likelihood estimation,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EModeling data points,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ETo describe the phenomenon in data,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ETo distinguish between classes based on these probabilities.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESince these types of models often rely on the Bayes theorem to find the joint probability, so generative models can tackle a more complex task than analogous discriminative models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"a797\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003ESo, Generative models focus on the distribution of individual classes in a dataset and the learning algorithms tend to model the underlying patterns or distribution of the data points. These models use the concept of joint probability and create the instances where a given \u003Cb\u003Efeature (\u003Cem\u003Ex\u003C\u002Fem\u003E) \u003C\u002Fb\u003Eor input and the desired output or\u003Cb\u003E label (\u003Cem\u003Ey\u003C\u002Fem\u003E)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E exist at the same time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"0e20\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EThese models use \u003Cb\u003Eprobability estimates\u003C\u002Fb\u003E and \u003Cb\u003Elikelihood\u003C\u002Fb\u003E to model data points and differentiate between different class labels present in a dataset. Unlike discriminative models, these models are also capable of generating new data points.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"0e20\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EHowever, they also have a major drawback &#8211; If there is a presence of outliers in the dataset, then it affects these types of models to a significant extent.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"0e20\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F1146\u002F1*Dl2yS5t0_9O_mG_BmHs2xw.png\" alt=\"models\" width=\"573\" height=\"471\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"0e20\" class=\"\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E                                                        Image Source: \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca class=\"btn\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@data_datum\u002Fdeep-learning-in-5-minutes-part-3-discriminative-vs-generative-models-8b27c616b8af\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELink\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb style=\"font-size: 26px; text-align: left;\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EMathematical things involved in \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003EGenerative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp id=\"592d\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Training generative classifiers involve estimating a function \u003Cb\u003Ef: X -&gt; Y\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, or probability \u003Cb\u003EP(Y|X):\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"54f4\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EAssume some functional form for the probabilities such as \u003Cb\u003EP(Y), P(X|Y)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"4440\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EWith the help of training data, we estimate the parameters of \u003Cb\u003EP(X|Y), P(Y)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"d0ff\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EUse the Bayes theorem to calculate the posterior probability \u003Cb\u003EP(Y |X)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome Examples of Generative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"6d1c\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Naïve Bayes\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"2078\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EBayesian networks\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"64a6\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EMarkov random fields\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"df4f\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003E‌Hidden Markov Models (HMMs)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"df4f\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003ELatent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"df4f\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EGenerative Adversarial Networks (GANs)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli id=\"df4f\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"\u003EAutoregressive Model\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EDifference between Discriminative and Generative Models\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s see some of the differences between Discriminative and Generative Models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECore Idea\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDiscriminative models draw boundaries in the data space, while generative models try to model how data is placed throughout the space. A generative model focuses on explaining how the data was generated, while a discriminative model focuses on predicting the labels of the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EMathematical Intuition\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn mathematical terms, a discriminative machine learning trains a model which is done by learning parameters that maximize the conditional probability\u003Cb\u003E P(Y|X)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E, while on the other hand, a generative model learns parameters by maximizing the joint probability of\u003Cb\u003E P(X, Y)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EApplications\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EDiscriminative models recognize existing data i.e, discriminative modeling identifies tags and sorts data and can be used to classify data while Generative modeling produces something.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESince these models use different approaches to machine learning, so both are suited for specific tasks i.e, Generative models are useful for unsupervised learning tasks while discriminative models are useful for supervised learning tasks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOutliers\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EGenerative models have more impact on outliers than discriminative models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EComputational Cost\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDiscriminative models are computationally cheap as compared to generative models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EComparison between Discriminative and Generative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s see some of the comparisons based on the following criteria between Discriminative and Generative Models:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPerformance\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EMissing Data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAccuracy Score\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EApplications\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EBased on Performance\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EGenerative models need fewer data to train compared with discriminative models since generative models are more biased as they make stronger assumptions i.e, \u003Cb\u003Eassumption of conditional independence\u003C\u002Fb\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EBased on Missing Data\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn general, if we have missing data in our dataset, then Generative models can work with these missing data, while on the contrary discriminative models can’t. This is because, in generative models, still we can estimate the posterior by marginalizing over the unseen variables. However, for discriminative models, we usually require all the features X to be observed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EBased on Accuracy Score\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf the assumption of conditional independence violates, then at that time generative models are less accurate than discriminative models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EBased on Applications \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EDiscriminative models are called \u003Cb\u003E“discriminative”\u003C\u002Fb\u003E since they are useful for discriminating Y’s label i.e, target outcome, so they can only solve classification problems while Generative models have more applications besides classification such as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESamplings,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EBayes learning,\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EMAP inference, etc.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESelf Learning Resource\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf you want to go into the deep concepts about Discriminative and Generative Models, then read the following paper by \u003Cb\u003EProfessor Andrew Ng\u003C\u002Fb\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fai.stanford.edu\u002F~ang\u002Fpapers\u002Fnips01-discriminativegenerative.pdf\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EGenerative and Discriminative Models\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOther Blog Posts by Me\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can also check my previous blog posts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Fchirag676\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPrevious Data Science Blog posts.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ELinkedIn\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp noreferrer\"\u003Emy Linkedin profile\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E in case you want to connect with me. I’ll be happy to be connected with you.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EEmail\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor any queries, you can mail me on \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F06\u002Fpart-20-step-by-step-guide-to-master-nlp-information-retrieval\u002Fchiraggoyaliit@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGmail\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003EThanks for reading!\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI hope that you have enjoyed the article. Science (both Machine Learning and Deep Learning …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2166\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2166\"\u003EIntroduction:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe have witnessed many Data Science (both Machine Learning and Deep Learning techniques) algorithms in numerous application fields. But in reality, when compared to many applications, there will be very few articles or open-source available for Bio-Medical related signals. We might be wondering about, Bio-Medical field is the hottest research going on right now, and also another interesting thing is knowing about our own human body is always interesting to research when compared to other sophisticated research because it&#8217;s our own system. So in this article, we will see some interesting applications that might be helpful for beginners who can understand and explore the field of Bio-Medical Signal Processing with the help of Data Science.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F73904Common-physiological-and-physical-measures-related-to-stress-investigated-in-this-study.png\" alt=\"Biomedical data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"850\" height=\"957\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fwww.researchgate.net\u002Fpublication\u002F334352064_Review_on_psychological_stress_detection_using_biosignals\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDimensional in Data:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo before we get into the topic, we must understand basic terminology to understand &#8211; &#8216;Dimensional&#8217;. We came across, this word w.r.t to image processing technique right! and in many applications too. Let&#8217;s understand what is dimension first then what are the different dimensions in data, Dimension in mathematics can be defined as a measurement (a measure of distance, size, or any region or maybe space), and w.r.t to Physics, Dimension is defined as the magnitude of something in a particular direction. In fact, our lives are encircled by three dimensions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F342141564720746_dimensions-4.png\" alt=\"Dimensional data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"681\" height=\"330\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDifferent types of Dimensions in Data:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EI hope now we understand about dimension, let&#8217;s understand about different dimension, predominantly we have,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E0-D &#8211; Zero Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1-D- One Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2-D- Two Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3-D- Three Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4-D- Four-Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F12132The-Geometry-of-Fourth-Dimension-and-Space-Time-Continuum-three-dimensions.jpg\" alt=\"different dimensions in data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"1920\" height=\"887\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fdigitash.com\u002Fscience\u002Fthe-geometry-of-the-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s get some deep explanation,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EZero-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFrom the above diagram, we can easily understand that for all simple to complex diagrams, the base point is a dot, so for that DOT, we don&#8217;t have any direction or magnitude because of its characteristics. Hence DOT has no dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOne-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOk! So what do we do with the dot? let&#8217;s draw a straight line, we have two options we can draw a straight line either on the X-axis or on the Y-axis, for a mathematical point of view, let&#8217;s assume to draw the line horizontally i.e., the X-axis. So by drawing the line we can easily measure the length right? (how much cm or in m or in any measurement). So from this, we can say that this straight line is one dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETwo-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOn continuation with One-dimension, (straight line &#8211; X-axis), draw another straight line to form a square (X-axis or Y-axis irrespective with one dimensional), Square shape which has two dimensions,i.e., length (first dimension) and width (second dimension), so it has two dimensions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThree-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E Again from the continuation from Two Dimension, Square, continue to draw another straight line apart from X and Y axis, i.e., Z-axis, and make a square to cube shape. Now we have length, width as of square shape (two-dimension), and also another newly formed dimension, i.e., height (through cube), so for cube shape, we have three-dimension (by including one straight line from square)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFourth-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E Lastly from cube shape (three-dimension), if it&#8217;s considered in the point of stationery then it&#8217;s in three-dimension when you rotate the same cube from one place to another place say for example in a slide, it moves from a stationary state to non-stationary i.e., moving (one place to another), here if you consider closely, then you can understand another measurement as time (Einstein who introduced 4th dimension &#8211; TIME from three-dimension, added time flows in the forward direction only unlike cinematically as TIME MACHINE concept &#8211; Reverse process which is practically not possible)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F63164Time-for-the-geometry-of-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum.jpg\" alt=\"dimension and space time \" width=\"1716\" height=\"954\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fdigitash.com\u002Fscience\u002Fthe-geometry-of-the-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat is Bio-Signal Processing:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe are running behind machines to do smart work in this data science or artificial intelligence-related technology. But our own human body is a natural machine and are regularly communicating about our health too and from this machine, through some natural sensors (through physiological instruments like ECG, EEG, PPG&#8230;) like heart, brain, skin, fingers and other parts, we can able get some useful information or we call it as DATA (maybe through image or through numbers) in simple. Still, our human body is a BLACK-BOX, discovering so much useful research like how we can alarm ourselves before our human body may damage any organs or life-threatening problems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo signals that we are getting from living things like from our human body, we call it as Bio-Medical signal. From that signal we are going to process and analyze it, to get some useful information related to our health we call it Biomedical Signal Processing in simple. In another word, it&#8217;s almost replacing doctors physically and from the ML\u002F DL technology we can come to know whether we are normal or abnormal, detecting some abnormalities from the Medical Image. For example, measuring heart rate, oxygen saturation, or even blood pressure at home is practically feasible today, either using a mobile phone (high-end Samsung or iPhone users) or using some low-cost special gadgets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome important Bio-Signals:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E1. Electrocardiogram &#8211; Heart\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E2. Electromyography &#8211; Skeletal muscles\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E3. Electroencephalography &#8211; Brain\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E4. Electrooculography &#8211; Corneo-Retinal (Eye)\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E5. Electroretinography &#8211; Retina\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E6. Electrogastrogram &#8211; Stomach\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E7. Phonocardiogram &#8211; Plot of high-fidelity recording of the sounds and murmurs made by the heart\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E8. Photoplethysmography &#8211; Blood volume changes in the microvascular bed of tissue and many more&#8230;\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EElectroCardioGram:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EECG is the abbreviated term for an electrocardiogram, which means it is used to record the electrical activity in simple working conditions of our heart from different perspectives or angles we call it technically. For most of them, if we say about ECG, they visualize the spikes, some people recognize it as PQRST-U waveform. To be simple our whole life is closely related to this PQRST-U rhythm only. There are so many patterns that occur in this rhythm and from that, if we monitored properly we can save most of our life from many deadly diseases too. As ECG signal has some regular pattern that we visually see through a monitor or get from electrodes, if some person is going to get heart attack let us consider, through some pattern change from the regular one we can easily find out well in advance from ECG, so that we can take some precautionary method either by taking some medication or admit in hospital.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F64600Most-common-waveform-of-the-classical-ECG-curve.png\" alt=\"Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"850\" height=\"493\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fwww.researchgate.net\u002Ffigure\u002FMost-common-waveform-of-the-classical-ECG-curve_fig1_325056456\u002Fdownload\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESome of the terms are explained as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EP Waves &#8211; Atrial Depolarization (electrical shift between negative and positive ions)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EPR Interval &#8211; Start of the P wave and ends at the beginning of the Q wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EQRS Complex &#8211; Ventricle Depolarization\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EST-Segment &#8211; Starts at the end of the S wave and ends at the beginning of the T wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ET Wave- Ventricular Repolarization\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ERR Interval &#8211; Between QRS complex\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EQT Interval &#8211; Starts at the beginning of QRS complex and ends at T wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOpen-Source for ECG Database:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are many open sources available for collecting ECG real data. But among the most famous database is \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fphysionet.org\u002F \u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003EHere you can get efficient raw signals to work in ECG-based applications.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EArtificial Neural Network:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe discussed already Artificial Neural Network (ANN) in detail in the following article with python code. Please find the link for better understanding, (\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fpreview\u002Flink\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F06\u002Fartificial-neural-networks-better-understanding\u002F\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EANN &#8211; ECG Python Code:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDataset: \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.kaggle.com\u002Fshayanfazeli\u002Fheartbeat\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#importing some basic libraries\r\nimport numpy as np\r\nimport pandas as pd\r\nimport seaborn as sns\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\nfrom sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split\r\nfrom imblearn.over_sampling import SMOTE\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#importing datasets\r\nnormal = pd.read_csv('ptbdb_normal.csv')\r\nabnormal = pd.read_csv('ptbdb_abnormal.csv')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing normal dataset\r\nnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing abnormal dataset\r\nabnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#dimenion for normal\r\nnormal.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#dimension for abnormal\r\nabnormal.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#changing the random column names to sequential - normal\r\n#as we have some numbers name as columns we need to change that to numbers as\r\nfor normals in normal:\r\n    normal.columns = list(range(len(normal.columns)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing edited columns for normal data\r\nnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#changing the random column names to sequential - abnormal\r\n#as we have some numbers name as columns we need to change that to numbers as\r\nfor abnormals in abnormal:\r\n    abnormal.columns = list(range(len(abnormal.columns)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing edited columns for abnormal data\r\nabnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#combining two data into one\r\n#suffling the dataset and dropping the index\r\n#As when concatenating we all have arranged 0 and 1 class in order manner\r\ndataset = pd.concat([normal, abnormal], axis=0).sample(frac=1.0, random_state =0).reset_index(drop=True)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing combined dataset\r\ndataset.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#whole dataset size\r\ndataset.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#basic info of statistics\r\ndataset.describe()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#basic information of dataset\r\ndataset.info()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing the uniqueness in dataset\r\ndataset.nunique()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#skewness of the dataset\r\n#the deviation of the distribution of the data from a normal distribution\r\n#+ve mean &gt; median &gt; mode\r\n#-ve mean &lt; median &lt; mode\r\ndataset.skew()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#kurtosis of dataset\r\n#identifies whether the tails of a given distribution contain extreme values\r\n#Leptokurtic indicates a positive excess kurtosis\r\n#mesokurtic distribution shows an excess kurtosis of zero or close to zero\r\n#platykurtic distribution shows a negative excess kurtosis\r\ndataset.kurtosis()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#missing values any from the dataset\r\nprint(str('Any missing data or NaN in the dataset:'), dataset.isnull().values.any())\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#data ranges in the dataset - sample\r\nprint(\"The minimum and maximum values are {}, {}\".format(np.min(dataset.iloc[-2,:].values), np.max(dataset.iloc[-2,:].values)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#correlation for all features in the dataset\r\ncorrelation_data =dataset.corr()\r\nprint(correlation_data)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#visulaization for correlation\r\nplt.figure(figsize=(10,7.5))\r\nsns.heatmap(correlation_data, annot=True, cmap='BrBG')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#for target value count\r\nlabel_dataset = dataset[187].value_counts()\r\nlabel_dataset\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#visualization for target label\r\nlabel_dataset.plot.bar()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#splitting dataset to dependent and independent variable\r\nX = dataset.iloc[:,:-1].values #independent values \u002F features\r\ny = dataset.iloc[:,-1].values #dependent values \u002F target\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#checking imbalance of the labels\r\nfrom collections import Counter\r\ncounter_before = Counter(y)\r\nprint(counter_before)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#applying SMOTE for imbalance\r\noversample = SMOTE()\r\nX, y = oversample.fit_resample(X, y)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#after applying SMOTE for imbalance condition\r\ncounter_after = Counter(y)\r\nprint(counter_after)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#splitting the datasets for training and testing process\r\nX_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size =0.3, random_state=42)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#size for the sets\r\nprint('size of X_train:', X_train.shape)\r\nprint('size of X_test:', X_test.shape)\r\nprint('size of y_train:', y_train.shape)\r\nprint('size of y_test:', y_test.shape)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#ANN\r\nimport tensorflow as tf\r\n# Create \u002F initialize sequential model \r\nann_model = tf.keras.models.Sequential()\r\n#Dense layer as first layer with 10 neurons, input share (187,) and and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001), input_shape=(187,)))\r\n#Dense layer as second layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Dense layer as third layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Dense layer as fourth layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Softmax as last layer with two outputs\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(2, activation='softmax'))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy'])\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model.summary()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F424591.png\" alt=\"Model summary\" width=\"602\" height=\"341\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model_history = ann_model.fit(X_train, y_train, epochs=50, batch_size = 10, validation_data = (X_test, y_test))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F886242.png\" alt=\"Training\" width=\"1101\" height=\"373\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F266763.png\" alt=\"Training contd. | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"1105\" height=\"356\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['accuracy'])\r\n\r\nplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['val_accuracy'])\r\n\r\nplt.legend([\"accuracy\",\"val_accuracy\"])\r\n\r\nplt.title('Accuracy Vs Val_Accuracy')\r\n\r\nplt.xlabel('Epoch')\r\n\r\nplt.ylabel('Accuracy')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\r\n    \u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F344715.png\" alt=\"Accuracy vs validation \" width=\"466\" height=\"318\" \u002F\u003E\r\n        \r\n\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['loss'])\r\nplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['val_loss'])\r\nplt.legend([\"loss\",\"val_loss\"])\r\nplt.title('Loss Vs Val_loss')\r\nplt.xlabel('Epoch')\r\nplt.ylabel('Loss')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F741064.png\" alt=\"loss vs val loss\" width=\"456\" height=\"313\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFor Github link: \u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener
