Questions to test a data scientist on Natural Language Processing [Solution: Skilltest – NLP]","sub_title":"","description":"Introduction Humans are social animals and language is our primary tool to communicate with the society. But, what if machines could understand our language …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp align=\"justify\"\u003EHumans are social animals and language is our primary tool to communicate with the society. But, what if machines could understand our language and then act accordingly? Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the science of teaching machines how to understand the language we humans speak and write.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe recently launched an NLP skill test on which a total of 817 people registered. This skill test was designed to test your knowledge of Natural Language Processing. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-text-mining\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E ranking for all the participants.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow are the distribution scores, they will help you evaluate your performance.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-37067 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F30153341\u002Fskilltest_NLP2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"498\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F30153341\u002Fskilltest_NLP2.png 498w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F30153341\u002Fskilltest_NLP2-300x157.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 498px) 100vw, 498px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can access the scores \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-text-mining\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. More than 250 people participated in the skill test and the highest score obtained was 24.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in-depth knowledge of the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F04\u002Fnatural-language-processing-made-easy-using-spacy-%E2%80%8Bin-python\u002F\"\u003ENatural Language Processing Made Easy – using SpaCy ( in Python)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fultimate-guide-to-understand-implement-natural-language-processing-codes-in-python\u002F\"\u003EUltimate Guide to Understand &amp; Implement Natural Language Processing (with codes in Python)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill Test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EQ1 Which of the following techniques can be used for the purpose of keyword normalization, the process of converting a keyword into its base form?\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELemmatization\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELevenshtein\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EStemming\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESoundex\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 2 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 1, 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 2, 3 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nF) 1, 2, 3 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELemmatization and stemming are the techniques of keyword normalization, while Levenshtein and Soundex are techniques of string matching.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cstrong\u003E2) N-grams are defined as the combination of N keywords together. How many bi-grams can be generated from given sentence: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Analytics Vidhya is a great source to learn data science”\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 7\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 8\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 9\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 10\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 11\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBigrams: Analytics Vidhya, Vidhya is, is a, a great, great source, source to, To learn, learn data, data science\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3) How many trigrams phrases can be generated from the following sentence, after performing following text cleaning steps:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EStopword Removal\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EReplacing punctuations by a single space\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E“#Analytics-vidhya is a great source to learn @data_science.”\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 5\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 7\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter performing stopword removal and punctuation replacement the text becomes: &#8220;Analytics vidhya great source learn data science&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrigrams &#8211; Analytics vidhya great, vidhya great source, great source learn, source learn data, learn data science\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4) Which of the following regular expression can be used to identify date(s) present in the text object: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E“The next meetup on data science will be held on 2017-09-21, previously it happened on 31\u002F03, 2016”\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) \\d{4}-\\d{2}-\\d{2}\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) (19|20)\\d{2}-(0[1-9]|1[0-2])-[0-2][1-9]\nC) (19|20)\\d{2}-(0[1-9]|1[0-2])-([0-2][1-9]|3[0-1])\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENone if these expressions would be able to identify the dates in this text object.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EQuestion Context 5-6:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou have collected a data of about 10,000 rows of tweet text and no other information. You want to create a tweet classification model that categorizes each of the tweets in three buckets &#8211; positive, negative and neutral.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E5) Which of the following models can perform tweet classification with regards to context mentioned above? \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Naive Bayes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) SVM\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESince, you are given only the data of tweets and no other information, which means there is no target variable present. One cannot train a supervised learning model, both svm and naive bayes are supervised learning techniques.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E6) You have created a document term matrix of the data, treating every tweet as one document. Which of the following is correct, in regards to document term matrix?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ERemoval of stopwords from the data will affect the dimensionality of data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENormalization of words in the data will reduce the dimensionality of data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EConverting all the words in lowercase will \u003Cu\u003Enot\u003C\u002Fu\u003E affect the dimensionality of the data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Only 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Only 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Only 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nF) 1, 2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChoices A and B are correct because stopword removal will decrease the number of features in the matrix, normalization of words will also reduce redundant features, and, converting all words to lowercase will also decrease the dimensionality.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E7) Which of the following features can be used for accuracy improvement of a classification model\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Frequency count of terms\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Vector Notation of sentence\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Part of Speech Tag\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Dependency Grammar\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) All of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (E)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of the techniques can be used for the purpose of engineering features in a model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E8) What percentage of the total statements are correct with regards to Topic Modeling?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is a supervised learning technique\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELDA (Linear Discriminant Analysis) can be used to perform topic modeling\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESelection of number of topics in a model does not depend on the size of data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENumber of topic terms are directly proportional to size of the data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 0\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 25\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 50\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 75\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 100\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (A)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELDA is unsupervised learning model, LDA is latent Dirichlet allocation, not Linear discriminant analysis. Selection of the number of topics is directly proportional to the size of the data, while number of topic terms is not directly proportional to the size of the data. Hence none of the statements are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E9) In Latent Dirichlet Allocation model for text classification purposes, what does alpha and beta hyperparameter represent-\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Alpha: number of topics within documents, beta: number of terms within topics False\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Alpha: density of terms generated within topics, beta: density of topics generated within terms False\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Alpha: number of topics within documents, beta: number of terms within topics False\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Alpha: density of topics generated within documents, beta: density of terms generated within topics True\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOption D is correct\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E10) Solve the equation according to the sentence &#8220;I am planning to visit New Delhi to attend Analytics Vidhya Delhi Hackathon&#8221;.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA = (# of words with Noun as the part of speech tag)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB = (# of words with Verb as the part of speech tag)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC = (# of words with frequency count greater than one)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat are the correct values of A, B, and C?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 5, 5, 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 5, 5, 0\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 7, 5, 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 7, 4, 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 6, 4, 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENouns: I, New, Delhi, Analytics, Vidhya, Delhi, Hackathon (7)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVerbs: am, planning, visit, attend (4)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWords with frequency counts &gt; 1: to, Delhi (2)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHence option D is correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E11) In a corpus of N documents, one document is randomly picked. The document contains a total of T terms and the term “data” appears K times. \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat is the correct value for the product of TF (term frequency) and IDF (inverse-document-frequency), if the term “data” appears in approximately one-third of the total documents?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) KT * Log(3)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) K * Log(3) \u002F T\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) T * Log(3) \u002F K\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Log(3) \u002F KT\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Eformula for TF is K\u002FT\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Eformula for IDF is log(total docs \u002F no of docs containing “data”)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E= log(1 \u002F (⅓))\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E= log (3)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHence correct choice is Klog(3)\u002FT\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EQuestion Context 12 to 14:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERefer the following document term matrix\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F05\u002F31130818\u002FPicture1.png\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E12) Which of the following documents contains the same number of terms and the number of terms in the one of the document is not equal to least number of terms in any document in the entire corpus. \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) d1 and d4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) d6 and d7\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) d2 and d4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) d5 and d6\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth of the documents d2 and d4 contains 4 terms and does not contain the least number of terms which is 3.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E13) Which are the most common and the rarest term of the corpus?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) t4, t6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) t3, t5\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) t5, t1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) t5, t6\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (A)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ET5 is most common terms across 5 out of 7 documents, T6 is rare term only appears in d3 and d4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E14) What is the term frequency of a term which is used a maximum number of times in that document? \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) t6 &#8211; 2\u002F5\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) t3 &#8211; 3\u002F6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) t4 &#8211; 2\u002F6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) t1 &#8211; 2\u002F6\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Et3 is used max times in entire corpus = 3, tf for t3 is 3\u002F6\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E15) Which of the following technique is not a part of flexible text matching?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Soundex\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Metaphone\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Edit Distance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Keyword Hashing\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExcept Keyword Hashing all other are the techniques used in flexible string matching\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"color: #0000ff;\"\u003E\u003Ca style=\"color: #0000ff;\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftrainings.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fcourse-v1:AnalyticsVidhya+NLP101+2018_T1\u002Fabout?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=30-questions-test-data-scientist-natural-language-processing-solution-skilltest-nlp\"\u003EFeel like improving your skillset? Click Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E16) True or False: Word2Vec model is a machine learning model used to create vector notations of text objects. Word2vec contains multiple deep neural networks\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWord2vec also contains preprocessing model which is not a deep neural network\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E17) Which of the following statement is(are) true for Word2Vec model?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The architecture of word2vec consists of only two layers &#8211; continuous bag of words and skip-gram model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Continuous bag of word is a shallow neural network model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Skip-gram is a deep neural network model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Both CBOW and Skip-gram are deep neural network models\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWord2vec contains the Continuous bag of words and skip-gram models, which are deep neural nets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E18) With respect to this context-free dependency graphs, how many sub-trees exists in the sentence?\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F05\u002F31133701\u002Fq181.png\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nA) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 5\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 6\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESubtrees in the dependency graph can be viewed as nodes having an outward link, for example:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMedia, networking, play, role, billions, and lives are the roots of subtrees\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E19) What is the right order for a text classification model components\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EText cleaning\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EText annotation\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGradient descent\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EModel tuning\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EText to predictors\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 12345\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 13425\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 12534\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 13452\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA right text classification model contains &#8211; cleaning of text to remove noise, annotation to create more features, converting text-based features into predictors, learning a model using gradient descent and finally tuning a model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E20) Polysemy is defined as the coexistence of multiple meanings for a word or phrase in a text object. Which of the following models is likely the best choice to correct this problem?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Random Forest Classifier\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Convolutional Neural Networks\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Gradient Boosting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) All of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECNNs are popular choice for text classification problems because they take into consideration left and right contexts of the words as features which can solve the problem of polysemy\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E21) Which of the following models can be used for the purpose of document similarity?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Training a word 2 vector model on the corpus that learns context present in the document\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Training a bag of words model that learns occurrence of words in the document\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Creating a document-term matrix and using cosine similarity for each document\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Eword2vec model can be used for measuring document similarity based on context. Bag Of Words and document term matrix can be used for measuring similarity based on terms.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E22) What are the possible features of a text corpus \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECount of word in a document\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EBoolean feature &#8211; presence of word in a document\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EVector notation of word\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPart of Speech Tag\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EBasic Dependency Grammar\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EEntire document as a feature\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 12\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 123\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 1234\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nE) 12345\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nF) 123456\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (E)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExcept for entire document as the feature, rest all can be used as features of text classification learning model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E23) While creating a machine learning model on text data, you created a document term matrix of the input data of 100K documents. Which of the following remedies can be used to reduce the dimensions of data &#8211; \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELatent Dirichlet Allocation\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELatent Semantic Indexing\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EKeyword Normalization\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) only 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 2, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 1, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 1, 2, 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of the techniques can be used to reduce the dimensions of the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E24) Google Search’s feature &#8211; “Did you mean”, is a mixture of different techniques. Which of the following techniques are likely to be ingredients?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECollaborative Filtering model to detect similar user behaviors (queries)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EModel that checks for Levenshtein distance among the dictionary terms\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ETranslation of sentences into multiple languages\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) 1, 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) 1, 2, 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (C)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECollaborative filtering can be used to check what are the patterns used by people, Levenshtein is used to measure the distance among dictionary terms.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E25) While working with text data obtained from news sentences, which are structured in nature, which of the grammar-based text parsing techniques can be used for noun phrase detection, verb phrase detection, subject detection and object detection.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Part of speech tagging\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Dependency Parsing and Constituency Parsing\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Skip Gram and N-Gram extraction\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Continuous Bag of Words\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDependency and constituent parsing extract these relations from the text\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E26) Social Media platforms are the most intuitive form of text data. You are given a corpus of complete social media data of tweets. How can you create a model that suggests the hashtags? \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Perform Topic Models to obtain most significant words of the corpus\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Train a Bag of Ngrams model to capture top n-grams &#8211; words and their combinations\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Train a word2vector model to learn repeating contexts in the sentences\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) All of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of the techniques can be used to extract most significant terms of a corpus.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E27) While working with context extraction from a text data, you encountered two different sentences: The tank is full of soldiers. The tank is full of nitrogen. Which of the following measures can be used to remove the problem of word sense disambiguation in the sentences? \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Compare the dictionary definition of an ambiguous word with the terms contained in its neighborhood\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Co-reference resolution in which one resolute the meaning of ambiguous word with the proper noun present in the previous sentence\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Use dependency parsing of sentence to understand the meanings\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (A)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOption 1 is called Lesk algorithm, used for word sense disambiguation, rest others cannot be used.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E28) Collaborative Filtering and Content Based Models are the two popular recommendation engines, what role does NLP play in building such algorithms.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Feature Extraction from text\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Measuring Feature Similarity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Engineering Features for vector space learning model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) All of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (D)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENLP can be used anywhere where text data is involved &#8211; feature extraction, measuring feature similarity, create vector features of the text.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E29) Retrieval based models and Generative models are the two popular techniques used for building chatbots. Which of the following is an example of retrieval model and generative model respectively.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Dictionary based learning and Word 2 vector model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) Rule-based learning and Sequence to Sequence model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Word 2 vector and Sentence to Vector model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Recurrent neural network and convolutional neural network\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Echoice 2 best explains examples of retrieval based models and generative models\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E30) What is the major difference between CRF (Conditional Random Field) and HMM (Hidden Markov Model)?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA) CRF is Generative whereas HMM is Discriminative model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nB) CRF is Discriminative whereas HMM is Generative model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nC) Both CRF and HMM are Generative model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nD) Both CRF and HMM are Discriminative model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: (B)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOption B is correct\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions\u002Fdoubts please drop in your comments below. And I would love to hear the feedback about the skill test. Feel free to share them in comments below. And it deserves the attention, as deep learning is helping us achieve the AI dream of getting near human performance in every day tasks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EGiven the importance to learn Deep learning for a data scientist, we created a skill test to help people assess themselves on Deep Learning. Interestingly, the distribution of scores ended up being very similar to past 2 tests:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fmust-know-questions-deep-learning\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EDeep Learning skill test &#8211; January 2017\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F04\u002F40-questions-test-data-scientist-deep-learning\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EDeep Learning skill power &#8211; April 2017\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EClearly, a lot of people start the test without understanding Deep Learning, which is not the case with other skill tests. This also means that these solutions would be useful to a lot of people.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca Scratch\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca Neural Networks in Python (using Theano)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca Deep Learning in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Ftutorial-optimizing-neural-networks-using-keras-with-image-recognition-case-study\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003ETutorial: Optimizing Neural Networks using Keras (with Image recognition case study)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"entry-title\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fan-introduction-to-implementing-neural-networks-using-tensorflow\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EAn Introduction to Implementing Neural Networks using TensorFlow\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1) Is the data linearly separable?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19172951\u002FImage36.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-36588 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19172951\u002FImage36.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"195\" height=\"134\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you can draw a line or plane between the data points, it is said to be linearly separable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) Which of the following are universal approximators?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Kernel SVM\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Neural Networks\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Boosted Decision Trees\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of the above methods can approximate any function.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) In which of the following applications can we use deep learning to solve the problem?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Protein structure prediction\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Prediction of chemical reactions\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Detection of exotic particles\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWe can use neural network to approximate any function so it can theoretically be used to solve any problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) Which of the following statements is true when you use 1&#215;1 convolutions in a CNN?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) It can help in dimensionality reduction\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) It can be used for feature pooling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) It suffers less overfitting due to small kernel size\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1&#215;1 convolutions are called bottleneck structure in CNN.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) \u003C\u002Fb\u003EQuestion Context:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EStatement 1: It is possible to train a network well by initializing all the weights as 0\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nStatement 2: It is possible to train a network well by initializing biases as 0\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhich of the statements given above is true?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Statement 1 is true while Statement 2 is false\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Statement 2 is true while statement 1 is false\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both statements are true\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Both statements are false\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EEven if all the biases are zero, there is a chance that neural network may learn. On the other hand, if all the weights are zero; the neural neural network may never learn to perform the task.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) The number of nodes in the input layer is 10 and the hidden layer is 5. The maximum number of connections from the input layer to the hidden layer are\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 50\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Less than 50\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) More than 50\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) It is an arbitrary value\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESince MLP is a fully connected directed graph, the number of connections are a multiple of number of nodes in input layer and hidden layer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) The input image has been converted into a matrix of size 28 X 28 and a kernel\u002Ffilter of size 7 X 7 with a stride of 1. What will be the size of the convoluted matrix?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 22 X 22\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 21 X 21\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 28 X 28\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 7 X 7\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe size of the convoluted matrix is given by C=((I-F+2P)\u002FS)+1, where C is the size of the Convoluted matrix, I is the size of the input matrix, F the size of the filter matrix and P the padding applied to the input matrix. Here P=0, I=28, F=7 and S=1.  There the answer is 22.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) In a simple MLP model with 8 neurons in the input layer, 5 neurons in the hidden layer and 1 neuron in the output layer. What is the size of the weight matrices between hidden output layer and input hidden layer?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) [1 X 5] , [5 X 8]\r\n\u003Cp\u003EB) [8 X 5] , [ 1 X 5]\r\n\u003Cp\u003EC) [8 X 5] , [5 X 1]\r\n\u003Cp\u003ED) [5 x 1] , [8 X 5]\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe size of weights between any layer 1 and layer 2 Is given by [nodes in layer 1 X nodes in layer 2]\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E9) Given below is an input matrix named I, kernel F and Convoluted matrix named C. Which of the following is the correct option for matrix C with stride =2 ?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" eliminated since they do not conform to the output size for a stride of 2. Upon calculation option 3 is the correct answer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E10) Given below is an input matrix of shape 7 X 7. What will be the output on applying a max pooling of size 3 X 3 with a stride of 2?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" height=\"67\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EMax pooling takes a 3 X 3 matrix and takes the maximum of the matrix as the output. Slide it over the entire input matrix with a stride of 2 and you will get option (1) as the answer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) Which of the following functions can be used as an activation function in the output layer if we wish to predict the probabilities of n classes (p1, p2..pk) such that sum of p over all n equals to 1?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Softmax\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) ReLu\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Sigmoid\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Tanh\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESoftmax function is of the form  in which the sum of probabilities over all k sum to 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E12) Assume a simple MLP model with 3 neurons and inputs= 1,2,3. The weights to the input neurons are 4,5 and 6 respectively. Assume the activation function is a linear constant value of 3. What will be the output ?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 32\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 643\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 96\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 48\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe output will be calculated as 3(1*4+2*5+6*3) = 96\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) Which of following activation function can&#8217;t be used at output layer to classify an image ?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) sigmoid\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Tanh\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) ReLU\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) If(x&gt;5,1,0)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) None of the above\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EReLU gives continuous output in range 0 to infinity. But in output layer, we want a finite range of values. So option C is correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) [True | False] In the neural network, every parameter can have their different learning rate.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYes, we can define the learning rate for each parameter and it can be different from other parameters.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Dropout can be applied at visible layer of Neural Network model?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ELook at the below model architecture, we have added a new Dropout layer between the input (or visible layer) and the first hidden layer. The dropout rate is set to 20%, meaning one in 5 inputs will be randomly excluded from each update cycle.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Edef \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Ecreate_model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E: \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \r\n    # create model \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003E \r\n    model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003ESequential\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003E \r\n    model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Eadd\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003EDropout\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-cn\"\u003E0.2\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Einput_shape\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-cn\"\u003E60\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003E \r\n    model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Eadd\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003EDense\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-cn\"\u003E60\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Eactivation\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-s\"\u003E'relu')\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \r\n    \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Emodel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Eadd\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003EDense\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-cn\"\u003E1\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Eactivation\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-s\"\u003E'sigmoid'\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-p\"\u003E \r\n    # Compile model \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003E sgd\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003ESGD\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Elr\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-cn\"\u003E0.1\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003E \r\n    model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Ecompile\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Eloss\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-s\"\u003E'binary_crossentropy'\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Eoptimizer\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Esgd\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-v\"\u003Emetrics\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-o\"\u003E=\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E[\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-s\"\u003E'accuracy'\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E]\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-sy\"\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"crayon-st\"\u003E \r\n    return\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"crayon-e\"\u003Emodel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cstrong\u003EI am working with the fully connected architecture having one hidden layer with 3 neurons and one output neuron to solve a binary classification challenge. Below is the structure of input and output:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput dataset: [ [1,0,1,0] , [1,0,1,1] , [0,1,0,1] ]\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOutput: [ [1] , [1] , [0] ]\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETo train the model, I have initialized all weights for hidden and output layer with 1.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat do you say model will able to learn the pattern in the data?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAs all the weights of the neural network model are same, so all the neurons will try to do the same thing and the model will never converge.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E17) Which of the following neural network training challenge can be solved using batch normalization?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Overfitting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Restrict activations to become too high or low\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Training is too slow\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Both B and C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBatch normalization restricts the activations and indirectly improves training time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E18) Which of the following would have a constant input in each epoch of training a Deep Learning model?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Weight between input and hidden layer\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Weight between hidden and output layer\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Biases of all hidden layer neurons\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Activation function of output layer\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWeights between input and hidden layer are constant.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E19) True\u002FFalse: Changing Sigmoid activation to ReLu will help to get over the vanishing gradient issue? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EReLU can help in solving vanishing gradient problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) In CNN, having max pooling always decrease the parameters? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is not always true. If we have a max pooling layer of pooling size as 1, the parameters would remain the same.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E21) [True or False] BackPropogation cannot be applied when using pooling layers\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBackPropogation can be applied on pooling layers too.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E22) What value would be in place of question mark?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" The training loss\u002Fvalidation loss remains constant. What could be the possible reason?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Architecture is not defined correctly\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Data given to the model is noisy\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth architecture and data could be incorrect. Refer this article https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F07\u002Fdebugging-neural-network-with-tensorboard\u002F\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19164200\u002FImage1.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-36571 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19164200\u002FImage1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"341\" height=\"271\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19164200\u002FImage1.jpg 341w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F19164200\u002FImage1-300x238.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 341px) 100vw, 341px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EThe red curve above denotes training accuracy with respect to each epoch in a deep learning algorithm. Both the green and blue curves denote validation accuracy.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhich of these indicate overfitting?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Green Curve\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Blue Curve\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBlue curve shows overfitting, whereas green curve is generalized.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E26) Which of the following statement is true regrading dropout?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1: Dropout gives a way to approximate by combining many different architectures\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2: Dropout demands high learning rates\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3: Dropout can help preventing overfitting\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Both 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Both 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All 1, 2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EStatements 1 and 3 are correct, statement 2 is not always true. Even after applying dropout and with low learning rate, a neural network can learn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E27) Gated Recurrent units can help prevent vanishing gradient problem in RNN.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) True\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) False\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption A is correct. This is because it has implicit memory to remember past behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E28) Suppose you are using early stopping mechanism with patience as 2, at which point will the neural network model stop training?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ctable style=\"height: 182px;\" border=\"2\" width=\"621\"\u003E\r\n\u003Ctbody\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESr. No.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETraining Loss\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EValidation Loss\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E1\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E1.0\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E1.1\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E2\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E0.9\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E1.0\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E3\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E0.8\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E1.0\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E4\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E0.7\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E1.0\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctr\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"186\"\u003E5\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"205\"\u003E0.6\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003Ctd style=\"text-align: center;\" width=\"210\"\u003E1.1\u003C\u002Ftd\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftr\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftbody\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ftable\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 5\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAs we have set patience as 2, the network will automatically stop training after  epoch 4.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E29) [True or False] Sentiment analysis using Deep Learning is a many-to one prediction task\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption A is correct. This is because from a sequence of words, you have to predict whether the sentiment was positive or negative.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E30) What steps can we take to prevent overfitting in a Neural Network?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Data Augmentation\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Weight Sharing\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Early Stopping\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Dropout\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of the above mentioned methods can help in preventing overfitting problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions \u002F doubts please drop in your comments below. They are transparent, easy to understand, robust in …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EDecision Trees are one of the most respected algorithm in machine learning and data science. They are transparent, easy to understand, robust in nature and widely applicable. You can actually see what the algorithm is doing and what steps does it perform to get to a solution. This trait is particularly important in business context when it comes to explaining a decision to stakeholders.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skill test was specially designed for you to test your knowledge on decision tree techniques. More than 750 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-decision-trees\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F04\u002Fcomplete-tutorial-tree-based-modeling-scratch-in-python\u002F\"\u003EA Complete Tutorial on Tree Based Modeling from Scratch (in R &amp; Python)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fdetailed-solutions-for-skilltest-tree-based-algorithms\u002F\"\u003E45 questions to test Data Scientists on Tree Based Algorithms (Decision tree, Random Forests, XGBoost)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about bagging trees?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn bagging trees, individual trees are independent of each other\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EBagging is the method for improving the performance by aggregating the results of weak learners\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth options are true. In Bagging, each individual trees are independent of each other because they consider different subset of features and samples.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about boosting trees?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn boosting trees, individual weak learners are independent of each other\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is the method for improving the performance by aggregating the results of weak learners\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIn boosting tree individual weak learners are not independent of each other because each tree correct the results of previous tree. Bagging and boosting both can be consider as improving the base learners results.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E3) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about Random Forest and Gradient Boosting ensemble methods?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth methods can be used for classification task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest is use for classification whereas Gradient Boosting is use for regression task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest is use for regression whereas Gradient Boosting is use for Classification task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth methods can be used for regression task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) 1 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth algorithms are design for classification as well as regression task.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4) In Random forest you can generate hundreds of trees (say T1, T2 &#8230;..Tn) and then aggregate the results of these tree. Which of the following is true about individual(Tk) tree in Random Forest?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on a subset of the features\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on all the features\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on a subset of observations\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on full set of observations\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom forest is based on bagging concept, that consider faction of sample and faction of feature for building the individual trees.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E5) Which of the following is true about “max_depth” hyperparameter in Gradient Boosting?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELower is better parameter in case of same validation accuracy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EHigher is better parameter in case of same validation accuracy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the value of max_depth may overfit the data\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the value of max_depth may underfit the data\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the depth from the certain value of depth may overfit the data and for 2 depth values validation accuracies are same we always prefer the small depth in final model building.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) Which of the following algorithm doesn&#8217;t uses learning Rate as of one of its hyperparameter?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EGradient Boosting\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EExtra Trees\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EAdaBoost\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest and Extra Trees don&#8217;t have learning rate as a hyperparameter.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E7) Which of the following algorithm would you take into the consideration in your final model building on the basis of performance?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have given the following graph which shows the ROC curve for two different classification algorithms such as Random Forest(Red) and Logistic Regression(Blue)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F12181501\u002F7_image_dt.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F12181501\u002F7_image_dt-300x189.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 717px) 100vw, 717px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Random Forest\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Logistic Regression\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both of the above\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESince, Random forest has largest AUC given in the picture so I would prefer Random Forest\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) Which of the following is true about training and testing error in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you want to apply AdaBoost algorithm on Data D which has T observations. You set half the data for training and half for testing initially. Now you want to increase the number of data points for training T1, T2 &#8230; Tn where T1 &lt; T2&#8230;. Tn-1 &lt; Tn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The difference between training error and test error increases as number of observations increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The difference between training error and test error decreases as number of observations increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The difference between training error and test error will not change\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of These\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EAs we have more and more data, training error increases and testing error de-creases. And they all converge to the true error.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) In random forest or gradient boosting algorithms, features can be of any type. For example, it can be a continuous feature or a categorical feature. Which of the following option is true when you consider these types of features?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Only Random forest algorithm handles real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Only Gradient boosting algorithm handles real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both algorithms can handle real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth can handle real valued features.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Which of the following algorithm are not an example of ensemble learning algorithm?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Random Forest\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Adaboost\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Extra Trees\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Gradient Boosting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) Decision Trees\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EDecision trees doesn’t aggregate the results of multiple trees so it is not an ensemble algorithm.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E11) Suppose you are using a bagging based algorithm say a RandomForest in model building. Which of the following can be true?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ENumber of tree should be as large as possible\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EYou will have interpretability after using RandomForest\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESince Random Forest aggregate the result of different weak learners, If It is possible we would want more number of trees in model building.  Random Forest is a black box model you will lose interpretability after using it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EContext 12-15 \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EConsider the following figure for answering the next few questions. In the figure, X1 and X2 are the two features and the data point is represented by dots (-1 is negative class and +1 is a positive class). And you first split the data based on feature X1(say splitting point is x11) which is shown in the figure using vertical line. Every value less than x11 will be predicted as positive class and greater than x will be predicted as negative class.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp correctly?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Greater than x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Less than x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Equal to x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan accuracy.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) If you consider only feature X2 for splitting. Can you now perfectly separate the positive class from negative class for any one split on X2?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIt is also not possible.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Now consider only one splitting on both (one on X1 and one on X2) feature. You can split both features at any point. Would you be able to classify all data points correctly?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EYou won&#8217;t find such case because you can get minimum 1 misclassification.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EContext 16-17 \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose, you are working on a binary classification problem with 3 input features. And you chose to apply a bagging algorithm(X) on this data. You chose max_features = 2 and the n_estimators =3. Now, Think that each estimators have 70% accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: Algorithm X is aggregating the results of individual estimators based on maximum voting\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) What will be the maximum accuracy you can get?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 70%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 80%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 90%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 100%\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERefer below table for models M1, M2 and M3.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ctable
