Which of the following is true abut choosing the learning rate?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Learning rate should be as high as possible\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Learning Rate should be as low as possible\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Learning Rate should be low but it should not be very low\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Learning rate should be high but it should not be very high\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELearning rate should be low but it should not be very low otherwise algorithm will take so long to finish the training because you need to increase the number trees.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) [True or False] Cross validation can be used to select the number of iterations in boosting; this procedure may help reduce overfitting.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E26) When you use the boosting algorithm you always consider the weak learners. Which of the following is the main reason for having weak learners?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ETo prevent overfitting\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ETo prevent under fitting\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003ETo prevent overfitting, since the complexity of the overall learner increases at each step. Starting with weak learners implies the final classifier will be less likely to overfit.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E27) To apply bagging to regression trees which of the following is\u002Fare true in such case?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe build the N regression with N bootstrap sample\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe take the average the of N regression tree\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EEach tree has a high variance with low bias\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EAll of the options are correct and self explanatory\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E28) How to select best hyperparameters in tree based models?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Measure performance over training data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Measure performance over validation data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both of these\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: validation results to compare with the test result.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E29) In which of the following scenario a gain ratio is preferred over Information Gain?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) When a categorical variable has very large number of category\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) When a categorical variable has very small number of category\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Number of categories is the not the reason\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of Which of the following hyper parameter would you choose in such case?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ctable border=\"2\" This skill test is specially designed for you to test your knowledge on logistic regression and its nuances.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions. More than 800 people participated in the skill test and the highest score obtained was 27.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F11\u002Fbeginners-guide-on-logistic-regression-in-r\u002F\"\u003ESimple Guide to Logistic Regression in R\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F10\u002Fbasics-logistic-regression\u002F\"\u003EBuilding a Logistic Regression model from scratch\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1) True-False: Is Logistic regression a supervised machine learning algorithm?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E A\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ETrue, Logistic regression is a supervised learning algorithm because it uses true labels for training. Supervised learning algorithm should have input variables (x) and an target variable (Y) when you train the model .\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) True-False: Is Logistic regression mainly used for Regression?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELogistic regression is a classification algorithm, don&#8217;t confuse with the name regression.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) True-False: Is it possible to design a logistic regression algorithm using a Neural Network Algorithm?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ETrue, Neural network is a is a \u003Cem\u003Euniversal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E approximator so it can implement linear regression algorithm.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) True-False: Is it possible to apply a logistic regression algorithm on a 3-class Classification problem?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EYes, we can apply logistic regression on 3 classification problem, We can use One Vs all method for 3 class classification in logistic regression.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) Which of the following methods do we use to best fit the data in Logistic Regression?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Least Square Error\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Maximum Likelihood\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Jaccard distance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Both A and B\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELogistic regression uses maximum likely hood estimate for training a logistic regression.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) Which of the following evaluation metrics can not be applied in case of logistic regression output to compare with target?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) AUC-ROC\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Accuracy\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Logloss\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Mean-Squared-Error\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESince, Logistic Regression is a classification algorithm so it&#8217;s output can not be real time value so mean squared error can not use for evaluating it\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) One of the very good methods to analyze the performance of Logistic Regression is AIC, which is similar to R-Squared in Linear Regression. Which of the following is true about AIC?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We prefer a model with minimum AIC value\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We prefer a model with maximum AIC value\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both but depend on the situation\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EWe select the best model in logistic regression which can least AIC. For more information refer this source: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww4.ncsu.edu\u002F~shu3\u002FPresentation\u002FAIC.pdf\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"color: windowtext;text-decoration: none\"\u003Ehttp:\u002F\u002Fwww4.ncsu.edu\u002F~shu3\u002FPresentation\u002FAIC.pdf\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) [True-False] Standardisation of features is required before training a Logistic Regression.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EStandardization isn&#8217;t required for logistic regression. The main goal of standardizing features is to help convergence of the technique used for optimization.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) Which of the following algorithms do we use for Variable Selection?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) LASSO\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Ridge\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';color: #242729\"\u003EIn case of lasso we apply a absolute penality, after increasing the penality in lasso some of the coefficient of variables may become zero.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EContext: 10-11\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EConsider a following model for logistic regression: P (y =1|x, w)= g(w0 + w1x)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nwhere g(z) is the logistic function.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the above equation the P (y =1|x; w) , viewed as a function of x, that we can get by changing the parameters w.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) What would be the range of p in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) (0, inf)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) (-inf, 0 )\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) (0, 1)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) (-inf, inf)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor values of \u003Cem\u003Ex\u003C\u002Fem\u003E in the range of  real number from −∞ to +∞ Logistic function will give the output between (0,1)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) In above question what do you think which function would make p between (0,1)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) logistic function\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Log them\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EExplanation is same as question number 10\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EContext: class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EOption B would be the right answer. Since our line will be represented by y = g(-6+x2) which is shown in the option A and option B. But option B is the right answer because when you put the value x2 = 6 in the equation then y = g(0) you will get that means y= 0.5 will be on the line, if you increase the value of x2 greater then 6 you will get negative values so output will be the region y =0.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) If you replace coefficient of x1 with x2 what would be the output figure?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08174459\u002FQ16A.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"139\" height=\"83\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08174506\u002FQ16B.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"167\" height=\"107\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08174512\u002FQ16C.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"136\" height=\"96\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ED)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08174523\u002FQ16D.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"133\" height=\"96\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESame explanation as in previous question.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) Suppose you have been given a fair coin and you want to find out the odds of getting heads. Which of the following option is true for such a case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) odds will be 0\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) odds will be 0.5\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) odds will be 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EOdds are defined as the ratio of the probability of success and the probability of failure. So in case of fair coin probability of success is 1\u002F2 and the probability of failure is 1\u002F2 so odd would be 1\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) The logit function(given as l(x)) is the log of odds function. What could be the range of logit function in the domain x=[0,1]?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) (&#8211; ∞ , ∞)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) (0,1)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) (0, ∞)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) (- ∞, 0)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor our purposes, the odds function has the advantage of transforming the probability function, which has values from 0 to 1, into an equivalent function with values between 0 and ∞. When we take the natural log of the odds function, we get a range of values from -∞ to ∞\u003Cem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) Which of the following option is true?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Linear Regression errors values has to be normally distributed but in case of Logistic Regression it is not the case\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Logistic Regression errors values has to be normally distributed but in case of Linear Regression it is not the case\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both Linear Regression and Logistic Regression error values have to be normally distributed\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Both Linear Regression and Logistic Regression error values have not to be normally distributed\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution:A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EOnly A is true. Refer this tutorial \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fczep.net\u002Fstat\u002Fmlelr.pdf\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"color: windowtext;text-decoration: none\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fczep.net\u002Fstat\u002Fmlelr.pdf\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E17) Which of the following is true regarding the logistic function for any value &#8220;x&#8221;?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nLogistic(x): is a logistic function of any number &#8220;x&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ELogit(x): is a logit function of any number &#8220;x&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ELogit_inv(x): is a inverse logit function of any number &#8220;x&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Logistic(x) = Logit(x)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Logistic(x) = Logit_inv(x)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Logit_inv(x) = Logit(x)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERefer this link for the solution: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\u002Fwiki\u002FLogit\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\u002Fwiki\u002FLogit\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E18) How will the bias change on using high(infinite) regularisation?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have given the two scatter plot &#8220;a&#8221; and &#8220;b&#8221; for two classes( blue for positive and red for negative class). In scatter plot &#8220;a&#8221;, you correctly classified all data points using logistic regression ( black line is a decision boundary).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: center\"\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08175442\u002FQc22.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"491\" height=\"253\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Bias will be high\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Bias will be low\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EModel will become very simple so bias will be very high.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E19) Suppose, You applied a Logistic Regression model on a given data and got a training accuracy X and testing accuracy Y. Now, you want to add a few new features in the same data. Select the option(s) which is\u002Fare correct in such a case.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote: Consider remaining parameters are same.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Training accuracy increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Training accuracy increases or remains the same\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Testing accuracy decreases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Testing accuracy increases or remains the same\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A and D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAdding more features to model will increase the training accuracy because model has to consider more data to fit the logistic regression. But testing accuracy increases if feature is found to be significant\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) Choose which of the following options is true regarding One-Vs-All method in Logistic Regression.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We need to fit n models in n-class classification problem\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We need to fit n-1 models to classify into n classes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) We need to fit only 1 model to classify into n classes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf there are n classes, then n separate logistic regression has to fit, where the probability of each category is predicted over the rest of the categories combined.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E21) Below are two different logistic models with different values for β0 and β1.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08180221\u002FQ27.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"508\" height=\"342\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhich of the following statement(s) is true about β0 and β1 values of two logistics models (Green, Black)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENote: consider Y = β0 + β1*X. Here, β0 is intercept and β1 is coefficient.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) β1 for Green is greater than Black\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) β1 for Green is lower than Black\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) β1 for both models is same\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Can&#8217;t Say\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';color: #080e14\"\u003Eβ0 and β1: β0 = 0, β1 = 1 is in X1 color(black) and β0 = 0, β1 = −1 is in X4 color (green)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EContext 22-24\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow are the three scatter plot(A,B,C left to right) and hand drawn decision boundaries for logistic regression.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E22) Which of the following above figure shows that the decision boundary is overfitting the training data?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003EA) A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD)None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESince in figure 3, Decision boundary is not smooth that means it will over-fitting the data.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E23) What do you conclude after seeing this visualization?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe training error in first plot is maximum as compare to second and third plot.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe best model for this regression problem is the last (third) plot because it has minimum training error (zero).\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe second model is more robust than first and third because it will perform best on unseen data.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe third model is overfitting more as compare to first and second.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAll will perform same because we have not seen the testing data.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1, 3 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 5\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe trend in the graphs looks like a quadratic trend over independent variable X. A higher degree(Right graph) polynomial might have a very high accuracy on the train population but is expected to fail badly on test dataset. But if you see in left graph we will have training error maximum because it underfits the training data\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) Suppose, above decision boundaries were generated for the different value of regularization. Which of the above decision boundary shows the maximum regularization?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All have equal regularization\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESince, more regularization means more penality means less complex decision boundry that shows in first figure A.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: left\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E25) The below figure shows AUC-ROC curves for three logistic regression models. Different colors show curves for different hyper parameters values. Which of the following AUC-ROC will give best result?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F23105505\u002FQ321.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"440\" height=\"409\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Yellow\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Pink\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Black\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All are same\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EThe best classification is the largest area under the curve so yellow line has largest area under the curve.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E26) What would do if you want to train logistic regression on same data that will take less time as well as give the comparatively similar accuracy(may not be same)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are using a Logistic Regression model on a huge dataset. One of the problem you may face on such huge data is that Logistic regression will take very long time to train.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Decrease the learning rate and decrease the number of iteration\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Decrease the learning rate and increase the number of iteration\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Increase the learning rate and increase the number of iteration\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Increase the learning rate and decrease the number of iteration\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIf you decrease the number of iteration while training it will take less time for surly but will not give the same accuracy for getting the similar accuracy but not exact you need to increase the learning rate.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E27) Which of the following image is showing the cost function for y =1.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFollowing is the loss function in logistic regression(Y-axis loss function and x axis log probability) for two class classification problem.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote: Y is the target class\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: center\"\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F23110450\u002FQ36_image11.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"499\" height=\"170\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EA is the true answer as loss function decreases as the log probability increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E28) Suppose, Following graph is a cost function for logistic regression.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F23120501\u002FQ371.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"523\" height=\"323\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003ENow, How many local minimas are present in the graph?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EThere are three local minima present in the graph\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E29) Imagine, you have given the below graph of logistic regression  which is shows the relationships between cost function and number of iteration for 3 different learning rate values (different colors are showing different curves at different learning rates ). \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F23113750\u002FQ391.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"494\" height=\"364\" \u002F\u003ESuppose, you save the graph for future reference but you forgot to save the value of different learning rates for this graph. Now, you want to find out the relation between the leaning rate values of these curve. Which of the following will be the true relation?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENote:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe learning rate for blue is l1\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe learning rate for red is l2\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe learning rate for green is l3\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) l1&gt;l2&gt;l3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) l1 = l2 = l3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) l1 &lt; l2 &lt; l3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ED) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you have low learning rate means your cost function will decrease slowly but in case of large learning rate cost function will decrease very fast.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E30) Can a Logistic Regression classifier do a perfect classification on the below data?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F06\u002F08165515\u002FQ40.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"202\" height=\"171\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: You can use only X1 and X2 variables where X1 and X2 can take only two binary values(0,1).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ENo, logistic regression only forms linear decision surface, but the examples in the figure are not linearly separable.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.cs.cmu.edu\u002F~tom\u002F10701_sp11\u002Fmidterm_sol.pdf\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions \u002F doubts please drop in your comments below. One such example of unstructured data is an image, and analysis of image data has applications in various aspects of business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skilltest is specially designed for you to test your knowledge on the knowledge on how to handle image data, with an emphasis on image processing. More than 300 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fimage-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F\"\u003EEssentials of Machine Learning Algorithms (with Python and R Codes)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2014\u002F12\u002Fimage-processing-python-basics\u002F\"\u003EBasics of Image Processing in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1) Match the following image formats to their correct number of channels\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EGrayScale\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ERGB\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Col style=\"list-style-type: upper-roman;\"\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E 1 channel\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E2 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E3 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E4 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENone\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) RGB -&gt; I, GrayScale-&gt; III\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) RGB -&gt; IV, GrayScale-&gt; II\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) RGB -&gt; III, GrayScale -&gt; I\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) RGB -&gt; II, GrayScale -&gt; I\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EGrayscale images have one number per pixel, and are stored as an m × n matrix, whereas Color images  have 3 numbers per pixel – red, green, and blue brightness (RGB)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have to rotate an image. Image rotation is nothing but multiplication of image by a specific matrix to get a new transformed image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31104149\u002FImage_Cont.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-38411 point in the image to rotate with co-ordinates as (1, 0) to a co-ordinate of (0, 1), which of the following matrix would we have to multiply with?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31104325\u002FImage1A.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38412 \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31104417\u002FImage2.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone size-full like this;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n[[0], [1]] = [[0, -1], [1, 0]] x [1, 0]\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) [True or False] To blur an image, you can use a linear filter\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBlurring compares neighboring pixels in a filter and smooth them. For this, you cannot use a linear filter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) Which of the following is a challenge when dealing with computer vision problems?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Variations due to geometric changes (like pose, scale etc)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Variations due to photometric factors (like illumination, appearance etc)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Image occlusion\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the above mentioned options are challenges in computer vision\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose we have an image given below.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" A simple way to do this is to represent the image in terms of the intensity of pixels and the cluster them according to the values. On doing this, we got this type of structure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38417 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"440\" height=\"268\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg 440w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b-300x183.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 440px) 100vw, 440px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003ESuppose we choose k-means clustering to solve the problem, what would be the appropriate value of k from just a visual inspection of the intensity graph?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThree clusters will be formed; points in the circle, points in the square and the points excluding both of these objects\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-38418 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"277\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg 277w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6-217x300.jpg 217w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 277px) 100vw, 277px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIn this image, you can find an edge labelled in the red region. Which form of discontinuity creates this kind of edge?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Depth Discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Surface color Discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Illumination discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe chair and wall are far from each other, causing an edge in the image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) Finite difference filters in image processing are very susceptible to noise. To cope up with this, which of the following methods can you use so that there would be minimal distortions by noise?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Downsample the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Convert the image to grayscale from RGB\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Smooth the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESmoothing helps in reducing noise by forcing pixels to be more like their neighbours\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) Consider and image with width and height as 100&#215;100. Each pixel in the image can have a color from Grayscale, i.e. values. How much space would this image require for storing?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: No compression is done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 2,56,00,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 25,60,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2,56,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 8,00,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) 80,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nF) 8,000\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe answer will be 8x100x100 because 8 bits will be required to represent a number from 0-256\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) [True or False] Quantizing an image will reduce the amount of memory required for storage.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe statement given is true.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Suppose we have a grayscale image, with most of the values of pixels being same. What can we use to compress the size of image?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Encode the pixels with same values in a dictionary\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Encode the sequence of values of pixels\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) No compression can be done\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EEncoding same values of pixels will greatly reduce the size for storage\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) [True or False] JPEG is a lossy image compression technique\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe reason for JPEG being a lossy compression technique is because of the use of quantization.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E12) Given an image with only 2 pixels and 3 possible values for each pixel, what is the number of possible image histograms that can be formed?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 9\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 12\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe permutations possible of the histograms would be 9.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) Suppose we have a 1D image with values as\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n[2, 5, 8, 5, 2]\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we apply average filter on this image of size 3. What would be the value of the last second pixel?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The value would remain the same\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The value would increase by 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The value would decrease by 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E(8+5+2)\u002F3 will become 5. So there will be no change.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) fMRI (Functional magnetic resonance imaging) is a technology where volumetric scans of the brain are acquired while the subject is performing some cognitive tasks over time. What is the dimensionality of fMRI output signals?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe question itself mentions “volumetric scans” over time, so it would be a series of 3D scans\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Which of the following methods is used as a model fitting method for edge detection?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) SIFT\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Difference of Gaussian detector\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) RANSAC\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERANSAC is used to find the best fit line in edge detection\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E16)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose we have an image which is noisy. \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) The image will be shifted to the right by 1 pixel\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The image will be shifted down by 1 result!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E18) Which of the following is a correct way to sharpen an image?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EConvolve the image with identity matrix\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESubtract this resulting image from the original\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this subtracted result back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EB)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESmooth the image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESubtract this smoothed image from the original\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this subtracted result back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EC)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESmooth the image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this smoothed image back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ED) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption B gives a correct way to sharpen an image\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E19) Below given images are two operations performed on a signal. Can you identify which is which?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38422 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"167\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg 167w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19-147x300.jpg 147w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 167px) 100vw, 167px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Operation 1 is cross correlation between signal f and signal g, whereas operation 2 is convolution function applied to signal f and signal g\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Operation 2 is cross correlation between signal f and signal g, whereas operation 1 is convolution function applied to signal f and signal g\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ECorrelation and convolution are two different methods with give different result. Convolution defines how much the signals overlap, whereas correlation tries to find the relation between the signals\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) [True or False] By using template matching along with cross correlation, you can build a vision system for TV remote control\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is a excellent example of cross correlation in computer vision. Refer paper “Computer Vision for Interactive Computer Graphics,” W.Freeman et al, IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E21) Suppose you are creating a face detector in the wild. Which of the following features would you select for creating a robust facial detector?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Location of iris, eyebrow and chin\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Boolean feature: Is the person smiling or not\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. Angle of orientation of face\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n4. Is the person sitting or standing\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1, 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1, 2, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 1, 2, 3, 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOptions 1, 3 would be relevant features for the problem, but 2, 4 may not be\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E22) Which of the following is example of low level feature in an image?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) HOG\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) SIFT\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) HAAR features\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the above are examples of low-level features\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) In RGBA mode of color representation, what does A represent?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Depth of an image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Intensity of colors\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Opacity of an image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOpacity can be mentioned by introducing it as a fourth parameter in RGB\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) In Otsu thresholding technique, you remove the noise by thresholding the points which are irrelevant and keeping those which do not represent noise.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38424 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"631\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg 631w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24-300x224.jpg 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24-83x63.jpg 83w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 631px) 100vw, 631px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIn the image given, at which point would you threshold on?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) D\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ELine B would catch most of the noise in the image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E25) Which of the following data augmentation technique would you prefer for an object recognition problem?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E`\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Horizontal flipping\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Rescaling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Zooming in the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the mentioned techniques can be used for data augmentation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow is the distribution of the scores of the participants:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-39080 size-full\"
