You have various tools, but you ought …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can think of machine learning algorithms as an armory packed with axes, sword and blades. You have various tools, but you ought to learn to use them at the right time. As an analogy, think of ‘Regression’ as a sword capable of slicing and dicing data efficiently, but incapable of dealing with highly complex data. On the contrary, ‘Support Vector Machines’ is like a sharp knife – it works on smaller datasets, but on them, it can be much more stronger and powerful in building models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skilltest was specially designed for you to test your knowledge on SVM techniques and its applications. More than 550 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fsvm-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F\"\u003EEssentials of Machine Learning Algorithms (with Python and R Codes)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Funderstaing-support-vector-machine-example-code\u002F\"\u003EUnderstanding Support Vector Machine algorithm from examples (along with code)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 1 &#8211; 2\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are using a Linear SVM classifier with 2 class classification problem. Now you have been given the following data in which some points are circled red that are representing support vectors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38435 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"404\" height=\"250\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png 404w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19-300x186.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 404px) 100vw, 404px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1) If you remove the following any one red points from the data. Does the decision boundary will change?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThese three examples are positioned such that removing any one of them introduces slack in the constraints. So the decision boundary would completely change.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) [True or False] If you remove the non-red circled points from the data, the decision boundary will change?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) True\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) False\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOn the other hand, rest of the points in the data won&#8217;t affect the decision boundary much.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) What do you mean by generalization error in terms of the SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) How far the hyperplane is from the support vectors\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) How accurately the SVM can predict outcomes for unseen data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The threshold amount of error in an SVM\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EGeneralisation error in statistics is generally the out-of-sample error which is the measure of how accurately a model can predict values for previously unseen data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) When the C parameter is set to infinite, which of the following holds true?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The optimal hyperplane if exists, will be the one that completely separates the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The soft-margin classifier will separate the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAt such a high level of misclassification penalty, soft margin will not hold existence as there will be no room for error.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) What do you mean by a hard margin?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The SVM allows very low error in classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The SVM allows high amount of error in classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA hard margin means that an SVM is very rigid in classification and tries to work extremely well in the training set, causing overfitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) The minimum time complexity for training an SVM is O(n2). According to this fact, what sizes of datasets are not best suited for SVM&#8217;s?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Large datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Small datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Medium sized datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Size does not matter\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EDatasets which have a clear classification boundary will function best with SVM’s.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) The effectiveness of an SVM depends upon:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Selection of Kernel\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Kernel Parameters\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Soft Margin Parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe SVM effectiveness depends upon how you choose the basic 3 requirements mentioned above in such a way that it maximises your efficiency, reduces error and overfitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) Support vectors are the data points that lie closest to the decision surface.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThey are the points closest to the hyperplane and the hardest ones to classify. They also have a direct bearing on the location of the decision surface.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) The SVM&#8217;s are less effective when:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The data is linearly separable\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The data is clean and ready to use\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The data is noisy and contains overlapping points\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen the data has noise and overlapping points, there is a problem in drawing a clear hyperplane without misclassifying.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Suppose you are using RBF kernel in SVM with high Gamma value. What does this signify?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The model would consider even far away points from hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The model would consider only the points close to the hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The model would not be affected by distance of points from hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe gamma parameter in SVM tuning signifies the influence of points either near or far away from the hyperplane.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a low gamma, the model will be too constrained and include all points of the training dataset, without really capturing the shape.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a higher gamma, the model will capture the shape of the dataset well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) The cost parameter in the SVM means:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The number of cross-validations to be made\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The kernel to be used\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The tradeoff between misclassification and simplicity of the model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe cost parameter decides how much an SVM should be allowed to “bend” with the data. For a low cost, you aim for a smooth decision surface and for a higher cost, you aim to classify more points correctly. It is also simply referred to as the cost of misclassification.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E12)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are building a SVM model on data X. The data X can be error prone which means that you should not trust any specific data point too much. Now think that you want to build a SVM model which has quadratic kernel function of polynomial degree 2 that uses Slack variable C as one of it&#8217;s hyper parameter. Based upon that give the answer for following question.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat would happen when you use very large value of C(C-&gt;infinity)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote: For small C was also classifying all data points correctly\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We can still classify data correctly for given setting of hyper parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We can not classify data correctly for given setting of hyper parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t Say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor large values of C, the penalty for misclassifying points is very high, so the decision boundary will perfectly separate the data if possible.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) What would happen when you use very small C (C~0)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Misclassification would happen\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Data will be correctly classified\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe classifier can maximize the margin between most of the points, while misclassifying a few points, because the penalty is so low.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) If I am using all features of my dataset and I achieve 100% accuracy on my training set, but ~70% on validation set, what should I look out for?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Underfitting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Nothing, the model is perfect\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Overfitting\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we’re achieving 100% training accuracy very easily, we need to check to verify if we’re overfitting our data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Which of the following are real world applications of the SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Text and Hypertext Categorization\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Image Classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Clustering of News Articles\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESVM’s are highly versatile models that can be used for practically all real world problems ranging from regression to clustering and handwriting recognitions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 16 &#8211; 18\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have trained an SVM with linear decision boundary after training SVM, you correctly infer that your SVM model is under fitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) Which of the following option would you more likely to consider iterating SVM next time?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003EA) You want to increase your data points\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) You want to decrease your data points\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) You will try to calculate more variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) You will try to reduce the features\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe best option here would be to create more features for the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E17) Suppose you gave the correct answer in previous question. What do you think that is actually happening?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. We are lowering the bias\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. We are lowering the variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. We are increasing the bias\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n4. We are increasing the variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBetter model will lower the bias and increase the variance\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E18) In above question suppose you want to change one of it&#8217;s(SVM) hyperparameter so that effect would be same as previous questions i.e model will not under fit?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We will increase the parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We will decrease the parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Changing in C don&#8217;t effect\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIncreasing C parameter would be the right thing to do here, as it will ensure regularized model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E19) We usually use feature normalization before using the Gaussian kernel in SVM. What is true about feature normalization?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. We do feature normalization so that new feature will dominate other\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Some times, feature normalization is not feasible in case of categorical variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. Feature normalization always helps when we use Gaussian kernel in SVM\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EStatements one and two are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 20-22\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are dealing with 4 class classification problem and you want to train a SVM model on the data for that you are using One-vs-all method. Now answer the below questions?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) How many times we need to train our SVM model in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a 4 class problem, you would have to train the SVM at least 4 times if you are using a one-vs-all method.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E21) Suppose you have same distribution of classes in the data. Now, say for training 1 time in one vs all setting the SVM is taking 10 second. How many seconds would it require to train one-vs-all method end to end?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 20\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 40\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 60\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 80\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIt would take 10&#215;4 = 40 seconds\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E22) Suppose your problem has changed now. Now, data has only 2 classes. What would you think how many times we need to train SVM in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ETraining the SVM only one time would give you appropriate results\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion context: 23 &#8211; 24\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are using SVM with linear kernel of polynomial degree 2, Now think that you have applied this on data and found that it perfectly fit the data that means, Training and testing accuracy is 100%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) Now, think that you increase the complexity(or degree of polynomial of this kernel). What would you think will happen?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Increasing the complexity will overfit the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Increasing the complexity will underfit the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Nothing will happen since your model was already 100% accurate\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIncreasing the complexity of the data would make the algorithm overfit the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) In the previous question after increasing the complexity you found that training accuracy was still 100%. According to you what is the reason behind that?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Since data is fixed and we are fitting more polynomial term or parameters so the algorithm starts memorizing everything in the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Since data is fixed and SVM doesn&#8217;t need to search in big hypothesis space\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the given statements are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) What is\u002Fare true about kernel in SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Kernel function map low dimensional data to high dimensional space\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. It&#8217;s a similarity function\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the given statements are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow is the distribution of the scores of the participants:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E \u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-39075 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"481\" height=\"290\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm.png 481w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm-300x181.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 481px) 100vw, 481px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can access the scores \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fsvm-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. More than 350 people participated in the skill test and the highest score obtained was a 25.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions \u002F doubts please drop in your comments below. I would love to hear your feedback about the skill test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener I'm fascinated by this topic. Can a machine write as well as Shakespeare? …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe are standing at the intersection of language and machines. I&#8217;m fascinated by this topic. Can a machine write as well as Shakespeare? What if a machine could improve my own writing skills? Could a robot interpret a sarcastic remark?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI&#8217;m sure you&#8217;ve asked these questions before. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fnatural-language-processing-nlp?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ENatural Language Processing (NLP)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E also aims to answer these questions, and I must say, there has been groundbreaking research done in this field towards bridging the gap between humans and machines.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-63997\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3.jpg\" alt=\"pretrained models text classification\" width=\"1050\" height=\"520\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3.jpg 1050w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-300x149.jpg 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-768x380.jpg 768w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-850x421.jpg 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1050px) 100vw, 1050px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne of the core ideas in NLP is \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fa-comprehensive-guide-to-understand-and-implement-text-classification-in-python\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Etext classification\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. If a machine can differentiate between a noun and a verb, or if it can detect a customer&#8217;s satisfaction with the product in his\u002Fher review, we can use this understanding for other advanced \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002FIntro-to-NLP?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ENLP\u003C\u002Fa\u003E tasks like understanding context or even generating a brand new story!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat&#8217;s primarily the reason we&#8217;ve seen a lot of research in text classification. And yes, the advent of \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F06\u002Ftransfer-learning-the-art-of-fine-tuning-a-pre-trained-model\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Etransfer learning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has definitely helped accelerate the research. We are now able to use a pre-existing model built on a huge dataset and tune it to achieve other tasks on a different dataset.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETransfer learning, and pretrained models, have 2 major advantages:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt has reduced the cost of training a new deep learning model every time\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThese datasets meet industry-accepted standards, and thus the pretrained models have already been vetted on the quality aspect\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can see why there&#8217;s been a surge in the popularity of pretrained models. We&#8217;ve seen the likes of \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F09\u002Fdemystifying-bert-groundbreaking-nlp-framework\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGoogle&#8217;s BERT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F07\u002Fopenai-gpt2-text-generator-python\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EOpenAI&#8217;s GPT-2\u003C\u002Fa\u003E really take the bull by the horns. I&#8217;ll cover 6 state-of-the-art text classification pretrained models in this article.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EI assume that you are aware of what text classification is. Here&#8217;s a comprehensive tutorial to get you up to date:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fa-comprehensive-guide-to-understand-and-implement-text-classification-in-python\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EA Comprehensive Guide to Understand and Implement Text Classification in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EThe Pretrained Models for Text Classification we&#8217;ll cover:\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EXLNet\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EERNIE\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EText-to-Text Transfer Transformer (T5)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EBinary Partitioning Transfomer (BPT)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENeural Attentive Bag-of-Entities (NABoE)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ERethinking Complex Neural Network Architectures\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #1: XLNet\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe can&#8217;t review state-of-the-art pretrained models without mentioning XLNet!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGoogle’s latest model, XLNet achieved State-of-the-Art (SOTA) performance on the major NLP tasks such as \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fa-comprehensive-guide-to-understand-and-implement-text-classification-in-python\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EText Classification\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F07\u002Fhands-on-sentiment-analysis-dataset-python\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ESentiment Analysis\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Question Answering, and Natural Language Inference along with the essential GLUE benchmark for English. It outperformed \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F09\u002Fdemystifying-bert-groundbreaking-nlp-framework\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EBERT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and has now cemented itself as the model to beat for not only text classification, but also advanced NLP tasks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe core ideas behind XLNet are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGeneralized Autoregressive Pretraining for Language Understanding\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe Transformer-XL\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Arch.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63911 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Arch.png\" alt=\"XLNet\" width=\"838\" height=\"401\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Arch.png 838w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Arch-300x144.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Arch-768x368.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 838px) 100vw, 838px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf this sounds complicated, don&#8217;t worry! I&#8217;ll break this down into simple words.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAutoregressive modeling is used to predict the next word using the context words occurring either before or after the missing word in question. However, we can’t process both the forward and backward directions at the same time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThough BERT’s autoencoder did take care of this aspect, it did have other disadvantages like assuming no correlation between the masked words. To combat this, XLNet proposes a technique called \u003Cstrong\u003EPermutation Language Modeling\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E during the pre-training phase. \u003Cem\u003EThis technique uses permutations to generate information from both the forward and backward directions simultaneously.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt is no secret that the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F06\u002Funderstanding-transformers-nlp-state-of-the-art-models\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ETransformer architecture\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has been a game-changer. XLNet uses Transformer XL. As we know, transformers were an alternative to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F12\u002Fintroduction-to-recurrent-neural-networks\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Erecurrent neural networks (RNN)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in the sense that they allowed non-adjacent tokens to be processed together as well. This improved understanding of long-distance relations in text. Transformer-XL is basically an enhanced version of the transformer used in BERT by adding two components:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EA recurrence at specific segments which gives the context between 2 sequences\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EA relative positional embedding which contains information on the similarity between 2 tokens\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs I mentioned previously, XLNet outperformed BERT on almost all tasks, including Text Classification and achieves SOTA performance on 18 of them!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is a summary of the Text Classification tasks and how XLNet performs on these different datasets and the high rank it has achieved on them:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Perf.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63913\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Perf.png\" alt=\"XLNet,text_classification\" width=\"693\" height=\"406\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Perf.png 777w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Perf-300x176.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FXLNet_Perf-768x450.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 693px) 100vw, 693px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the Paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fpdf\u002F1906.08237v2.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EXLNet: Generalized Autoregressive Pretraining for Language Understanding\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fzihangdai\u002Fxlnet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fzihangdai\u002Fxlnet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #2: ERNIE\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThough ERNIE 1.0 (released in March 2019) has been a popular model for text classification, it was ERNIE 2.0 which became the talk of the town in the latter half of 2019. Developed by tech-giant Baidu, ERNIE outperformed Google XLNet and BERT on the GLUE benchmark for English.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EERNIE stands for Enhanced Representation through kNowledge IntEgration\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, and ERNIE 2.0 is an upgraded version of ERNIE 1.0. ERNIE 1.0 was pathbreaking in its own way – it was one of the first models to leverage \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F10\u002Fhow-to-build-knowledge-graph-text-using-spacy\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EKnowledge Graphs\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. This incorporation further enhanced training the model for advanced tasks like Relation Classification and NamedEntityRecognition (NER).\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FERNIE_2.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63908 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FERNIE_2.png\" alt=\"ernie, text_classification\" width=\"801\" height=\"375\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FERNIE_2.png 801w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FERNIE_2-300x140.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FERNIE_2-768x360.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 801px) 100vw, 801px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELike its predecessor, \u003Cstrong\u003EERNIE 2.0 brings another innovation to the table in the form of Continual Incremental Multi-task Learning\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. Basically, this means that the model has defined 7 clear tasks, and\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003Ecan generate the output of more than 1 task at the same time. For example, completing the sentence “I like going to New &#8230;” -&gt; “I like going to New York”, and also classify the sentence as having a positive sentiment. The loss is also calculated accordingly for the combined tasks\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003Euses the output of previous tasks for the next task incrementally. For example, the output of Task 1 is used as training for Task 1, Task 2; output for this, Task 1 and Task 2 is used for training Tasks 1, 2 and 3,&#8230; and so on\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI really like how intuitive this process is since it follows a human way of understanding text. Our brain does not only think of “I like going to New York” as a positive sentence, does it? It simultaneously understands the nouns &#8220;New York&#8221;, and I; understand the verb &#8220;like&#8221;, and infers that New York is a place.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EERNIE achieves a SOTA \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F08\u002F11-important-model-evaluation-error-metrics\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EF1-Score\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of 88.32 on the Relation Extraction Task.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the Paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fpdf\u002F1905.07129v3.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EERNIE: Enhanced Language Representation with Informative Entities\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fthunlp\u002FERNIE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fthunlp\u002FERNIE\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #3: Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer (T5)\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI&#8217;ll be honest &#8211; I had the most fun studying this model as compared to the others. Google’s new Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer (T5) model uses \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F06\u002Ftransfer-learning-the-art-of-fine-tuning-a-pre-trained-model\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Etransfer learning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for a variety of NLP tasks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe most interesting part is that it converts every problem to a text input – a text output model. So, even for a classification task, the input will be text, and the output will again be a word instead of a label. This boils down to a single model on all tasks. Not only this, the output for one task can be used as input for the next task.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63910 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5.png\" alt=\"T5,transformers, text_classification\" width=\"803\" height=\"330\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5.png 803w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5-300x123.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5-768x316.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 803px) 100vw, 803px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe corpus uses an enhanced version of Common Crawls. This is basically scraped text from the web. The paper actually highlights the importance of cleaning the data, and clearly elucidates how this was done. Though the scraped data generates data of 20TB per month, most of this data is not suitable for NLP tasks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEven after retaining only text content (pages containing markups, code content, etc have been removed), the corpus still has a size of a whopping 750GB which is much larger than most datasets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENote: This has been released on TensorFlow too: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tensorflow.org\u002Fdatasets\u002Fcatalog\u002Fc4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ec4\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe task which is to be performed is encoded as a prefix along with the input. As you can see in the diagram above, be it a classification or a regression task, the T5 model still generates new text to get the output.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe T5 achieves SOTA on more than 20 established NLP tasks – this is rare, and taking a look at the metrics, it is as close to a human output as possible.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5_perf.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63970\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5_perf.png\" alt=\"T5, transformer\" width=\"555\" height=\"302\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5_perf.png 766w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FT5_perf-300x163.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 555px) 100vw, 555px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe T5 model follows up on the recent trend of training on unlabelled data and then fine-tuning this model on the labeled text. Understandably, this model is huge, but it would be interesting to see further research on scaling down such models for wider usage and distribution.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the Paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fpdf\u002F1910.10683.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EExploring the Limits of Transfer Learning with a Unified Text-to-Text Transformer\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fgoogle-research\u002Ftext-to-text-transfer-transformer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fgoogle-research\u002Ftext-to-text-transfer-transformer\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #4: Binary-Partitioning Transformer (BPT)\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs we have seen so far, the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F06\u002Funderstanding-transformers-nlp-state-of-the-art-models\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ETransformer architecture\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is quite popular in NLP research. The BP Transformer again uses the transformer, or rather an enhanced version of it for text classification, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F01\u002Fneural-machine-translation-keras\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Emachine translation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, etc.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, using a transformer is still a costly process since it uses the self-attention mechanism. Self-attention just means that we are performing the attention operation on the sentence itself, as opposed to 2 different sentences (this is attention). Self-attention helps identify the relationship between the words in a single sentence. It is this self-attention mechanism that contributes to the cost of using a transformer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63906 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT.png\" alt=\"Bipartitioning, transformer\" width=\"698\" height=\"280\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT.png 698w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT-300x120.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 698px) 100vw, 698px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Binary-Partitioning Transformer (BPT) aims to improve the efficiency of the self-attention mechanism by treating the transformer as a graph neural network. Essentially, each node in this graph represents an input token.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is how the BP Transformer works:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStep 1:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Divide the sentence into 2 parts recursively until some stopping condition is reached. This is called a binary partitioning. So, for example, the sentence &#8220;I like going to New York&#8221; will have the following partitions:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EI like going; to New York\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EI like; going; to New; York\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EI; like; going; to; New; York\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENote: A sentence with n words will have 2*n – 1 partitions, and in the end, you have a complete binary tree.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStep 2:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Each partition is now a node in the Graph Neural Network. There can be 2 types of edges:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe edge connecting a parent node to its children\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe edge connecting the leaf nodes with other nodes\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStep 3:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Perform self-attention on each node of the graph with its neighboring nodes:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT_2.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63907 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT_2.png\" alt=\"Binary_partitioning, transformers\" width=\"792\" height=\"273\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT_2.png 792w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT_2-300x103.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBPT_2-768x265.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 792px) 100vw, 792px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe BPT achieves:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESOTA performance on Chinese to English Machine Translation (BLEU score: 19.84)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAccuracy of 92.12 for Sentiment Analysis on the IMDb dataset (combined with \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fpretrained-word-embeddings-nlp\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGloVE embedding\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI appreciate this model in the sense that it made me revisit the concept of graphs and made me venture into looking up graph neural networks. I am admittedly late to the party, but I will surely be exploring more on Graph Neural networks in the near future!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the Paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fpdf\u002F1911.04070v1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EBP-Transformer: Modelling Long-Range Context via Binary Partitioning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fyzh119\u002FBPT\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fyzh119\u002FBPT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #5: Neural Attentive Bag-of-Entities Model for Text Classification (NABoE)\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002FIntroduction-to-Neural-Networks?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ENeural networks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have always been the most popular models for NLP tasks and they outperform the more traditional models. Additionally, replacing entities with words while building the knowledge base from the corpus has improved model learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis means that instead of building vocabulary from the words in a corpus, we build a bag of entities using Entity Linking. Though there has been research on this method of representing the corpus to the model, the NABoE model goes a step further by:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUsing a Neural network to detect the entities\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUsing the attention mechanism to compute the weights on the detected entities (this decides the relevance of the entities for the document in question)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63909\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE.png\" alt=\"Bag_Entitities, text_classification\" width=\"459\" height=\"394\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE.png 703w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE-300x257.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 459px) 100vw, 459px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Neural Attentive Bag of Entities model uses the Wikipedia corpus to detect the associated entities with a word. For example, the word “Apple” can refer to the fruit, the company, and other possible entities. Once all these entities are retrieved, the weight of each entity is calculated using the softmax-based attention function. This gives a smaller subset of entities which are relevant only to that particular document.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the end, the final representation of the word is given by its vectorized embedding combined with the vectorized embedding of the relevant entities associated with the word.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe NABoE model performs particularly well on Text Classification tasks:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE_perf.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63971\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE_perf.png\" alt=\"NABoE, text_classification\" width=\"609\" height=\"141\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE_perf.png 752w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FNABoE_perf-300x69.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 609px) 100vw, 609px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the Paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fpdf\u002F1909.01259.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ENeural Attentive Bag-of-Entities Model for Text Classification\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fwikipedia2vec\u002Fwikipedia2vec\u002Ftree\u002Fmaster\u002Fexamples\u002Ftext_classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fwikipedia2vec\u002Fwikipedia2vec\u002Ftree\u002Fmaster\u002Fexamples\u002Ftext_classification\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPretrained Model #6: Rethinking Complex Neural Network Architectures for Document Classification\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, it might appear counter-intuitive to study all these advanced pretrained models and at the end, discuss a model that uses plain (relatively) old \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F12\u002Ffundamentals-of-deep-learning-introduction-to-lstm\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EBidirectional LSTM\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to achieve SOTA performance. But that was precisely why I decided to introduce it at the end.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOftentimes, we miss the forest for the trees. We tend to forget that a simple well-tuned model might achieve just as good results as these complex deep learning models. This paper aims to explain just that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA combination of Bidirectional LSTM and Regularization is able to achieve SOTA performance on the IMDb document classification task and stands shoulder-to-shoulder with other bigwigs in this domain.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBiLSTM.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63905\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBiLSTM.png\" alt=\"BiLSTM, text_classification\" width=\"359\" height=\"269\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBiLSTM.png 602w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBiLSTM-300x225.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FBiLSTM-83x63.png 83w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 359px) 100vw, 359px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe most intriguing and noteworthy aspects of this paper are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt does not use the attention mechanism\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is the first paper to use a combination of LSTM + regularization for document classification\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis minimalistic model uses Adam optimizer, temporal averaging and dropouts to achieve this high score. The paper empirically compares these results with other deep learning models and demonstrates how this model is simple but effective and the results speak for themselves:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FLSTM_perf.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63972\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FLSTM_perf.png\" alt=\"LSTM_regularisation, text_classification\" width=\"642\" height=\"233\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FLSTM_perf.png 758w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FLSTM_perf-300x109.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 642px) 100vw, 642px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis kind of model can be considered a novel approach for the industry where it is important to build production-ready models and yet achieve high scores on your metrics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELink to the paper: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.aclweb.org\u002Fanthology\u002FN19-1408.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ERethinking Complex Neural Network Architectures for Document Classification\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGithub Link: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fcastorini\u002Fhedwig\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fcastorini\u002Fhedwig\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, we discussed the top 6 pretrained models that achieved state-of-the-art benchmarks in text classification recently. These NLP models show that there are many more ones yet to come and I will be looking forward to learning about them this year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe one awesome element in all this research is the availability and open source nature of these pretrained models. All the above models have a GitHub repository to them and are available for implementation. Another aspect that cannot be ignored is that they are available on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-pytorch-for-deeplearning?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=6-pretrained-models-text-classification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPyTorch\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as well. This emphasizes that PyTorch is fast replacing TensorFlow as THE platform to build your deep learning models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI encourage you to try out these models on various datasets and experiment with them to understand how they work. If you have some models in mind which were just as cool but went under the radar last year, do mention them in the comments below!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image_url":{"full":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3.jpg","large":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-850x421.jpg","medium":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-360x206.jpg","small":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-262x141.jpg","nano":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Ffeatured_image-3-100x72.jpg"},"categories":[{"id":"7c7d26c8-865f-4567-9bb5-171cd056339a","title":"Unstructured
