Here are 5 Things you Should Absolutely Know","sub_title":"","description":"Starting your Deep Learning Career? Deep learning can be a complex and daunting field for newcomers. Concepts like hidden layers, convolutional neural networks, backpropagation …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EStarting your Deep Learning Career?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDeep learning can be a complex and daunting field for newcomers. Concepts like hidden layers, convolutional neural networks, backpropagation keep coming up as you try to grasp deep learning topics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s not easy &#8211; especially if you take an unstructured learning path and don&#8217;t cover your basic fundamental concepts first. You&#8217;ll be stumbling around a foreign city like a tourist without a map!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-50697\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1020\" height=\"520\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon.png 1020w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon-300x153.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon-768x392.png 768w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2019\u002F03\u002Fdeep-learning-framework-icon-850x433.png 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1020px) 100vw, 1020px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s the good news &#8211; you don&#8217;t need an advanced degree or a Ph.D. to learn and master deep learning. But there are certain key concepts you should know (and be well versed in) before you plunge into the deep learning world.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI&#8217;ll be covering five such essential concepts in this article. I also recommend going through the below resources to augment your deep learning experience:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002FIntroduction-to-Neural-Networks?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EIntroduction to Neural Networks (Free Course)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fcomputer-vision-using-deep-learning-version2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EComputer Vision using Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2020\u002F01\u002Fcomprehensive-learning-path-deep-learning-2020\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EA Comprehensive Learning Path for Deep Learning in 2020\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EThe five essentials for starting your deep learning journey are:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EGetting your system ready\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPython programming\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELinear Algebra and Calculus\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EProbability and Statistics\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EKey Machine Learning Concepts\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F5-essential.gif\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-63336\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F5-essential.gif\" alt=\"deep_learning_essentials\" width=\"1050\" height=\"520\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s go over them one by one.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E1. Getting your System Ready for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor learning a new skill, say cooking, you would first need to have all the equipment. You would need tools like a knife, a cooking pan, and of course, a gas stove! You would also need to know how to use the tools given to you.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63159\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef.png\" alt=\"cooking_tools_deep_learning\" width=\"515\" height=\"300\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef.png 960w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef-300x175.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef-768x447.png 768w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002Fchef-850x495.png 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 515px) 100vw, 515px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESimilarly, it is important to set up your system for deep learning, have some knowledge of the tools you would need, and how to use them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERegardless of your operating system, Windows, Linux or Mac, it is important to know the basic commands. Here is a handy table for your reference:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-35-30.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63152\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-35-30.png\" alt=\"linux_windows_commands\" width=\"554\" height=\"221\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-35-30.png 785w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-35-30-300x120.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-35-30-768x306.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 554px) 100vw, 554px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EHere is a great tutorial to get started with Git and the basic Git commands: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogella.com\u002Ftutorials\u002FGit\u002Farticle.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGit &#8211; Tutorial\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Deep learning boom has not only brought path-breaking research in the field of AI but has also broken new barriers in computer hardware.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EGPU (Graphics Processing Unit):\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou would need a GPU to work with image and video data for most deep learning projects. You can build a deep learning model on your laptop\u002FPC without the GPU as well, but then it would be extremely time-consuming to do. The main advantages a GPU has to offer are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt allows for parallel processing\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIn a CPU+GPU combination, CPU assigns complex tasks to GPU and other tasks to itself, thereby saving a lot of time\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is a great video explaining the difference between a GPU and CPU:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ciframe src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002F-P28LKWTzrI\" width=\"857\" height=\"482\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe best part? You don’t need to buy a GPU or get one installed on your machine. There are multiple Cloud Computing resources that provide GPUs either for free or for an extremely low cost. Additionally, there are a few GPUs that come preinstalled with some practice datasets and their own tutorials preloaded. Some of them are Paperspace Gradient, Google Colab, and Kaggle Kernels.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn the other hand, there are full-fledged servers as well which require some installation steps and some customization like Amazon Web Services EC2.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is a table illustrating the options you have:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-33-07.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63150 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-33-07.png\" alt=\"deep learning_Hardware\" width=\"536\" height=\"438\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-33-07.png 536w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-33-07-300x245.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 536px) 100vw, 536px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDeep Learning has also led to Google developing its own type of Processing Units exclusively catering towards building \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002FIntroduction-to-Neural-Networks?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eneural networks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and deep learning tasks &#8211; TPUs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003ETPUs\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETPU, or Tensor Processing Unit, is essentially a co-processor which you use with the CPU. Cheaper than a GPU, a TPU is much faster and thus makes building deep learning models affordable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGoogle Colab also provides free usage of the TPU (not its full-fledged enterprise version, but a cloud version). Here is Google’s own Colab tutorial on working with TPUs and building models on them: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcloud.google.com\u002Ftpu\u002Fdocs\u002Fcolabs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EColab notebooks | Cloud TPU\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo summarize, here are the basic minimum hardware requirements to start cooking your deep learning model:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63153\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28.png\" alt=\"hardware_requirements_dl\" width=\"703\" height=\"316\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28.png 894w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28-300x135.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28-768x345.png 768w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-19-39-28-850x382.png 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 703px) 100vw, 703px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2. Python Programming\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EContinuing the same analogy of learning to cook, you have now got the hang of operating a knife and a gas stove. But what about the skills and the recipes needed to actually cook food?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is where we encounter the software required for deep learning. Python is a programming language that is used across industries for deep learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Fpython.gif\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-62169\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Fpython.gif\" alt=\"loc iloc\" width=\"1050\" height=\"520\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, we can&#8217;t use only Python for the level of computations and operations that deep learning needs. Additional functionalities are provided by what are known as \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F07\u002Fdont-miss-out-24-amazing-python-libraries-data-science\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Elibraries in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. A library can have hundreds of small tools, called functions, that we can use for programming.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EWhile you don’t need to be a coding ninja for Deep Learning, you do need to know the basics of programming in Python\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThat being said, rather than mastering the vast ocean that is programming in Python, you can start off by learning about some specific libraries exclusively geared towards machine learning and dealing with data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnaconda is a framework that helps you keep track of your Python versions and the libraries as well. It is a handy all-in-one tool that is quite popular, easy to work with, and has simple documentation as well. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F08\u002Feverything-know-about-setting-up-python-windows-linux-and-mac\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EHere is how you can install Anaconda\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo what do I mean by the basics of Python? Let&#8217;s discuss this in a bit more detail.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENote: You can start learning Python in our free and popular course &#8211; \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPython for Data Science\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E1. Variables and data types in Python\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe main data types in Python are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInt\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Integer numbers, can be signed\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFloat\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Decimal numbers\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EString\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: a single character or a sequence of characters\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBool\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: to hold the 2 boolean values &#8211; True and False\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E2. Operators in Python\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are 5 main types of operators in Python:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EArithmetic operators\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Like +, -, *, \u002F, etc\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EComparison operators\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: like &lt;, &gt;, &lt;=, &gt;=, ==, !=\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ELogical operators\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: and, or, not\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentity operators\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: is, is not\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EMembership operators\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: in, not in\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E3. Data Structures in Python\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPython offers a variety of datasets that we can use for different purposes. Each data structure has its unique properties that we can leverage to store different types of data and data types. These properties are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EOrdered:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EThis means that there is a specific order in which the elements in the data structure are stored. No matter how and when we use it, this order remains the same (unless we change it explicitly)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EImmutable:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E This means that the data structure cannot be changed. If a data structure is mutable, it means that it can be changed\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn data science, the most frequently used data structures are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ELists:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Ordered and mutable\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: We have a list like this:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emy_list = [1, 3, 7, 9]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis order will remain the same everywhere we use this list. Also, we can change this list, like removing 7, adding 11, etc.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETuple:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Similar to a list (it is ordered), but unlike a list, a tuple is immutable\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: A tuple can be declared as:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emy_t\u003Cspan class=\"pythoncolor\"\u003Euple = (\u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"apple\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"banana\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"cherry\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"pythoncolor\"\u003ENow, again, this order will remain the same, but unlike a list, we cannot remove &#8216;cherry&#8217;, or add &#8216;orange&#8217; to the tuple.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESets:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Unordered and mutable, though they can only hold unique values\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: A set uses curly braces like this:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E my_set = {'apple', 'banana', 'cherry'}\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe order is not defined for a set.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EDictionaries:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E A set of &lt;key, value&gt; pairs. A dictionary is unordered and changeable. This means that they essentially have no order, can be changed, but yet can be accessed via indices or keys. A dictionary can have only unique keys, though a key may not necessarily hold a unique value.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: A dictionary also uses curly braces with a key-value format:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emy_dict = \u003Cspan class=\"pythoncolor\"\u003E{ \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"brand\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E: \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"Ford\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E,  \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"model\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E: \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"Mustang\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E,  \u003Cspan class=\"pythonstringcolor\"\u003E\"year\"\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E: \u003Cspan class=\"pythonnumbercolor\"\u003E1964\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E}\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, &#8216;brand&#8217;, &#8216;model&#8217;, and &#8216;year&#8217; are the keys that have the values &#8216;Ford&#8217;, &#8216;Mustang&#8217;, and &#8216;1964&#8217; respectively. The order of the keys can be different every time you print the dictionary.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E4. Control Flow in Python\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EControl flow means controlling the flow of the execution of your code. We execute the code line by line, and what we execute on a line affects how we write the next line of code:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-21-02.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63155 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-21-02.png\" alt=\"control flow\" width=\"466\" height=\"342\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-21-02.png 466w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-21-02-300x220.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-21-02-100x72.png 100w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 466px) 100vw, 466px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003EConditional statements\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThese are used to set a condition with the conditional operators we saw earlier.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Eif-else\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: What would you like to eat today? A burger, or a salad? If you want the healthier option, you would go for the salad, or if you just wanted a quick bite without caring for the calories, you would choose the burger. That is what the if-else conditional statement does\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: You need to check if a student has passed or failed. If he has obtained marks &gt;= 40, he has passed, otherwise, he has failed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn that case, our conditional statement would be:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eif marks &gt;= 40:\r\n    print(\"Pass\")\r\nelse:\r\n    print(\"Fail\")\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch4\u003ELoops\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe \u003Cstrong\u003Efor loop\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Used to iterate over a sequence. The sequence can mean a sequence of characters (a string) or any of the data structures above like lists, sets, tuples, and dictionaries\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: We have a list having values from 1 to 5 and we need to multiply each value in this list with 3:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Enumbers_list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]\r\n\r\nfor each_number is numbers_list:\r\n   print(each_number * 3)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETry out the above snippets and you can see how easy Python is!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFun note: Unlike other programming languages, we don’t need to store variables of the same type in a data structure. We can totally have a list like this [John, 153, 78.5, “A+”] or even a list of lists like [[“A”, 56], [“B”, 36.5]]. It is this variety and flexibility of Python that has made it so popular among data scientists!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can also avail the below free courses that cover Python and Pandas essentials:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\"\u003EPython for Data Science Course &#8211; Free Course\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fpandas-for-data-analysis-in-python?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPandas for Data Analysis in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E5. Pandas Python\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is one of the first libraries you would come across when you start Machine Learning and Deep Learning. An extremely popular library, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fpandas-for-data-analysis-in-python?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPandas\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is just as required for deep learning as for machine learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe store data in a variety of formats, such as CSV (Comma Separated Values) file, Excel sheets, etc. In order to work with the data in these files, Pandas provides a data structure called a Pandas dataframe (you can think of it as a table).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDataframes and the sheer number of manipulation operations Pandas provides on dataframes make it the workhorse library for machine and deep learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can take this free and easy course to get started with Pandas if you haven’t already: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fpandas-for-data-analysis-in-python?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPandas for Data Analysis in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, if you read the list of 5 things we started out with, you might have a question: What do we do with all the mathematics in deep learning?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWell, let&#8217;s find out!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3. Linear Algebra and Calculus for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere is a common myth that Deep Learning requires advanced knowledge of linear algebra and calculus. Well, let me dispel that myth right here.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou only need to recollect your high school-level math to start your Deep Learning journey!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet us take a simple example. We have images of cats and dogs and we want the machine to tell us which animal is present in any given image:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-41-28.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63157 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-41-28.png\" alt=\"math_deep_learning\" width=\"504\" height=\"294\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-41-28.png 504w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-21-41-28-300x175.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 504px) 100vw, 504px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, we can easily identify the cat and the dog here. But how will the machine distinguish the two? The only way is to give this data to the model in the form of numbers, and that is where we need linear algebra. We basically convert the images of a cat and a dog into numbers. These numbers can be either expressed as vectors or as matrices.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe will cover some key terms and some great resources you can learn from.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003ELinear Algebra for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E1. \u003Cstrong\u003EScalars and vectors:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E While scalars only have magnitude, vectors have both direction and magnitude.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"list-style-type: none;\"\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EDot product:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The Dot product of 2 vectors returns a scalar value\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003ECross product:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The Cross product of two vectors returns another vector which is orthogonal (right-angled) to both\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExample: If we have 2 vectors a = [1, -3, 5] and b = [4, -2, -1], then:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Ea) Dot product:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ea . b = (a1 * b1) + (a2 * b2) + (a3 * b3) = (1 * 4) + (-3 * -2) + (5 * 1) = 3\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Eb) Cross product:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ea X b = [c1, c2, c3] = [13, 21, 10]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Ewhere,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ec1 = (a2*b3) - (a3*b2)\r\nc2 = (a3*b1) - (a1*b3)\r\nc3 = (a1*b2) - (a2*b1)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2. Matrices and Matrix Operations:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E A matrix is an array of numbers in the form of rows and columns. Now, for example, the above image of a cat can be written as a matrix of pixels: \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-22-11-55.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63158 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-22-11-55.png\" alt=\"deep learning linear algebra\" width=\"409\" height=\"304\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-22-11-55.png 409w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-22-11-55-300x223.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-03-22-11-55-83x63.png 83w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 409px) 100vw, 409px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EJust like numbers, we can perform operations like adding and subtracting two matrices. However, operations like multiplication and division are performed slightly differently from the regular way:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EScalar Multiplication:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E When we multiply a single scalar value with a matrix, we multiply the scalar with all the elements in the matrix\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EMatrix Multiplication:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Multiplying 2 matrices means calculating the dot product of the rows and columns and creating a new matrix with different dimensions than the 2 input matrices\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETranspose of the matrix:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E We swap the rows and the columns in a matrix to get its transpose\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInverse to the matrix:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Conceptually similar to inverting numbers, an inverse of a matrix multiplied with the matrix gives you an identity matrix\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can refer to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.khanacademy.org\u002Fmath\u002Flinear-algebra\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ethis excellent Khan Academy course on Linear Algebra\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to learn the above concepts in detail. You can also check out 10 powerful applications of linear algebra \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F07\u002F10-applications-linear-algebra-data-science\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003ECalculus for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe value we are trying to predict, say, ‘y’, is whether the image is a cat or a dog. This value can be expressed as a function of the input variables\u002Finput vectors. Our main aim is to make this predicted value as close to the actual value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, imagine dealing with thousands of cat images and dog images. These are surely cute to look at, but you can imagine that working on these images and numbers is not easy at all!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESince deep learning essentially involves large amounts of data and complex machine learning models, working with both is often time and resource expensive. That is why it is important to optimize our deep learning model in such a way that it is able to predict as accurately as possible without using too many resources and time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is where the crux of the calculus used in deep learning lies: \u003Cstrong\u003EOptimization\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn any deep learning or machine learning model, we can express the output as a mathematical function of the input variables. Thus, we need to see how our output changes with changes in each of the input variables. We need derivatives to do this since derivatives express the rate of change.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EDerivatives and Partial derivatives\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cb\u003E: \u003C\u002Fb\u003ESimply speaking, derivatives measure the change in the output value when we change the input value. In mathematical terms:\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cpre style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003EIf y = f(x), then the derivative of y with respect to x, id given as\r\ndy\u002Fdx = change in y \u002F change in x\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGeometrically, if we express f(x) as a graph, the derivative at a point is also the slope of the tangent to the graph at that point.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is a figure to help you understand it:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fupload.wikimedia.org\u002Fwikipedia\u002Fcommons\u002F9\u002F97\u002FIntroductory_Physics_fig_1.15.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fupload.wikimedia.org\u002Fwikipedia\u002Fcommons\u002F9\u002F97\u002FIntroductory_Physics_fig_1.15.png\" alt=\"calculus deep learning\" width=\"458\" height=\"296\" data-file-width=\"458\" data-file-height=\"296\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe derivative we have seen above talks only of one variable, x. However, in deep learning, there can be hundreds of variables on which our final output, y, depends. In such cases, we need to calculate the rate of change in y with respect to each of these input variables. Here is where partial derivatives come into the picture.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EPartial derivatives\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Basically, we consider only one variable, and keep all the other variables as constant. Then, we calculate the derivate of y with the remaining variable. Like this, we calculate the derivative with respect to each variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EChain Rule:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Oftentimes, the function of y in terms of the input variables can be much more complicated. How do we calculate the derivative then? The chain rule helps us compute this:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003EIf y = f(g(x)), where g(x) is a function of x, and f is a function of g(x), then\r\ndy\u002Fdx = df\u002Fdx * dg\u002Fdx\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet us consider a relatively simple example:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ey = sin(x^2)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThus, using the Chain Rule:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edy\u002Fdx = d(sin(x2))\u002Fdx * d(x2)\u002Fdx = cos(x2) * 2x\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELearning Resources for Calculus in Deep Learning:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EDifferential Calculus Course on Khan Academy: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.khanacademy.org\u002Fmath\u002Fdifferential-calculus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EDifferential Calculus\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E3Blue1Brown has great videos on Mathematics and Calculus:  \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fchannel\u002FUCYO_jab_esuFRV4b17AJtAw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003E3Blue1Brown\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E4. Probability and Statistics for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EJust like Linear Algebra, ‘Statistics and Probability’ is its own new world of mathematics. It can be quite intimidating for beginners and even seasoned data scientists sometimes find it challenging to recall advanced statistical concepts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, it cannot be denied that Statistics form the backbone of Machine Learning and Deep Learning. The concepts of probability and statistics like descriptive statistics and hypothesis testing are extremely crucial in the industry where the interpretability of your deep learning model is the topmost priority.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet us start with the basic definitions:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EStatistics is the study of data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EDescriptive statistics is the study of the mathematical tools to describe and represent the data\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EProbability measures the likelihood that an event will occur\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EDescriptive Statistics\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet me give you a simple example. Suppose you have the marks scored by 1000 students on an entrance exam (the marks are out of 100). Someone asks you &#8211; how did the students perform in this exam? Would you present that person with a detailed study of the scores of the students? In the future, you might, but initially, you can start off by saying that the average score was 68. This is the mean of the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESimilarly, we can figure out more simple statements based on the data:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-04-10-48-45.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-63191 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-04-10-48-45.png\" alt=\"descriptive_statistics\" width=\"393\" height=\"150\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-04-10-48-45.png 393w, https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F03\u002FScreenshot-from-2020-03-04-10-48-45-300x115.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 393px) 100vw, 393px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere you go &#8211; just with these few lines, we can say that a majority of the students performed well, but not many were able to score really high marks in the test. This is what descriptive statistics is. We represented the data of 1000 students using just 5 values.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are other key terms used in descriptive statistics as well, such as:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EStandard Deviation\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EVariance\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ENormal distribution\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECentral Limit Theorem\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EProbability\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBased on the same example, let&#8217;s say that you are asked a question: if I pick a student randomly from these 1000 students, what are the chances that he\u002Fshe has passed the test? The concept of probability will help you answer this question. If you get a probability of 0.6, it implies that there is a 60% chance that he\u002Fshe passed it (assuming the passing criteria is 40 marks).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOther questions on the same data (as shown below) can be answered using Hypothesis testing and Inferential Statistics to answer them:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECan the entrance test be considered to be tough?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EWas a high score by the student the result of studying hard or because the questions in the test were easy?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can learn all about statistics and probability from the below resources:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science-2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EIntroduction to Data Science (with Statistics and Probability)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fcomprehensive-practical-guide-inferential-statistics-data-science\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EComprehensive &amp; Practical Inferential Statistics Guide\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fbasic-probability-data-science-with-examples\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EBasics of Probability for Data Science\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Fhypothesis-testing-explained\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EYour Guide to Master Hypothesis Testing in Statistics\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E5. Key Machine Learning Concepts for Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s the good news &#8211; you don’t need to know the entire gamut of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EMachine Learning algorithms\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that exist today. Not to say that they are insignificant, but just from the point of view of starting deep learning, there are not many you need to be acquainted with.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are, however, a few concepts that are crucial to build your foundation and acquaint yourself with. Let us go over these concepts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003ESupervised and Unsupervised algorithms\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESupervised Learning:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E In these algorithms, we know the target variable (what we want to predict) and we know the input variables (the independent features which contribute to the target variable). We then generate an equation that gives the relationship between the input and the target variables and apply it to the data we have. Examples: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F03\u002Fintroduction-k-neighbours-algorithm-clustering\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EkNN\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Funderstaing-support-vector-machine-example-code\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ESVM\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F06\u002Fa-comprehensive-guide-for-linear-ridge-and-lasso-regression\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELinear Regression\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, etc.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EUnsupervised Learning:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E In unsupervised learning, we do not know the target variable. It is mainly used to cluster our data into groups, and we can identify the groups after we have clustered the data. Examples of unsupervised learning include \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F11\u002Fan-introduction-to-clustering-and-different-methods-of-clustering\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ek-means clustering\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, apriori algorithm, etc.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EEvaluation Metrics\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBuilding a predictive model is not the only step required in deep learning. You need to check how good the model is and keep improving it till we reach the best model we can.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo how do we judge the performance of a deep learning model? We use some evaluation metrics. Depending on the task, we have different evaluation metrics for regression and classification.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EEvaluation metrics for Classification:\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EConfusion Matrix\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAccuracy\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPrecision and Recall\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EF1-score\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAUC-ROC\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ELog Loss\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EEvaluation metrics for Regression:\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ERMSE\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ERMSLE\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ER2 and adjusted R2\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEvaluation metrics are extremely crucial in deep learning. Be it in the research domain or in the industry, your deep learning model will be judged on the value of the evaluation metric.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F08\u002F11-important-model-evaluation-error-metrics\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003E11 Important Model Evaluation Metrics for Machine Learning Everyone should know\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fevaluation-metrics-for-machine-learning-models?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EFree Course &#8211; Evaluation Metrics for Machine Learning Models\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EValidation Techniques\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA deep learning model trains itself on the data provided to it. However, as I mentioned above, we need to improve this model and we need to check its performance. The true mettle of the model can only be observed when we give it totally new (although cleaned) data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut then, how do we improve on the model? Do we give it new data every time we want to change even a single parameter? You can imagine how time-consuming and costly such a task would be!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is why we use validation. We divide our entire data into 3 parts: training, validation, and testing. Here is a single sentence to help you remember:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWe train the model on the training set, improve it on the validation set, and finally predict on the so-far unseen test set.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome common strategies for Cross-validation are: k-fold Cross-Validation and Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation (LOOCV).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s a comprehensive article covering validation techniques and how to implement them in Python: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2018\u002F05\u002Fimprove-model-performance-cross-validation-in-python-r\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EImprove Your Model Performance using Cross-Validation (in Python \u002F R)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EGradient Descent\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet us go back to the calculus we saw earlier and the need for optimization. How do we know that we have achieved the best model there can be? We can make small changes in the equation and at each change, we check if we are closer to the actual value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt is this act of taking small steps towards a possible direction which is the basic intuition behind gradient descent. Gradient descent is one of the most important concepts you will come across and revisit often in deep learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExplanation and implementation of Gradient Descent in Python: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F03\u002Fintroduction-to-gradient-descent-algorithm-along-its-variants\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EIntroduction to Gradient Descent Algorithm (along with variants)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Machine Learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003ELinear Models\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat is the simplest equation you can think of? Let me list a few:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"list-style-type: none;\"\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EY = x + 1\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E4x + 3y -2z = 56\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EY = x\u002F(1-x)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDid you notice the one thing that was common in all the 3 functions? Yes, they are all linear functions. What if we could predict the value of y using these functions?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThese would then be called linear models. You would be surprised to know how popular linear models are in the industry. They are not too complicated, are interpretable, and with the right gradient descent, we can get high evaluation metrics too! Not only this, linear models form the basis of deep learning. For instance, do you know that you can create a logistic regression model using a simple \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002FIntroduction-to-Neural-Networks?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eneural network\u003C\u002Fa\u003E?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s a detailed guide covering not only linear and logistic regression but other linear models as well: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F08\u002Fcomprehensive-guide-regression\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003E7 Regression Types and Techniques in Data Science\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EUnderfitting and Overfitting\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou will often come across situations where your deep learning model is performing very well on the training set but gives you poor accuracy on the validation set. This is because the model is learning each and every pattern from the training set, and thus, it is unable to detect these patterns in the validation set. This is called overfitting the data and it makes the model too complex.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn the other hand, if your deep learning model is performing poorly on both the training set as well as the validation set, it is most likely underfitting. Think of it as applying a linear equation (a too simple model) on our data when it is, in fact, non-linear (complex):\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Funderfitting-overfitting.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-13056 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Funderfitting-overfitting.png\" alt=\"overfitting underfitting\" width=\"555\" height=\"140\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Funderfitting-overfitting.png 555w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Funderfitting-overfitting-300x76.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 555px) 100vw, 555px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA simple analogy for overfitting and underfitting is a student’s example in a math class:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EOverfitting is associated with that student who does rote learning of all the problems discussed in the class but is unable to answer different questions pertaining to the same concepts during the exam\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUnderfitting is that student who doesn’t perform well in the class, nor in the exam. We aim for that model\u002Fstudent who need not know all the problems discussed in the class but performs well enough in the exam to show that he\u002Fshe knows the concepts\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECheck out this intuitive explanation of overfitting and underfitting, along with the comparison between them: \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Funderfitting-overfitting-best-fitting-machine-learning\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EUnderfitting vs. Overfitting in Machine Learning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EBias-Variance\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn simplest terms, bias is the difference between the actual value and the predicted value. Variance is measured by the change in the output when we change the training data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F07\u002Fvariance_bias.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-18506 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F07\u002Fvariance_bias.png\" alt=\"bias variance\" width=\"503\" height=\"474\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F07\u002Fvariance_bias.png 503w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F07\u002Fvariance_bias-300x283.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 503px) 100vw, 503px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s quickly summarize what we can interpret from the above image:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"list-style-type: none;\"\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETop left:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E A model that is very accurate, therefore the error of our model will be low, meaning a low bias and low variance. All the data points fit within the bullseye\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETop right:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The predicted data points are centered around the bullseye (low variance), but they are far from each other and from the center as well (high bias)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBottom left:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The predicted values are clustered together (low variance), but are pretty far from the bulls-eye (high bias)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBottom right:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The predicted data points are neither close to the bullseye (high bias) nor are close to each other (high variance)\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth high bias and high variance lead to an increase in the error. \u003Cstrong\u003ETypically, a high bias implies underfitting, and a high variance implies overfitting.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E It is very difficult to achieve both low bias and low variance &#8211; one usually comes at the cost of the other.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn terms of model complexity, we can use the below diagram to decide on the optimal complexity of our model:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Fbiasvariance.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-62965 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Fbiasvariance.png\" alt=\"BiasVsVariance\" width=\"492\" height=\"309\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI encourage you to go through this awesome essay by Scott Fortmann-Roe on Bias Variance using examples: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fscott.fortmann-roe.com\u002Fdocs\u002FBiasVariance.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EUnderstanding the Bias-Variance Tradeoff\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003Esklearn\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EJust like the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fpandas-for-data-analysis-in-python?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EPandas library\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, there is another library that forms the foundation of machine learning. The sklearn library is the most popular library in machine learning. It contains a large number of machine learning algorithms which can you can apply to your data in the form of functions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat&#8217;s more, sklearn even has the functionalities for all the evaluation metrics, cross-validation, and scaling\u002Fnormalizing your data as well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s a quick example of sklearn in action:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Efrom sklearn import datasets, linear_model\r\nfrom sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error\r\n\r\nregr = LinearRegression()  \r\n\r\n#train your data - remember how we train the model on our train set?\r\nregr.fit(X_train, y_train)\r\n\r\n#predict on our validation set to improve it\r\ny_pred = regr.predict(X_Valid)\r\n\r\n#evaluation metrics: MSE\r\nprint('Mean Squared Error:', mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))\r\n...#further improvement of our model\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere you go! We could build a simple linear regression model with essentially less than 10 lines of code!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are a couple of excellent resources to learn more about sklearn:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fget-started-with-scikit-learn-sklearn?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EGetting Started with scikit-learn (sklearn) for Machine Learning\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2020\u002F02\u002Feverything-you-should-know-scikit-learn\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=deep-learning-5-things-to-know\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EEverything you Need to Know about skikit-learn&#8217;s Latest Update\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this article, we covered 5 essential things you need to know before building your first deep learning model. It is here that you will encounter the popular deep learning frameworks like PyTorch and TensorFlow. They have been built with Python in mind and you can now easily understand working with them since you have a good grasp of Python.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are a couple of great articles to get started on these frameworks:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fan-introduction-to-implementing-neural-networks-using-tensorflow\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EDeep Learning Guide: Introduction to Implementing Neural Networks using TensorFlow in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2019\u002F09\u002Fintroduction-to-pytorch-from-scratch\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003EA Beginner-Friendly Guide to PyTorch and How it Works from Scratch\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOnce you have built your foundations on these 5 pillars, you can always explore more advanced concepts like Hyperparameter Tuning, Backpropagation, etc. These are the concepts I built my knowledge of deep learning on.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHow would you go about starting your deep learning journey?
