The dataset has 550,069 rows and 12 columns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict purchase amount.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fblack-friday\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdiscuss.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Ft\u002Fblack-friday-data-hack-reveal-your-approach\u002F5986\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E2. Human Activity Recognition Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\" wp-image-28589 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fas.jpg\" alt=\"as\" width=\"157\" height=\"107\" \u002F\u003EThis data set is collected from recordings of 30 human subjects captured via smartphones enabled with embedded inertial sensors. Many machine learning courses use this data for teaching purposes. It&#8217;s your turn now. This is a multi-classification problem. The data set has 10,299 rows and 561 columns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the activity category of a human.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Farchive.ics.uci.edu\u002Fml\u002Fdatasets\u002FHuman+Activity+Recognition+Using+Smartphones\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Frstudio-pubs-static.s3.amazonaws.com\u002F291850_859937539fb14c37b0a311db344a6016.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E3. Text Mining Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28575 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Ftext-mining-150x150.jpg\" alt=\"De l'éloquence judiciaire À Athenes\" width=\"119\" height=\"93\" \u002F\u003EThis dataset is originally from the Siam Text Mining Competition held in 2007. The data comprises of aviation safety reports describing problem(s) which occurred in certain flights. It is a multi-classification and high dimensional problem. It has 21,519 rows and 30,438 columns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Classify the documents according to their labels.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.csie.ntu.edu.tw\u002F~cjlin\u002Flibsvmtools\u002Fdatasets\u002Fmultilabel.html#siam-competition2007\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwtlab.um.ac.ir\u002Fimages\u002Fe-library\u002Ftext_mining\u002FSurvey%20of%20Text%20Mining%202%20.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E4. Trip History Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28576 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Ftrip-history-data-150x150.jpg\" alt=\"trip-history-data\" width=\"114\" height=\"110\" \u002F\u003EThis dataset comes from a bike sharing service in the United States. This dataset requires you to exercise your pro data munging skills. The data is provided quarter-wise from 2010 (Q4) onwards. Each file has 7 columns. It is a classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the class of user.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.capitalbikeshare.com\u002Ftrip-history-data\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsolution-kaggle-competition-bike-sharing-demand\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E5. Million Song Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28577 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fmillion-song-300x169.jpg\" alt=\"million-song\" width=\"150\" height=\"87\" \u002F\u003EDid you know data science can be used in the entertainment industry also? Do it yourself now. This data set puts forward a regression task. It consists of 5,15,345 observations and 90 variables. However, this is just a tiny subset of the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Flabrosa.ee.columbia.edu\u002Fmillionsong\u002Fpages\u002Fgetting-dataset\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003Eoriginal database\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of data about a million songs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict release year of the song.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Farchive.ics.uci.edu\u002Fml\u002Fdatasets\u002FYearPredictionMSD\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww-personal.umich.edu\u002F~yjli\u002Fcontent\u002Fprojectreport.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E6. Census Income Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28578 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002FUS-Census-300x228.png\" alt=\"us-census\" width=\"160\" height=\"81\" \u002F\u003EIt&#8217;s an imbalanced classification and a classic machine learning problem. You know, machine learning is being extensively used to solve imbalanced problems such as cancer detection, fraud detection etc. It&#8217;s time to get your hands dirty. The data set has 48,842 rows and 14 columns. For guidance, you can check this \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F09\u002Fthis-machine-learning-project-on-imbalanced-data-can-add-value-to-your-resume\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003Eimbalanced data project\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the income class of US population.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Farchive.ics.uci.edu\u002Fml\u002Fmachine-learning-databases\u002Fcensus-income-mld\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcseweb.ucsd.edu\u002F~jmcauley\u002Fcse190\u002Freports\u002Fsp15\u002F048.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E7. Movie Lens Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28579 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fmovie-lens-data-300x201.jpg\" alt=\"movie-lens-data\" width=\"159\" height=\"79\" \u002F\u003EHave you built a recommendation system yet? Here&#8217;s your chance! This dataset is one of the most popular &amp; quoted datasets in the data science industry. It is available in \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fgrouplens.org\u002Fdatasets\u002Fmovielens\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003Evarious dimensions\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Here I&#8217;ve used a fairly small size. It has 1 million ratings from 6,000 users on 4,000 movies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Recommend new movies to users.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fgrouplens.org\u002Fdatasets\u002Fmovielens\u002F1m\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F06\u002Fquick-guide-build-recommendation-engine-python\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E8. Twitter Classification Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-9696 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2014\u002F11\u002FMining_Twitter_Data.jpg\" alt=\"Mining Twitter Data\" width=\"140\" height=\"116\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2014\u002F11\u002FMining_Twitter_Data.jpg 450w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2014\u002F11\u002FMining_Twitter_Data-300x248.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 140px) 100vw, 140px\" \u002F\u003EWorking with Twitter data has become an integral part of sentiment analysis problems. If you want to carve a niche for yourself in this area, you will have fun working on the challenge this dataset poses. The dataset is 3MB in size and has 31,962 tweets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EIdentify the tweets which are hate tweets and which are not.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fpractice-problem-twitter-sentiment-analysis\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fabdulfatir\u002Ftwitter-sentiment-analysis\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EAdvanced Level\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E1. Identify your Digits Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28584 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fidentify-the-digits-1-150x150.jpg\" alt=\"identify-the-digits\" width=\"117\" height=\"99\" \u002F\u003EThis dataset allows you to study, analyze and recognize elements in the images. That&#8217;s exactly how your camera detects your face, using image recognition! It&#8217;s your turn to build and test that technique. It&#8217;s a digit recognition problem. This data set has 7,000 images of 28 X 28 size, totalling 31MB.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Identify digits from an image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fpractice-problem-identify-the-digits\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fan-introduction-to-implementing-neural-networks-using-tensorflow\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E2. Urban Sound Classification\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-43753 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FPractice_Problem_1920_480-thumbnail-1200x12001.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"92\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FPractice_Problem_1920_480-thumbnail-1200x12001.png 651w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FPractice_Problem_1920_480-thumbnail-1200x12001-300x138.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen you start your machine learning journey, you go with simple machine learning problems like titanic survival prediction. But you still don&#8217;t have enough practice when it comes to real life problems. Hence, this practice problem is meant to introduce you to audio processing in the usual classification scenario. This dataset consists of 8,732 sound excerpts of urban sounds from 10 classes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Classify the type of sound from the audio.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fpractice-problem-urban-sound-classification\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F08\u002Faudio-voice-processing-deep-learning\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E3. Vox Celebrity Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-43759 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fvox.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"225\" height=\"115\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fvox.png 514w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fvox-300x152.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 225px) 100vw, 225px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAudio processing is rapidly becoming an important field in deep learning hence here&#8217;s another challenging problem. This dataset is for large-scale speaker identification and contains words spoken by celebrities, extracted from YouTube videos. It’s an intriguing use case for isolating and identifying speech recognition. The data contains 100,000 utterances spoken by 1,251 celebrities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Figure out which celebrity the voice belongs to.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.robots.ox.ac.uk\u002F~vgg\u002Fdata\u002Fvoxceleb\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.robots.ox.ac.uk\u002F~vgg\u002Fpublications\u002F2017\u002FNagrani17\u002Fnagrani17.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E4. ImageNet Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28590 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fla-300x174.png\" alt=\"la\" width=\"191\" height=\"84\" \u002F\u003EImageNet offers variety of problems which encompasses object detection, localization, classification and screen parsing. All the images are freely available. You can search for any type of image and build your project around it. As of now, this image engine has more than 15 million images of multiple shapes sizing up to 140GB.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Problem to solve is subjected to the image type you download.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fimage-net.org\u002Fdownload-imageurls\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fimage-net.org\u002Fdownload-imageurls\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E5. Chicago Crime Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-28583 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fchicago-crime-300x225.jpg\" alt=\"chicago-crime\" width=\"175\" height=\"133\" \u002F\u003EThe ability to handle large datasets is expected of every data scientist these days. Companies no longer prefer to work on samples when they the computational power to work on the full dataset. This dataset provides you a much needed hands-on experience of handling large data sets on your local machines. The problem is easy, but data management is the key! This dataset has 6M observations. It&#8217;s a multi-classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the type of crime.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdata.cityofchicago.org\u002FPublic-Safety\u002FCrimes-2001-to-present\u002Fijzp-q8t2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fnathanwayneholt.com\u002Fmathematicalmodeling\u002FChicagoCrimesReport.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E6. Age Detection of Indian Actors Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-43750 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fage-detection.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"177\" height=\"115\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fage-detection.png 463w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fage-detection-300x194.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Fage-detection-258x169.png 258w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 177px) 100vw, 177px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is a fascinating challenge for any deep learning enthusiast. The dataset contains thousands of images of Indian actors and your task is to identify their age. All the images are manually selected and cropped from the video frames resulting in a high degree of variability interms of scale, pose, expression, illumination, age, resolution, occlusion, and makeup. There are 19,906 images in the training set and 6,636 in the test set.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the age of the actors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fimage-net.org\u002Fdownload-imageurls\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F06\u002Fhands-on-with-deep-learning-solution-for-age-detection-practice-problem\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E7. Recommendation Engine Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-43757 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Frecommendation-system.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"169\" height=\"113\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Frecommendation-system.png 619w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002Frecommendation-system-300x200.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 169px) 100vw, 169px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is an advanced recommendation system challenge. In this practice problem, you are given the data of programmers and questions that they have previously solved, along with the time that they took to solve that particular question. As a data scientist, the model you build will help online judges to decide the next level of questions to recommend to a user.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Predict the time taken to solve a problem given the current status of the user.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fpractice-problem-recommendation-engine\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E8. VisualQA Dataset\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-43754 alignright\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FVQA-768x432.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"231\" height=\"130\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FVQA-768x432.jpg 768w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FVQA-768x432-300x169.jpg 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2018\u002F04\u002FVQA-768x432-257x144.jpg 257w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 231px) 100vw, 231px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EVisualQA is a dataset containing open-ended questions about images. These questions require an understanding of computer vision and language. There is an automatic evaluation metric for this problem. The dataset has 265,016 images, 3 questions per image and 10 ground truth answers per question.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EProblem:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Use deep learning technique to answer open-ended questions about images.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EStart:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.visualqa.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Data\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Cstrong\u003ETutorial:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fabs\u002F1708.02711\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EGet Here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EOut of the 24 datasets listed above, you should start by finding the one that matches your skillset. Say, if you are a beginner in machine learning, avoid taking up advanced level data sets from the get go. Don&#8217;t bite more than you can chew and don&#8217;t feel overwhelmed with how much you still have to do. Instead, focus on making step-wise progress.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EOnce you complete 2 &#8211; 3 projects, showcase them on your resume and your GitHub profile (very important!). Lots of recruiters these days hire candidates by checking their GitHub profiles. Your motive shouldn&#8217;t be to do all the projects, but to pick out selected ones based on the problem to be solved, domain and the dataset size. If you want to look at complete project solution, take a look at \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F09\u002Fthis-machine-learning-project-on-imbalanced-data-can-add-value-to-your-resume\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Ethis article\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EDid you find this article useful? Have you already built any projects on these datasets? Do share your experience, learnings and suggestions in the comments section below.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3 style=\"text-align: One such example of unstructured …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EExtracting useful information from unstructured data has always been a topic of huge interest in the research community. One such example of unstructured data is an image, and analysis of image data has applications in various aspects of business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skilltest is specially designed for you to test your knowledge on the knowledge on how to handle image data, with an emphasis on image processing. More than 300 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fimage-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F\"\u003EEssentials of Machine Learning Algorithms (with Python and R Codes)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2014\u002F12\u002Fimage-processing-python-basics\u002F\"\u003EBasics of Image Processing in Python\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1) Match the following image formats to their correct number of channels\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EGrayScale\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ERGB\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Col style=\"list-style-type: upper-roman;\"\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E 1 channel\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E2 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E3 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E4 channels\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENone\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) RGB -&gt; I, GrayScale-&gt; III\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) RGB -&gt; IV, GrayScale-&gt; II\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) RGB -&gt; III, GrayScale -&gt; I\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) RGB -&gt; II, GrayScale -&gt; I\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EGrayscale images have one number per pixel, and are stored as an m × n matrix, whereas Color images  have 3 numbers per pixel – red, green, and blue brightness (RGB)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have to rotate an image. Image rotation is nothing but multiplication of image by a specific matrix to get a new transformed image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" point in the image to rotate with co-ordinates as (1, 0) to a co-ordinate of (0, 1), which of the following matrix would we have to multiply with?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" height=\"53\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe calculation of would be like this;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n[[0], [1]] = [[0, -1], [1, 0]] x [1, 0]\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) [True or False] To blur an image, you can use a linear filter\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBlurring compares neighboring pixels in a filter and smooth them. For this, you cannot use a linear filter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) Which of the following is a challenge when dealing with computer vision problems?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Variations due to geometric changes (like pose, scale etc)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Variations due to photometric factors (like illumination, appearance etc)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Image occlusion\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the above mentioned options are challenges in computer vision\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose we have an image given below.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOur task is to segment the objects in the image. A simple way to do this is to represent the image in terms of the intensity of pixels and the cluster them according to the values. On doing this, we got this type of structure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38417 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"440\" height=\"268\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b.jpg 440w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105047\u002FImage_Con_5b-300x183.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 440px) 100vw, 440px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003ESuppose we choose k-means clustering to solve the problem, what would be the appropriate value of k from just a visual inspection of the intensity graph?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThree clusters will be formed; points in the circle, points in the square and the points excluding both of these objects\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-38418 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"277\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6.jpg 277w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31105320\u002FImage6-217x300.jpg 217w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 277px) 100vw, 277px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIn this image, you can find an edge labelled in the red region. Which form of discontinuity creates this kind of edge?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Depth Discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Surface color Discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Illumination discontinuity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe chair and wall are far from each other, causing an edge in the image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) Finite difference filters in image processing are very susceptible to noise. To cope up with this, which of the following methods can you use so that there would be minimal distortions by noise?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Downsample the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Convert the image to grayscale from RGB\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Smooth the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESmoothing helps in reducing noise by forcing pixels to be more like their neighbours\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) Consider and image with width and height as 100&#215;100. Each pixel in the image can have a color from Grayscale, i.e. values. How much space would this image require for storing?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: No compression is done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 2,56,00,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 25,60,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2,56,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 8,00,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) 80,000\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nF) 8,000\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe answer will be 8x100x100 because 8 bits will be required to represent a number from 0-256\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) [True or False] Quantizing an image will reduce the amount of memory required for storage.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe statement given is true.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Suppose we have a grayscale image, with most of the values of pixels being same. What can we use to compress the size of image?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Encode the pixels with same values in a dictionary\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Encode the sequence of values of pixels\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) No compression can be done\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EEncoding same values of pixels will greatly reduce the size for storage\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) [True or False] JPEG is a lossy image compression technique\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe reason for JPEG being a lossy compression technique is because of the use of quantization.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E12) Given an image with only 2 pixels and 3 possible values for each pixel, what is the number of possible image histograms that can be formed?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 6\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 9\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 12\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe permutations possible of the histograms would be 9.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) Suppose we have a 1D image with values as\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n[2, 5, 8, 5, 2]\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we apply average filter on this image of size 3. What would be the value of the last second pixel?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The value would remain the same\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The value would increase by 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The value would decrease by 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E(8+5+2)\u002F3 will become 5. So there will be no change.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) fMRI (Functional magnetic resonance imaging) is a technology where volumetric scans of the brain are acquired while the subject is performing some cognitive tasks over time. What is the dimensionality of fMRI output signals?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe question itself mentions “volumetric scans” over time, so it would be a series of 3D scans\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Which of the following methods is used as a model fitting method for edge detection?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) SIFT\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Difference of Gaussian detector\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) RANSAC\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERANSAC is used to find the best fit line in edge detection\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E16)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose we have an image which is noisy. image?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EConvolve the image with identity matrix\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESubtract this resulting image from the original\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this subtracted result back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EB)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESmooth the image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESubtract this smoothed image from the original\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this subtracted result back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EC)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ESmooth the image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EAdd this smoothed image back to the original image\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ED) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: Can you identify which is which?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38422 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"167\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19.jpg 167w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111323\u002FImage19-147x300.jpg 147w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 167px) 100vw, 167px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Operation 1 is cross correlation between signal f and signal g, whereas operation 2 is convolution function applied to signal f and signal g\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Operation 2 is cross correlation between signal f and signal g, whereas operation 1 is convolution function applied to signal f and signal g\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ECorrelation and convolution are two different methods with give different result. Convolution defines how much the signals overlap, whereas correlation tries to find the relation between the signals\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) [True or False] By using template matching along with cross correlation, you can build a vision system for TV remote control\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is a excellent example of cross correlation in computer vision. Refer paper “Computer Vision for Interactive Computer Graphics,” W.Freeman et al, IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E21) Suppose you are creating a face detector in the wild. Which of the following features would you select for creating a robust facial detector?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Location of iris, eyebrow and chin\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Boolean feature: Is the person smiling or not\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. Angle of orientation of face\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n4. Is the person sitting or standing\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1, 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1, 2, 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 1, 2, 3, above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the above are examples of low-level features\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) In RGBA mode of color representation, what does A represent?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Depth of an image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Intensity of colors\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Opacity of an image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOpacity can be mentioned by introducing it as a fourth parameter in RGB\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) In Otsu thresholding technique, you remove the noise by thresholding the points which are irrelevant and keeping those which do not represent noise.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38424 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"631\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24.jpg 631w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24-300x224.jpg 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F31111908\u002FImage24-83x63.jpg 83w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 631px) 100vw, 631px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIn the image given, at which point would you threshold on?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) D\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ELine B would catch most of the noise in the image.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E25) Which of the following data augmentation technique would you prefer for an object recognition problem?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E`\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Horizontal flipping\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Rescaling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Zooming in the image\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll the mentioned techniques can be used for data augmentation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow is the distribution of the scores of the participants:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-39080 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F04211219\u002Fskilltest_image.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"479\" height=\"288\" 479px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can access the scores \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fimage-skilltest\u002Flb\"
