You have various tools, but you ought …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can think of machine learning algorithms as an armory packed with axes, sword and blades. You have various tools, but you ought to learn to use them at the right time. As an analogy, think of ‘Regression’ as a sword capable of slicing and dicing data efficiently, but incapable of dealing with highly complex data. On the contrary, ‘Support Vector Machines’ is like a sharp knife – it works on smaller datasets, but on them, it can be much more stronger and powerful in building models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skilltest was specially designed for you to test your knowledge on SVM techniques and its applications. More than 550 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fsvm-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F\"\u003EEssentials of Machine Learning Algorithms (with Python and R Codes)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Funderstaing-support-vector-machine-example-code\u002F\"\u003EUnderstanding Support Vector Machine algorithm from examples (along with code)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 1 &#8211; 2\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are using a Linear SVM classifier with 2 class classification problem. Now you have been given the following data in which some points are circled red that are representing support vectors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-38435 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"404\" height=\"250\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19.png 404w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F01154204\u002FImage_18-19-300x186.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 404px) 100vw, 404px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1) If you remove the following any one red points from the data. Does the decision boundary will change?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThese three examples are positioned such that removing any one of them introduces slack in the constraints. So the decision boundary would completely change.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2) [True or False] If you remove the non-red circled points from the data, the decision boundary will change?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) True\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) False\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOn the other hand, rest of the points in the data won&#8217;t affect the decision boundary much.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) What do you mean by generalization error in terms of the SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) How far the hyperplane is from the support vectors\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) How accurately the SVM can predict outcomes for unseen data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The threshold amount of error in an SVM\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EGeneralisation error in statistics is generally the out-of-sample error which is the measure of how accurately a model can predict values for previously unseen data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4) When the C parameter is set to infinite, which of the following holds true?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The optimal hyperplane if exists, will be the one that completely separates the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The soft-margin classifier will separate the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAt such a high level of misclassification penalty, soft margin will not hold existence as there will be no room for error.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5) What do you mean by a hard margin?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The SVM allows very low error in classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The SVM allows high amount of error in classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA hard margin means that an SVM is very rigid in classification and tries to work extremely well in the training set, causing overfitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) The minimum time complexity for training an SVM is O(n2). According to this fact, what sizes of datasets are not best suited for SVM&#8217;s?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Large datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Small datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Medium sized datasets\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Size does not matter\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EDatasets which have a clear classification boundary will function best with SVM’s.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E7) The effectiveness of an SVM depends upon:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Selection of Kernel\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Kernel Parameters\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Soft Margin Parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe SVM effectiveness depends upon how you choose the basic 3 requirements mentioned above in such a way that it maximises your efficiency, reduces error and overfitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E8) Support vectors are the data points that lie closest to the decision surface.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThey are the points closest to the hyperplane and the hardest ones to classify. They also have a direct bearing on the location of the decision surface.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) The SVM&#8217;s are less effective when:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The data is linearly separable\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The data is clean and ready to use\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The data is noisy and contains overlapping points\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen the data has noise and overlapping points, there is a problem in drawing a clear hyperplane without misclassifying.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Suppose you are using RBF kernel in SVM with high Gamma value. What does this signify?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The model would consider even far away points from hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The model would consider only the points close to the hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The model would not be affected by distance of points from hyperplane for modeling\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe gamma parameter in SVM tuning signifies the influence of points either near or far away from the hyperplane.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a low gamma, the model will be too constrained and include all points of the training dataset, without really capturing the shape.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a higher gamma, the model will capture the shape of the dataset well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E11) The cost parameter in the SVM means:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The number of cross-validations to be made\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The kernel to be used\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The tradeoff between misclassification and simplicity of the model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe cost parameter decides how much an SVM should be allowed to “bend” with the data. For a low cost, you aim for a smooth decision surface and for a higher cost, you aim to classify more points correctly. It is also simply referred to as the cost of misclassification.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E12)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are building a SVM model on data X. The data X can be error prone which means that you should not trust any specific data point too much. Now think that you want to build a SVM model which has quadratic kernel function of polynomial degree 2 that uses Slack variable C as one of it&#8217;s hyper parameter. Based upon that give the answer for following question.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat would happen when you use very large value of C(C-&gt;infinity)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote: For small C was also classifying all data points correctly\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We can still classify data correctly for given setting of hyper parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We can not classify data correctly for given setting of hyper parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t Say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor large values of C, the penalty for misclassifying points is very high, so the decision boundary will perfectly separate the data if possible.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) What would happen when you use very small C (C~0)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Misclassification would happen\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Data will be correctly classified\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe classifier can maximize the margin between most of the points, while misclassifying a few points, because the penalty is so low.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) If I am using all features of my dataset and I achieve 100% accuracy on my training set, but ~70% on validation set, what should I look out for?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Underfitting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Nothing, the model is perfect\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Overfitting\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we’re achieving 100% training accuracy very easily, we need to check to verify if we’re overfitting our data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Which of the following are real world applications of the SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Text and Hypertext Categorization\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Image Classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Clustering of News Articles\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESVM’s are highly versatile models that can be used for practically all real world problems ranging from regression to clustering and handwriting recognitions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 16 &#8211; 18\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have trained an SVM with linear decision boundary after training SVM, you correctly infer that your SVM model is under fitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) Which of the following option would you more likely to consider iterating SVM next time?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003EA) You want to increase your data points\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) You want to decrease your data points\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) You will try to calculate more variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) You will try to reduce the features\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe best option here would be to create more features for the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E17) Suppose you gave the correct answer in previous question. What do you think that is actually happening?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. We are lowering the bias\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. We are lowering the variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. We are increasing the bias\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n4. We are increasing the variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBetter model will lower the bias and increase the variance\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E18) In above question suppose you want to change one of it&#8217;s(SVM) hyperparameter so that effect would be same as previous questions i.e model will not under fit?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) We will increase the parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) We will decrease the parameter C\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Changing in C don&#8217;t effect\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIncreasing C parameter would be the right thing to do here, as it will ensure regularized model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E19) We usually use feature normalization before using the Gaussian kernel in SVM. What is true about feature normalization?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. We do feature normalization so that new feature will dominate other\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Some times, feature normalization is not feasible in case of categorical variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. Feature normalization always helps when we use Gaussian kernel in SVM\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EStatements one and two are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion Context: 20-22\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are dealing with 4 class classification problem and you want to train a SVM model on the data for that you are using One-vs-all method. Now answer the below questions?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E20) How many times we need to train our SVM model in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFor a 4 class problem, you would have to train the SVM at least 4 times if you are using a one-vs-all method.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E21) Suppose you have same distribution of classes in the data. Now, say for training 1 time in one vs all setting the SVM is taking 10 second. How many seconds would it require to train one-vs-all method end to end?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 20\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 40\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 60\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 80\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIt would take 10&#215;4 = 40 seconds\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E22) Suppose your problem has changed now. Now, data has only 2 classes. What would you think how many times we need to train SVM in such case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ETraining the SVM only one time would give you appropriate results\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EQuestion context: 23 &#8211; 24\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you are using SVM with linear kernel of polynomial degree 2, Now think that you have applied this on data and found that it perfectly fit the data that means, Training and testing accuracy is 100%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) Now, think that you increase the complexity(or degree of polynomial of this kernel). What would you think will happen?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Increasing the complexity will overfit the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Increasing the complexity will underfit the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Nothing will happen since your model was already 100% accurate\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIncreasing the complexity of the data would make the algorithm overfit the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) In the previous question after increasing the complexity you found that training accuracy was still 100%. According to you what is the reason behind that?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Since data is fixed and we are fitting more polynomial term or parameters so the algorithm starts memorizing everything in the data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. Since data is fixed and SVM doesn&#8217;t need to search in big hypothesis space\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the given statements are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) What is\u002Fare true about kernel in SVM?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. Kernel function map low dimensional data to high dimensional space\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. It&#8217;s a similarity function\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the given statements are correct.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow is the distribution of the scores of the participants:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E \u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-39075 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"481\" height=\"290\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm.png 481w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F04194238\u002Fskilltest_svm-300x181.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 481px) 100vw, 481px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can access the scores \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fsvm-skilltest\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. More than 350 people participated in the skill test and the highest score obtained was a 25.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions \u002F doubts please drop in your comments below. I would love to hear your feedback about the skill test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ELearn\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdiscuss.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Eengage,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ecompete,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fjobs\u002F#\u002Fuser\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eget hired\u003C\u002Fa\u003E!\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E","image_url":{"full":"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F05093720\u002Ffence-wood-fence-wood-limit-48246.jpeg","large":"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F05093720\u002Ffence-wood-fence-wood-limit-48246-850x421.jpeg","medium":"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F05093720\u002Ffence-wood-fence-wood-limit-48246-360x206.jpeg","small":"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F05093720\u002Ffence-wood-fence-wood-limit-48246-262x141.jpeg","nano":"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F05093720\u002Ffence-wood-fence-wood-limit-48246-100x72.jpeg"},"categories":[{"id":"a04b6869-52cd-44ca-9e3c-a12ff55c10e1","title":"Skilltest","slug":"skilltest","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"3fc6cc28-325e-4e33-84ee-c7d9c8a67a27","title":"Machine Learning","slug":"machine-learning","description":"","permalink":""}],"author":{"id":"f6067e23-ac9d-4228-bda1-fe95710801da","full_name":"Ankit Gupta","bio":"Ankit is currently working as a data scientist at UBS who has solved complex data mining problems in many domains. He is eager to learn more about data science and machine learning algorithms.","profile_image_url":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F2cb7163def359a52a1c99dcd76222b01?s=96&d=mm&r=g","profile_urls":{"blog":{"id":6611,"permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Ffacebook_user_4\u002F","extra_info":{"id":6611,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Fapp_scoped_user_id\u002F1107394225967405\u002F","link":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Ffacebook_user_4\u002F","name":"Ankit Gupta","slug":"facebook_user_4","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fusers\u002F6611"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fusers"}]},"avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F2cb7163def359a52a1c99dcd76222b01?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F2cb7163def359a52a1c99dcd76222b01?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F2cb7163def359a52a1c99dcd76222b01?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":"Ankit is currently working as a data scientist at UBS who has solved complex data mining problems in many domains. He is eager to learn more about data science and machine learning algorithms."}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"07422bec-406b-49bd-b37e-5014736ccdc2","created":"2018-12-27T11:13:04.010127Z","modified":"2021-05-01T13:56:41.815880Z","resource_id":"20569","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Funderstaing-support-vector-machine-example-code\u002F","resource_created":"2017-09-12T18:30:30Z","resource_modified":"2019-03-11T08:57:28Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":true,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Understanding Support Vector Machine algorithm from examples (along with code)","sub_title":"","description":"Note: This article was originally published on Oct 6th, 2015 and updated on Sept 13th, 2017 Introduction Mastering machine learning algorithms isn't a myth …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENote: This article was originally published on Oct\u003Cspan id=\"timestamp\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E 6th, 2015\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan id=\"timestamp\"\u003Eand updated on Sept 13th, 2017\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EMastering \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science-2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Emachine learning algorithms\u003C\u002Fa\u003E isn&#8217;t a myth at all. Most of the beginners start by learning regression. It is simple to learn and use, but does that solve our purpose? Of course not! Because, you can do so much more than just Regression!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EThink of machine learning algorithms as an armory packed with axes, sword, blades, bow, dagger etc. You have various tools, but you ought to learn to use them at the right time. As an analogy, think of &#8216;Regression&#8217; as a sword capable of slicing and dicing data efficiently, but incapable of dealing with highly complex data. On the contrary, &#8216;Support Vector Machines&#8217; is like a sharp knife &#8211; it works on smaller datasets, but on them, it can be much more stronger and powerful in building models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EBy now, I hope you&#8217;ve now mastered \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Frandom-forest-algorithm-multiple-challenges\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ERandom Forest\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Fnaive-bayes-explained\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ENaive Bayes Algorithm\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science-2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EEnsemble Modeling\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. If not, I&#8217;d suggest you to take out few minutes and read about them as well. In this article, I shall guide you through the basics to advanced knowledge of a crucial machine learning algorithm, support vector machines.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you&#8217;re a beginner looking to start your data science journey, you&#8217;ve come to the right place! Check out the below comprehensive courses, curated by industry experts, that we have created just for you:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science-2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EIntroduction to Data Science\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fbundles\u002Fdata-science-beginners-with-interview?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ECertified Program: Data Science for Beginners (with Interviews)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fsupport-vector.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-50531 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fsupport-vector.png\" alt=\"support vector machines, svm\" width=\"500\" height=\"300\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fsupport-vector.png 500w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002Fsupport-vector-300x180.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003ETable of Contents\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EWhat is Support Vector Machine?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EHow does it work?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EHow to implement SVM in Python and R?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EHow to tune Parameters of SVM?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPros and Cons associated with SVM\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EWhat is Support Vector Machine?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E&#8220;Support Vector Machine&#8221; (SVM) is a supervised \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcourses.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcourses\u002Fintroduction-to-data-science-2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Emachine learning algorithm\u003C\u002Fa\u003E which can be used for both classification or regression challenges. However,  it is mostly used in classification problems. In this algorithm, we plot each data item as a point in n-dimensional space (where n is number of features you have) with the value of each feature being the value of a particular coordinate. Then, we perform classification by finding the hyper-plane that differentiate the two classes very well (look at the below snapshot).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_1.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20602 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_1.png\" alt=\"SVM_1\" width=\"355\" height=\"254\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_1.png 410w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_1-300x214.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 355px) 100vw, 355px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003ESupport Vectors are simply the co-ordinates of individual observation. Support Vector Machine is a frontier which best segregates the two classes (hyper-plane\u002F line).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can look at \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2014\u002F10\u002Fsupport-vector-machine-simplified\u002F?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=understandingsupportvectormachinearticle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Esupport vector machines\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and a few examples of its working here.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EHow does it work?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EAbove, we got accustomed to the process of segregating the two classes with a hyper-plane. Now the burning question is &#8220;How can we identify the right hyper-plane?&#8221;. Don&#8217;t worry, it&#8217;s not as hard as you think!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s understand:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentify the right hyper-plane (Scenario-1): \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EHere, we have three hyper-planes (A, B and C). Now, identify the right hyper-plane to classify star and circle.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20605 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_21.png\" alt=\"SVM_2\" width=\"375\" height=\"265\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_21.png 487w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_21-300x212.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 375px) 100vw, 375px\" \u002F\u003EYou need to remember a thumb rule to identify the right hyper-plane: &#8220;Select the hyper-plane which segregates the two classes better&#8221;. In this scenario, hyper-plane &#8220;B&#8221; has excellently performed this job.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentify the right hyper-plane (Scenario-2): \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EHere, we have three hyper-planes (A, B and C) and all are segregating the classes well. Now, How can we identify the right hyper-plane?\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20606 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_3.png\" alt=\"SVM_3\" width=\"344\" height=\"246\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_3.png 476w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_3-300x214.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 344px) 100vw, 344px\" \u002F\u003EHere, maximizing the distances between nearest data point (either class) and hyper-plane will help us to decide the right hyper-plane. This distance is called as \u003Cstrong\u003EMargin\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. Let&#8217;s look at the below snapshot:\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_4.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20607 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_4.png\" alt=\"SVM_4\" width=\"365\" height=\"266\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_4.png 483w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_4-300x219.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 365px) 100vw, 365px\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fa\u003EAbove, you can see that the margin for hyper-plane C is high as compared to both A and B. Hence, we name the right hyper-plane as C. Another lightning reason for selecting the hyper-plane with higher margin is robustness. If we select a hyper-plane having low margin then there is high chance of miss-classification.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentify the right hyper-plane (Scenario-3):\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EHint:\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EUse the rules as discussed in previous section to identify the right hyper-plane\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_5.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20608 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_5.png\" alt=\"SVM_5\" width=\"372\" height=\"265\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_5.png 486w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_5-300x214.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 372px) 100vw, 372px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003ESome of you may have selected the hyper-plane \u003Cstrong\u003EB \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eas it has higher margin compared to \u003Cstrong\u003EA. \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EBut, here is the catch, SVM selects the hyper-plane which classifies the classes accurately prior to maximizing margin. Here, hyper-plane B has a classification error and A has classified all correctly. Therefore, the right hyper-plane is \u003Cstrong\u003EA.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECan we classify two classes (Scenario-4)?: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EBelow, I am unable to segregate the two classes using a straight line, as one of star lies in the territory of other(circle) class as an outlier. \u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_61.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20610 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_61.png\" alt=\"SVM_6\" width=\"389\" height=\"252\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_61.png 488w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_61-300x194.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 389px) 100vw, 389px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EAs I have already mentioned, one star at other end is like an outlier for star class. SVM has a feature to ignore outliers and find the hyper-plane that has maximum margin. Hence, we can say, SVM is robust to outliers.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_71.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20613 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_71.png\" alt=\"SVM_7\" width=\"354\" height=\"238\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_71.png 462w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_71-300x202.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 354px) 100vw, 354px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFind the hyper-plane to segregate to classes (Scenario-5): \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EIn the scenario below, we can&#8217;t have linear hyper-plane between the two classes, so how does SVM classify these two classes? Till now, we have only looked at the linear hyper-plane.\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_6.png\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_8.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20615 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_8.png\" alt=\"SVM_8\" width=\"358\" height=\"310\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_8.png 472w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_8-300x259.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 358px) 100vw, 358px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003ESVM can solve this problem. Easily! It solves this problem by introducing additional feature. Here, we will add a new feature z=x^2+y^2. Now, let&#8217;s plot the data points on axis x and z:\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_9.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20616 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_9.png\" alt=\"SVM_9\" width=\"359\" height=\"306\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_9.png 435w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_9-300x256.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 359px) 100vw, 359px\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fa\u003EIn above plot, points to consider are:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EAll values for z would be positive always because z is the squared sum of both x and y\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EIn the original plot, red circles appear close to the origin of x and y axes, leading to lower value of z and star relatively away from the origin result to higher value of z.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn SVM, it is easy to have a linear hyper-plane between these two classes. But, another burning question which arises is, should we need to add this feature manually to have a hyper-plane. No, SVM has a technique called the \u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\u002Fwiki\u002FKernel_method\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\"\u003Ekernel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E trick\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. These are functions which takes low dimensional input space and transform it to a higher dimensional space i.e. it converts not separable problem to separable problem, these functions are called kernels. It is mostly useful in non-linear separation problem. Simply put, it does some extremely complex data transformations, then find out the process to separate the data based on the labels or outputs you&#8217;ve defined.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen we look at the hyper-plane in original input space it looks like a circle:\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_10.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20624 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_10.png\" alt=\"SVM_10\" width=\"339\" height=\"301\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_10.png 441w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_10-300x267.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 339px) 100vw, 339px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, let&#8217;s  look at the methods to apply SVM algorithm in a data science challenge.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EHow to implement SVM in Python and R?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Python, scikit-learn is a widely used library for implementing machine learning algorithms, SVM is also available in scikit-learn library and follow the same structure (Import library, object creation, fitting model and prediction). Let&#8217;s look at the below code:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"kn\"\u003E#Import Library\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"kn\"\u003Efrom\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"nn\"\u003Esklearn\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"kn\"\u003Eimport\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E svm\r\n\u003Cspan class=\"c\"\u003E#Assumed you have, X (predictor) and Y (target) for training data set and x_test(predictor) of test_dataset\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"c\"\u003E# Create SVM classification object \r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Emodel = svm.svc(kernel='linear', c=1, gamma=1) \r\n\u003Cspan class=\"c\"\u003E# there is various option associated with it, like changing kernel, gamma and C value. Will discuss more # about it in next section.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"c\"\u003ETrain the model using the training sets and check score\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Emodel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"o\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Efit\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003EX\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Ey\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E)\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Emodel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"o\"\u003E.score\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003EX\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Ey\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E)\r\n\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"c\"\u003E#Predict Output\r\npredicted= model\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"o\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Epredict\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E(\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"n\"\u003Ex_test\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"p\"\u003E)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe e1071 package in R is used to create Support Vector Machines with ease. It has helper functions as well as code for the Naive Bayes Classifier. The creation of a support vector machine in R and Python follow similar approaches, let&#8217;s take a look now at the following code:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#Import Library\r\nrequire(e1071) #Contains the SVM \r\nTrain &lt;- read.csv(file.choose())\r\nTest &lt;- read.csv(file.choose())\r\n# there are various options associated with SVM training; like changing kernel, gamma and C value.\r\n\r\n# create model\r\nmodel &lt;- svm(Target~Predictor1+Predictor2+Predictor3,data=Train,kernel='linear',gamma=0.2,cost=100)\r\n\r\n#Predict Output\r\npreds &lt;- predict(model,Test)\r\ntable(preds)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EHow to tune Parameters of SVM?\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETuning parameters value for machine learning algorithms effectively improves the model performance. Let&#8217;s look at the list of parameters available with SVM.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003Ctt class=\"descclassname\"\u003Esklearn.svm.\u003C\u002Ftt\u003E\u003Ctt class=\"descname\"\u003ESVC\u003C\u002Ftt\u003E\u003Cbig\u003E(\u003C\u002Fbig\u003E\u003Cem\u003EC=1.0\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Ekernel='rbf'\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Edegree=3\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Egamma=0.0\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Ecoef0=0.0\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Eshrinking=True\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Eprobability=False\u003C\u002Fem\u003E,\u003Cem\u003Etol=0.001\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Ecache_size=200\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Eclass_weight=None\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Everbose=False\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Emax_iter=-1\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, \u003Cem\u003Erandom_state=None\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cbig\u003E)\u003C\u002Fbig\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI am going to discuss about some important parameters having higher impact on model performance, &#8220;kernel&#8221;, &#8220;gamma&#8221; and &#8220;C&#8221;.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Ekernel\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: We have already discussed about it. Here, we have various options available with kernel like, &#8220;linear&#8221;, &#8220;rbf&#8221;,&#8221;poly&#8221; and others (default value is &#8220;rbf&#8221;).  Here &#8220;rbf&#8221; and &#8220;poly&#8221; are useful for non-linear hyper-plane. Let&#8217;s look at the example, where we&#8217;ve used linear kernel on two feature of iris data set to classify their class.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExample: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EHave linear kernel\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport numpy as np\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\nfrom sklearn import svm, datasets\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E# import some data to play with\r\niris = datasets.load_iris()\r\nX = iris.data[:, :2] # we only take the first two features. We could\r\n # avoid this ugly slicing by using a two-dim dataset\r\ny = iris.target\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E# we create an instance of SVM and fit out data. We do not scale our\r\n# data since we want to plot the support vectors\r\nC = 1.0 # SVM regularization parameter\r\nsvc = svm.SVC(kernel='linear', C=1,gamma=0).fit(X, y)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E# create a mesh to plot in\r\nx_min, x_max = X[:, 0].min() - 1, X[:, 0].max() + 1\r\ny_min, y_max = X[:, 1].min() - 1, X[:, 1].max() + 1\r\nh = (x_max \u002F x_min)\u002F100\r\nxx, yy = np.meshgrid(np.arange(x_min, x_max, h),\r\n np.arange(y_min, y_max, h))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.subplot(1, 1, 1)\r\nZ = svc.predict(np.c_[xx.ravel(), yy.ravel()])\r\nZ = Z.reshape(xx.shape)\r\nplt.contourf(xx, yy, Z, cmap=plt.cm.Paired, alpha=0.8)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.scatter(X[:, 0], X[:, 1], c=y, cmap=plt.cm.Paired)\r\nplt.xlabel('Sepal length')\r\nplt.ylabel('Sepal width')\r\nplt.xlim(xx.min(), xx.max())\r\nplt.title('SVC with linear kernel')\r\nplt.show()\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_111.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20626 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_111.png\" alt=\"SVM_11\" width=\"362\" height=\"278\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_111.png 579w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_111-300x231.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_111-83x63.png 83w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 362px) 100vw, 362px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExample: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EHave rbf kernel\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChange the kernel type to rbf in below line and look at the impact.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Esvc = svm.SVC(kernel='rbf', C=1,gamma=0).fit(X, y)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_12.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20627 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_12.png\" alt=\"SVM_12\" width=\"387\" height=\"309\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_12.png 564w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_12-300x239.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 387px) 100vw, 387px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EI would suggest you to go for linear kernel if you have large number of features (&gt;1000) because it is more likely that the data is linearly separable in high dimensional space. Also, you can RBF but do not forget to cross validate for its parameters as to avoid over-fitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Egamma\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: Kernel coefficient for ‘rbf’, ‘poly’ and ‘sigmoid’. Higher the value of gamma, will try to exact fit the as per training data set i.e. generalization error and cause over-fitting problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExample: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003ELet&#8217;s difference if we have gamma different gamma values like 0, 10 or 100.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Esvc = svm.SVC(kernel='rbf', C=1,gamma=0).fit(X, y)\r\n\r\n\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_15.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20628 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_15.png\" alt=\"SVM_15\" width=\"922\" height=\"278\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_15.png 922w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_15-300x90.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_15-850x256.png 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 922px) 100vw, 922px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EC: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EPenalty parameter C of the error term. It also controls the trade off between smooth decision boundary and classifying the training points correctly.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_18.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20629 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_18.png\" alt=\"SVM_18\" width=\"916\" height=\"270\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_18.png 916w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_18-300x88.png 300w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_18-850x251.png 850w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 916px) 100vw, 916px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe should always look at the cross validation score to have effective combination of these parameters and avoid over-fitting.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn R, SVMs can be tuned in a similar fashion as they are in Python. Mentioned below are the respective parameters for e1071 package:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe kernel parameter can be tuned to take &#8220;Linear&#8221;,&#8221;Poly&#8221;,&#8221;rbf&#8221; etc.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe gamma value can be tuned by setting the &#8220;Gamma&#8221; parameter.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EThe C value in Python is tuned by the &#8220;Cost&#8221; parameter in R.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPros and Cons associated with SVM\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EPros:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt works really well with clear margin of separation\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is effective in high dimensional spaces.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is effective in cases where number of dimensions is greater than the number of samples.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt uses a subset of training points in the decision function (called support vectors), so it is also memory efficient.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECons:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt doesn&#8217;t perform well, when we have large data set because the required training time is higher\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIt also doesn&#8217;t perform very well, when the data set has more noise i.e. target classes are overlapping\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ESVM doesn&#8217;t directly provide probability estimates, these are calculated using an expensive five-fold cross-validation. It is related SVC method of Python scikit-learn library.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EPractice Problem\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFind right additional feature to have a hyper-plane for segregating the classes in below snapshot:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_19.png\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-20634 \" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_19.png\" alt=\"SVM_19\" width=\"340\" height=\"310\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_19.png 422w, https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2015\u002F10\u002FSVM_19-300x274.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 340px) 100vw, 340px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnswer the variable name in the comments section below. I&#8217;ll shall then reveal the answer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EIn this article, we looked at the machine learning algorithm, Support Vector Machine in detail.  I discussed its concept of working, process of implementation in python, the tricks to make the model efficient by tuning its parameters, Pros and Cons, and finally a problem to solve. I would suggest you to use SVM and analyse the power of this model by tuning the parameters. I also want to hear your experience with SVM, how have you tuned parameters to avoid over-fitting and reduce the training time?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align: justify;\"\u003EDid you find this article helpful? They are transparent, easy to understand, robust in …","source_description":"\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EDecision Trees are one of the most respected algorithm in machine learning and data science. They are transparent, easy to understand, robust in nature and widely applicable. You can actually see what the algorithm is doing and what steps does it perform to get to a solution. This trait is particularly important in business context when it comes to explaining a decision to stakeholders.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThis skill test was specially designed for you to test your knowledge on decision tree techniques. More than 750 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-decision-trees\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F04\u002Fcomplete-tutorial-tree-based-modeling-scratch-in-python\u002F\"\u003EA Complete Tutorial on Tree Based Modeling from Scratch (in R &amp; Python)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fdetailed-solutions-for-skilltest-tree-based-algorithms\u002F\"\u003E45 questions to test Data Scientists on Tree Based Algorithms (Decision tree, Random Forests, XGBoost)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about bagging trees?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn bagging trees, individual trees are independent of each other\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EBagging is the method for improving the performance by aggregating the results of weak learners\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth options are true. In Bagging, each individual trees are independent of each other because they consider different subset of features and samples.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about boosting trees?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn boosting trees, individual weak learners are independent of each other\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIt is the method for improving the performance by aggregating the results of weak learners\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIn boosting tree individual weak learners are not independent of each other because each tree correct the results of previous tree. Bagging and boosting both can be consider as improving the base learners results.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E3) Which of the following is\u002Fare true about Random Forest and Gradient Boosting ensemble methods?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth methods can be used for classification task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest is use for classification whereas Gradient Boosting is use for regression task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest is use for regression whereas Gradient Boosting is use for Classification task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth methods can be used for regression task\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) 1 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth algorithms are design for classification as well as regression task.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4) In Random forest you can generate hundreds of trees (say T1, T2 &#8230;..Tn) and then aggregate the results of these tree. Which of the following is true about individual(Tk) tree in Random Forest?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on a subset of the features\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on all the features\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on a subset of observations\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIndividual tree is built on full set of observations\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom forest is based on bagging concept, that consider faction of sample and faction of feature for building the individual trees.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E5) Which of the following is true about “max_depth” hyperparameter in Gradient Boosting?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELower is better parameter in case of same validation accuracy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EHigher is better parameter in case of same validation accuracy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the value of max_depth may overfit the data\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the value of max_depth may underfit the data\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIncrease the depth from the certain value of depth may overfit the data and for 2 depth values validation accuracies are same we always prefer the small depth in final model building.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) Which of the following algorithm doesn&#8217;t uses learning Rate as of one of its hyperparameter?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EGradient Boosting\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EExtra Trees\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EAdaBoost\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 2 and 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ERandom Forest and Extra Trees don&#8217;t have learning rate as a hyperparameter.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E7) Which of the following algorithm would you take into the consideration in your final model building on the basis of performance?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have given the following graph which shows the ROC curve for two different classification algorithms such as Random Forest(Red) and Logistic Regression(Blue)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca case?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you want to apply AdaBoost algorithm on Data D which has T observations. You set half the data for training and half for testing initially. Now you want to increase the number of data points for training T1, T2 &#8230; Tn where T1 &lt; T2&#8230;. Tn-1 &lt; Tn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The difference between training error and test error increases as number of observations increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The difference between training error and test error decreases as number of observations increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The difference between training error and test error will not change\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of These\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EAs we have more and more data, training error increases and testing error de-creases. And they all converge to the true error.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) In random forest or gradient boosting algorithms, features can be of any type. For example, it can be a continuous feature or a categorical feature. Which of the following option is true when you consider these types of features?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Only Random forest algorithm handles real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Only Gradient boosting algorithm handles real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both algorithms can handle real valued attributes by discretizing them\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth can handle real valued features.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Which of the following algorithm are not an example of ensemble learning algorithm?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Random Forest\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Adaboost\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Extra Trees\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Gradient Boosting\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) Decision Trees\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EDecision trees doesn’t aggregate the results of multiple trees so it is not an ensemble algorithm.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003E11) Suppose you are using a bagging based algorithm say a RandomForest in model building. Which of the following can be true?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ENumber of tree should be as large as possible\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EYou will have interpretability after using RandomForest\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESince Random Forest aggregate the result of different weak learners, If It is possible we would want more number of trees in model building.  Random Forest is a black box model you will lose interpretability after using it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EContext 12-15 \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EConsider the following figure for answering the next few questions. In the figure, X1 and X2 are the two features and the data point is represented by dots (-1 is negative class and +1 is a positive class). And you first split the data based on feature X1(say splitting point is x11) which is shown in the figure using vertical line. Every value less than x11 will be predicted as positive class and greater than x will be predicted as negative class.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 4\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EOnly one observation is misclassified, one negative class is showing at the left side of vertical line which will be predicting as a positive class.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E13) Which of the following splitting point on feature x1 will classify the data correctly?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Greater than x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Less than x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Equal to x11\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan accuracy.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E14) If you consider only feature X2 for splitting. Can you now perfectly separate the positive class from negative class for any one split on X2?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Yes\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) No\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EIt is also not possible.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Now consider only one splitting on both (one on X1 and one on X2) feature. You can split both features at any point. Would you be able to classify all data points correctly?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EYou won&#8217;t find such case because you can get minimum 1 misclassification.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EContext 16-17 \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose, you are working on a binary classification problem with 3 input features. And you chose to apply a bagging algorithm(X) on this data. You chose max_features = 2 and the n_estimators =3. Now, Think that each estimators have 70% accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: Algorithm X is aggregating the results of individual estimators based on maximum voting\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) What will be the maximum accuracy you can get?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 70%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 80%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 90%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 100%\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERefer below table for models M1, M2 and
