In the below image, select the attribute which has the highest information gain?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F14115929\u002F19_Image.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-37484 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F14115929\u002F19_Image.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"555\" height=\"406\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F14115929\u002F19_Image.jpg 555w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F14115929\u002F19_Image-300x219.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 555px) 100vw, 555px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) Outlook\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Humidity\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Windy\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Temperature\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EInformation gain increases with the average purity of subsets. trees?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn each stage, introduce a new regression tree to compensate the shortcomings of existing model\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe can use gradient decent method for minimize the loss function\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) True-False: The bagging is suitable for high variance low bias models?\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe bagging is suitable for high variance low bias models or you can say for complex models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E21) Which of the following is true when you choose fraction of observations for building the base learners in tree based algorithm?\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Decrease the fraction of samples to build a base learners will result in decrease in variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Decrease the fraction of samples to build a base learners will result in increase in variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Increase the fraction of samples to build a base learners will result in decrease in variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Increase the fraction of samples to build a base learners will result in Increase in variance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: self explanatory\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EContext 22-23\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose, you are building a Gradient Boosting model on data, which has millions of observations and 1000&#8217;s of features. Before building the model you want to consider the difference parameter setting for time measurement.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E22) Consider the hyperparameter &#8220;number of trees&#8221; and arrange the options in terms of time taken by each hyperparameter for building the Gradient Boosting model?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: remaining hyperparameters are same\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ENumber of trees = 100\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ENumber of trees = 500\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ENumber of trees = 1000\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1~2~3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1&lt;2&lt;3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EC) 1&gt;2&gt;3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EThe time taken by building 1000 trees is maximum and time taken by building the 100 trees is minimum which is given in solution B\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) Now, Consider the learning rate hyperparameter and arrange the options in terms of time taken by each hyperparameter for building the Gradient boosting model?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ENote: Remaining hyperparameters are same\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E1. learning rate = 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n2. learning rate = 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n3. learning rate = 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1~2~3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1&lt;2&lt;3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EC) 1&gt;2&gt;3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ESince learning rate doesn’t affect time so all learning rates would take equal time.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E24) In greadient boosting it is important use learning rate to get optimum output. Which of the following is true abut choosing the learning rate?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Learning rate should be as high as possible\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Learning Rate should be as low as possible\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Learning Rate should be low but it should not be very low\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Learning rate should be high but it should not be very high\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003ELearning rate should be low but it should not be very low otherwise algorithm will take so long to finish the training because you need to increase the number trees.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) [True or False] Cross validation can be used to select the number of iterations in boosting; this procedure may help reduce overfitting.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E26) When you use the boosting algorithm you always consider the weak learners. Which of the following is the main reason for having weak learners?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ETo prevent overfitting\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003ETo prevent under fitting\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003ETo prevent overfitting, since the complexity of the overall learner increases at each step. Starting with weak learners implies the final classifier will be less likely to overfit.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E27) To apply bagging to regression trees which of the following is\u002Fare true in such case?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe build the N regression with N bootstrap sample\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe take the average the of N regression tree\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EEach tree has a high variance with low bias\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 1,2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EAll of the options are correct and self explanatory\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E28) How to select best hyperparameters in tree based models?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Measure performance over training data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Measure performance over validation data\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Both of these\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EWe always consider the validation results to compare with the test result.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E29) In which of the following scenario a gain ratio is preferred over Information Gain?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) When a categorical variable has very large number of category\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) When a categorical variable has very small number of category\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Number of categories is the not the reason\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EWhen high cardinality problems, gain ratio is preferred over Information Gain technique.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E30) Suppose you have given the following scenario for training and validation error for Gradient Boosting. Which of the following hyper parameter would you choose in such case?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ctable border=\"2\" Both of them are simple to understand, easy to explain and perfect to demonstrate to people. Interestingly, we had skill tests for both these algorithms last month.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you are new to machine learning, make sure you test yourself on understanding of both of these algorithms. They are simplistic, but immensely powerful and used extensively in industry.  This skill test will help you test yourself on k-Nearest Neighbours. It  is specially designed for you to test your knowledge on kNN and its applications.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EMore than 650 people registered for the test. If you are one of those who missed out on this skill test, here are the questions and solutions. Here is the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-k-nearest-neighbor-knn\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Eleaderboard\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the participants who took the test.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EHelpful Resources\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHere are some resources to get in depth knowledge in the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cul\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2015\u002F08\u002Fcommon-machine-learning-algorithms\u002F\"\u003EEssentials of Machine Learning Algorithms (with Python and R Codes)Simple Guide to Logistic Regression in R\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2014\u002F10\u002Fintroduction-k-neighbours-algorithm-clustering\u002F\"\u003EIntroduction to k-nearest neighbors : Simplified\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ESkill test Questions and Answers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1) [True or False] k-NN algorithm does more computation on test time rather than train time.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe training phase of the algorithm consists only of storing the feature vectors and class labels of the training samples.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the testing phase, a test point is classified by assigning the label which are most frequent among the \u003Cem\u003Ek\u003C\u002Fem\u003E training samples nearest to that query point &#8211; hence higher computation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2) In the image below, which would be the best value for k assuming that the algorithm you are using is k-Nearest Neighbor.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" href=https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F01195427\u002FPic21.jpg\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-37862 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F08\u002F02144010\u002Ftraining-error_11.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"641\" height=\"319\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003EA) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 10\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 20\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD 50 \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EValidation error is the least when the value of k is 10. So it is best to use this value of k\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3) Which of the following distance metric can not be used in k-NN?\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) Manhattan\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Minkowski\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Tanimoto\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) Jaccard\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) Mahalanobis\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nF) All can be used \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: F\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll of these distance metric can be used as a distance metric for k-NN.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E4) Which of the following option is true about k-NN algorithm?\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) It can be used for classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) It can be used for regression\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) It can be used in both classification and regression \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWe can also use k-NN for regression problems. In this case the prediction can be based on the mean or the median of the k-most similar instances.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cstrong\u003E5) Which of the following statement is true about k-NN algorithm?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003Ek-NN performs much better if all of the data have the same scale\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003Ek-NN works well with a small number of input variables (p), but struggles when the number of inputs is very large\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003Ek-NN makes no assumptions about the functional form of the problem being solved\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Only 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) All of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe above mentioned statements are assumptions of kNN algorithm\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6) Which of the following machine learning algorithm can be used for imputing missing values of both categorical and continuous variables?\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) K-NN\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) Linear Regression\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) categorical and continuous variables.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cb\u003E7) Which of the following is true about Manhattan distance?\u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) It can be used for continuous variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) It can be used for categorical variables\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) It can be used for categorical as well as continuous\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EManhattan Distance is designed for calculating the distance between real valued features.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cstrong\u003E8) Which of the following distance measure do we use in case of categorical variables in k-NN?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli Distance\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EManhattan Distance\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) 2 and 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nF) 1,2 and 3\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth Euclidean and Manhattan distances are used in case of continuous variables, whereas hamming distance is used in case of categorical variable.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E9) Which of the following will be Euclidean Distance between the two data point A(1,3) and B(2,3)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 8\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003Esqrt( (1-2)^2 + (3-3)^2) = sqrt(1^2 + 0^2) = 1\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E10) Which of the following will be Manhattan Distance between the two data point A(1,3) and B(2,3)?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 4\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 8\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003Esqrt( mod((1-2)) + out cross validation accuracy for k=5?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 2\u002F14\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 4\u002F14\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 6\u002F14\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) 8\u002F14\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nE) None of the above\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 5-NN we will have  10\u002F14 leave one out cross validation accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E15) Which of the following will be true about k in k-NN in terms of Bias?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) When you increase the k the bias will be increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) When you decrease the k the bias will be increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003Elarge K means simple model, simple model always condider as high bias\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E16) Which of the following will be true about k in k-NN in terms of variance?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) When you increase the k the variance will increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) When you decrease the k the variance will increases\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: B\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESimple model will be consider as less variance model\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E17) The following two distances(Eucludean Distance and Manhattan Distance) have given to you which generally we used in K-NN algorithm. These distance are between two points A(x1,y1) and B(x2,Y2).\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EYour task is to tag the both distance by seeing the following two graphs. Which of the following option is true about below graph ?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ccenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Ca rel=\"lightbox\" Which of the following option would you consider to handle such problem?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EDimensionality Reduction\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EFeature selection\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Standard\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\" style=\"font-family: 'Abyssinica SIL';\"\u003EIn such case you can use either dimensionality reduction algorithm or the feature selection algorithm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E20) Below are two statements given. Which of the following will be true both statements?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003Ek-NN is a memory-based approach is that the classifier immediately adapts as we collect new training data.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EThe computational complexity for classifying new samples grows linearly with the number of samples in the training dataset in the worst-case scenario.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp class=\"Textbody\"\u003E\u003Cspan lang=\"EN-IN\"\u003EBoth are true and and 3 right), Now your task is to find out the value of k in k-NN in each image where k1 is for 1\u003Csup\u003Est\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E, k2 is for 2\u003Csup\u003End\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E and k3 is for \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) k1 &gt; k2&gt; k3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) k1&lt;k2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) k1 = k2 = k3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fcenter\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 3\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) accuracy. You can try this out yourself.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E23) A company has build a kNN classifier that gets 100% accuracy on training data. When they deployed this model on client side it has been found that the model is not at all accurate. Which of the following thing might gone wrong? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ENote: Model has successfully deployed and no technical issues are found at client side except the model performance\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nA) It is probably a overfitted model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) It is probably a underfitted model\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Can&#8217;t say\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIn an overfitted module, it seems to be performing well on training data, but it is not generalized enough to give the same results on a new data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E24) You have given the following 2 statements, find which of these option is\u002Fare true in case of k-NN?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn case of very large value of k, we may include points from other classes into the neighborhood.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EIn case of too small value of k the algorithm is very sensitive to noise\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the options are true and are self explanatory.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E25) Which of the following statements is true for k-NN classifiers?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The classification accuracy is better with larger values of k\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The decision boundary is smoother with smaller values of k\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) The decision boundary is linear\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) k-NN does not require an explicit training step\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: D\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption A: This is not always true. You have to ensure that the value of k is not too high or not too low.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption B: This statement is not true. The decision boundary can be a bit jagged\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption C: Same as option B\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EOption D: This statement is true\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E26) True-False: It is possible to construct a 2-NN classifier by using the 1-NN classifier?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) TRUE\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) FALSE\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can implement a 2-NN classifier by ensembling 1-NN classifiers\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E27) In k-NN what will happen when you increase\u002Fdecrease the value of k?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) The boundary becomes smoother with increasing value of K\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) The boundary becomes smoother with decreasing value of K\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) Smoothness of boundary doesn&#8217;t dependent on value of K\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe decision boundary would become smoother by increasing the value of K\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E28) Following are the two statements given for k-NN algorthm, which of the statement(s)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003Eis\u002Fare true?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Col\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EWe can choose optimal value of k with the help of cross validation\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003Cli\u003EEuclidean distance treats each feature as equally important\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1 and 2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth the statements are true\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EContext 29-30:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose, you have trained a k-NN model and now you want to get the prediction on test data. Before getting the prediction suppose you want to calculate the time taken by k-NN for predicting the class for test data.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nNote: Calculating the distance between 2 observation will take D time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E29) What would be the time taken by 1-NN if there are N(Very large) observations in test data?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) N*D\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) N*D*2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) (N*D)\u002F2\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: A\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe value of N is very large, so option A is correct\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E30) What would be the relation between the time taken by 1-NN,2-NN,3-NN.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA) 1-NN &gt;2-NN &gt;3-NN\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nB) 1-NN &lt; 2-NN &lt; 3-NN\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nC) 1-NN ~ 2-NN ~ 3-NN\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\nD) None of these\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESolution: C\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe training time for any value of k in kNN algorithm is the same.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EOverall Distribution\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EBelow is the distribution of the scores of the participants:\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\u003Cimg class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-38457\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F03183259\u002Fsk_knn.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"482\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F03183259\u002Fsk_knn.png 482w, https:\u002F\u002Fs3-ap-south-1.amazonaws.com\u002Fav-blog-media\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2017\u002F09\u002F03183259\u002Fsk_knn-300x178.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 482px) 100vw, 482px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EYou can access the scores \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fskilltest-logistics-regression\u002Flb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. More than 250 people participated in the skill test and the highest score obtained was 24.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEnd Notes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EI tried my best to make the solutions as comprehensive as possible but if you have any questions \u002F doubts please drop in your comments below. I would love to hear your feedback about the skill test. For more such skill tests, check out our current \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fall\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehackathons\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Eengage,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener I have worked for various multi-national Insurance companies in last 7 years."}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}}],"deep-learning":[{"id":"d48cd5cc-2e7c-4f35-8d93-15e360ad6f52","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:15.754562Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:08.969006Z","resource_id":"82456","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fartificial-neural-network-simplified-with-1-d-ecg-biomedical-data\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T11:17:00Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T11:17:00Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Artificial Neural Network simplified with 1-D ECG BioMedical Data!","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction: We have witnessed many Data Science (both Machine Learning and Deep Learning …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2166\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2166\"\u003EIntroduction:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe have witnessed many Data Science (both Machine Learning and Deep Learning techniques) algorithms in numerous application fields. But in reality, when compared to many applications, there will be very few articles or open-source available for Bio-Medical related signals. We might be wondering about, Bio-Medical field is the hottest research going on right now, and also another interesting thing is knowing about our own human body is always interesting to research when compared to other sophisticated research because it&#8217;s our own system. So in this article, we will see some interesting applications that might be helpful for beginners who can understand and explore the field of Bio-Medical Signal Processing with the help of Data Science.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F73904Common-physiological-and-physical-measures-related-to-stress-investigated-in-this-study.png\" alt=\"Biomedical data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"850\" height=\"957\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fwww.researchgate.net\u002Fpublication\u002F334352064_Review_on_psychological_stress_detection_using_biosignals\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDimensional in Data:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo before we get into the topic, we must understand basic terminology to understand &#8211; &#8216;Dimensional&#8217;. We came across, this word w.r.t to image processing technique right! and in many applications too. Let&#8217;s understand what is dimension first then what are the different dimensions in data, Dimension in mathematics can be defined as a measurement (a measure of distance, size, or any region or maybe space), and w.r.t to Physics, Dimension is defined as the magnitude of something in a particular direction. In fact, our lives are encircled by three dimensions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F342141564720746_dimensions-4.png\" alt=\"Dimensional data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"681\" height=\"330\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDifferent types of Dimensions in Data:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EI hope now we understand about dimension, let&#8217;s understand about different dimension, predominantly we have,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E0-D &#8211; Zero Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1-D- One Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2-D- Two Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3-D- Three Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4-D- Four-Dimensional\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F12132The-Geometry-of-Fourth-Dimension-and-Space-Time-Continuum-three-dimensions.jpg\" alt=\"different dimensions in data | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"1920\" height=\"887\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fdigitash.com\u002Fscience\u002Fthe-geometry-of-the-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s get some deep explanation,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EZero-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFrom the above diagram, we can easily understand that for all simple to complex diagrams, the base point is a dot, so for that DOT, we don&#8217;t have any direction or magnitude because of its characteristics. Hence DOT has no dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOne-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOk! So what do we do with the dot? let&#8217;s draw a straight line, we have two options we can draw a straight line either on the X-axis or on the Y-axis, for a mathematical point of view, let&#8217;s assume to draw the line horizontally i.e., the X-axis. So by drawing the line we can easily measure the length right? (how much cm or in m or in any measurement). So from this, we can say that this straight line is one dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETwo-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOn continuation with One-dimension, (straight line &#8211; X-axis), draw another straight line to form a square (X-axis or Y-axis irrespective with one dimensional), Square shape which has two dimensions,i.e., length (first dimension) and width (second dimension), so it has two dimensions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThree-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E Again from the continuation from Two Dimension, Square, continue to draw another straight line apart from X and Y axis, i.e., Z-axis, and make a square to cube shape. Now we have length, width as of square shape (two-dimension), and also another newly formed dimension, i.e., height (through cube), so for cube shape, we have three-dimension (by including one straight line from square)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFourth-Dimension:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E Lastly from cube shape (three-dimension), if it&#8217;s considered in the point of stationery then it&#8217;s in three-dimension when you rotate the same cube from one place to another place say for example in a slide, it moves from a stationary state to non-stationary i.e., moving (one place to another), here if you consider closely, then you can understand another measurement as time (Einstein who introduced 4th dimension &#8211; TIME from three-dimension, added time flows in the forward direction only unlike cinematically as TIME MACHINE concept &#8211; Reverse process which is practically not possible)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F63164Time-for-the-geometry-of-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum.jpg\" alt=\"dimension and space time \" width=\"1716\" height=\"954\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fdigitash.com\u002Fscience\u002Fthe-geometry-of-the-fourth-dimension-and-the-space-time-continuum\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat is Bio-Signal Processing:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe are running behind machines to do smart work in this data science or artificial intelligence-related technology. But our own human body is a natural machine and are regularly communicating about our health too and from this machine, through some natural sensors (through physiological instruments like ECG, EEG, PPG&#8230;) like heart, brain, skin, fingers and other parts, we can able get some useful information or we call it as DATA (maybe through image or through numbers) in simple. Still, our human body is a BLACK-BOX, discovering so much useful research like how we can alarm ourselves before our human body may damage any organs or life-threatening problems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo signals that we are getting from living things like from our human body, we call it as Bio-Medical signal. From that signal we are going to process and analyze it, to get some useful information related to our health we call it Biomedical Signal Processing in simple. In another word, it&#8217;s almost replacing doctors physically and from the ML\u002F DL technology we can come to know whether we are normal or abnormal, detecting some abnormalities from the Medical Image. For example, measuring heart rate, oxygen saturation, or even blood pressure at home is practically feasible today, either using a mobile phone (high-end Samsung or iPhone users) or using some low-cost special gadgets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome important Bio-Signals:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E1. Electrocardiogram &#8211; Heart\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E2. Electromyography &#8211; Skeletal muscles\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E3. Electroencephalography &#8211; Brain\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E4. Electrooculography &#8211; Corneo-Retinal (Eye)\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E5. Electroretinography &#8211; Retina\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E6. Electrogastrogram &#8211; Stomach\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E7. Phonocardiogram &#8211; Plot of high-fidelity recording of the sounds and murmurs made by the heart\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E8. Photoplethysmography &#8211; Blood volume changes in the microvascular bed of tissue and many more&#8230;\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EElectroCardioGram:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EECG is the abbreviated term for an electrocardiogram, which means it is used to record the electrical activity in simple working conditions of our heart from different perspectives or angles we call it technically. For most of them, if we say about ECG, they visualize the spikes, some people recognize it as PQRST-U waveform. To be simple our whole life is closely related to this PQRST-U rhythm only. There are so many patterns that occur in this rhythm and from that, if we monitored properly we can save most of our life from many deadly diseases too. As ECG signal has some regular pattern that we visually see through a monitor or get from electrodes, if some person is going to get heart attack let us consider, through some pattern change from the regular one we can easily find out well in advance from ECG, so that we can take some precautionary method either by taking some medication or admit in hospital.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F64600Most-common-waveform-of-the-classical-ECG-curve.png\" alt=\"Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"850\" height=\"493\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fwww.researchgate.net\u002Ffigure\u002FMost-common-waveform-of-the-classical-ECG-curve_fig1_325056456\u002Fdownload\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESome of the terms are explained as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EP Waves &#8211; Atrial Depolarization (electrical shift between negative and positive ions)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EPR Interval &#8211; Start of the P wave and ends at the beginning of the Q wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EQRS Complex &#8211; Ventricle Depolarization\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EST-Segment &#8211; Starts at the end of the S wave and ends at the beginning of the T wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ET Wave- Ventricular Repolarization\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ERR Interval &#8211; Between QRS complex\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EQT Interval &#8211; Starts at the beginning of QRS complex and ends at T wave\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EOpen-Source for ECG Database:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are many open sources available for collecting ECG real data. But among the most famous database is \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fphysionet.org\u002F \u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003EHere you can get efficient raw signals to work in ECG-based applications.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EArtificial Neural Network:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe discussed already Artificial Neural Network (ANN) in detail in the following article with python code. Please find the link for better understanding, (\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fpreview\u002Flink\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F06\u002Fartificial-neural-networks-better-understanding\u002F\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EANN &#8211; ECG Python Code:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDataset: \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.kaggle.com\u002Fshayanfazeli\u002Fheartbeat\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#importing some basic libraries\r\nimport numpy as np\r\nimport pandas as pd\r\nimport seaborn as sns\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\nfrom sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split\r\nfrom imblearn.over_sampling import SMOTE\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#importing datasets\r\nnormal = pd.read_csv('ptbdb_normal.csv')\r\nabnormal = pd.read_csv('ptbdb_abnormal.csv')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing normal dataset\r\nnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing abnormal dataset\r\nabnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#dimenion for normal\r\nnormal.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#dimension for abnormal\r\nabnormal.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#changing the random column names to sequential - normal\r\n#as we have some numbers name as columns we need to change that to numbers as\r\nfor normals in normal:\r\n    normal.columns = list(range(len(normal.columns)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing edited columns for normal data\r\nnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#changing the random column names to sequential - abnormal\r\n#as we have some numbers name as columns we need to change that to numbers as\r\nfor abnormals in abnormal:\r\n    abnormal.columns = list(range(len(abnormal.columns)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing edited columns for abnormal data\r\nabnormal.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#combining two data into one\r\n#suffling the dataset and dropping the index\r\n#As when concatenating we all have arranged 0 and 1 class in order manner\r\ndataset = pd.concat([normal, abnormal], axis=0).sample(frac=1.0, random_state =0).reset_index(drop=True)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing combined dataset\r\ndataset.head()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#whole dataset size\r\ndataset.shape\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#basic info of statistics\r\ndataset.describe()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#basic information of dataset\r\ndataset.info()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#viewing the uniqueness in dataset\r\ndataset.nunique()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#skewness of the dataset\r\n#the deviation of the distribution of the data from a normal distribution\r\n#+ve mean &gt; median &gt; mode\r\n#-ve mean &lt; median &lt; mode\r\ndataset.skew()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#kurtosis of dataset\r\n#identifies whether the tails of a given distribution contain extreme values\r\n#Leptokurtic indicates a positive excess kurtosis\r\n#mesokurtic distribution shows an excess kurtosis of zero or close to zero\r\n#platykurtic distribution shows a negative excess kurtosis\r\ndataset.kurtosis()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#missing values any from the dataset\r\nprint(str('Any missing data or NaN in the dataset:'), dataset.isnull().values.any())\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#data ranges in the dataset - sample\r\nprint(\"The minimum and maximum values are {}, {}\".format(np.min(dataset.iloc[-2,:].values), np.max(dataset.iloc[-2,:].values)))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#correlation for all features in the dataset\r\ncorrelation_data =dataset.corr()\r\nprint(correlation_data)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#visulaization for correlation\r\nplt.figure(figsize=(10,7.5))\r\nsns.heatmap(correlation_data, annot=True, cmap='BrBG')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#for target value count\r\nlabel_dataset = dataset[187].value_counts()\r\nlabel_dataset\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#visualization for target label\r\nlabel_dataset.plot.bar()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#splitting dataset to dependent and independent variable\r\nX = dataset.iloc[:,:-1].values #independent values \u002F features\r\ny = dataset.iloc[:,-1].values #dependent values \u002F target\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#checking imbalance of the labels\r\nfrom collections import Counter\r\ncounter_before = Counter(y)\r\nprint(counter_before)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#applying SMOTE for imbalance\r\noversample = SMOTE()\r\nX, y = oversample.fit_resample(X, y)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#after applying SMOTE for imbalance condition\r\ncounter_after = Counter(y)\r\nprint(counter_after)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#splitting the datasets for training and testing process\r\nX_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size =0.3, random_state=42)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#size for the sets\r\nprint('size of X_train:', X_train.shape)\r\nprint('size of X_test:', X_test.shape)\r\nprint('size of y_train:', y_train.shape)\r\nprint('size of y_test:', y_test.shape)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#ANN\r\nimport tensorflow as tf\r\n# Create \u002F initialize sequential model \r\nann_model = tf.keras.models.Sequential()\r\n#Dense layer as first layer with 10 neurons, input share (187,) and and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001), input_shape=(187,)))\r\n#Dense layer as second layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Dense layer as third layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Dense layer as fourth layer with 10 neurons and leaky Relu activation\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(20, activation=tf.keras.layers.LeakyReLU(alpha=0.001)))\r\n#Softmax as last layer with two outputs\r\nann_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(2, activation='softmax'))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy'])\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model.summary()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F424591.png\" alt=\"Model summary\" width=\"602\" height=\"341\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eann_model_history = ann_model.fit(X_train, y_train, epochs=50, batch_size = 10, validation_data = (X_test, y_test))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F886242.png\" alt=\"Training\" width=\"1101\" height=\"373\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F266763.png\" alt=\"Training contd. | Artificial Neural Network simplified\" width=\"1105\" height=\"356\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['accuracy'])\r\n\r\nplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['val_accuracy'])\r\n\r\nplt.legend([\"accuracy\",\"val_accuracy\"])\r\n\r\nplt.title('Accuracy Vs Val_Accuracy')\r\n\r\nplt.xlabel('Epoch')\r\n\r\nplt.ylabel('Accuracy')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\r\n    \u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F344715.png\" alt=\"Accuracy vs validation \" width=\"466\" height=\"318\" \u002F\u003E\r\n        \r\n\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['loss'])\r\nplt.plot(ann_model_history.history['val_loss'])\r\nplt.legend([\"loss\",\"val_loss\"])\r\nplt.title('Loss Vs Val_loss')\r\nplt.xlabel('Epoch')\r\nplt.ylabel('Loss')\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F741064.png\" alt=\"loss vs val loss\" width=\"456\" height=\"313\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"0a5666e2-1778-4ffc-951a-2ab969c4a2a2","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:16.116879Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:09.271366Z","resource_id":"82471","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Funderstanding-the-basics-of-artificial-neural-network-ann\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T10:29:40Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T10:29:40Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Understanding the Basics Of Artificial Neural Network","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon INTRODUCTION In this article, I will explain to you the basics of neural …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2183\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2183\"\u003EINTRODUCTION\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this article, I will explain to you the basics of neural networks and their code. Nowadays many students just learn how to code for neural networks without understanding the core concepts behind it and how it internally works. First,  Understand what is Neural Networks?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EWhat is Neural Network?\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENeural Network is a series of algorithms that are trying to mimic the human brain and find the relationship between the sets of data. It is being used in various use-cases like in regression, classification, Image Recognition and many more.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs we have talked above that neural networks tries to mimic the human brain then there might be the difference as well as the similarity between them. Let us talk in brief about it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome major differences between them are biological neural network does parallel processing whereas the Artificial neural network does series processing also in the former one processing is slower (in millisecond) while in the latter one processing is faster (in a nanosecond).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EArchitecture Of ANN\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F210362021-07-18 (2).png\" alt=\"Architecture Of ANN 1\" width=\"1305\" height=\"669\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA neural network has many layers and each layer performs a specific function, and as the complexity of the model increases, the number of layers also increases that why it is known as the multi-layer perceptron.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe purest form of a neural network has three layers input layer, the hidden layer, and the output layer. The input layer picks up the input signals and transfers them to the next layer and finally, the output layer gives the final prediction and these neural networks have to be trained with some training data as well like machine learning algorithms before providing a particular problem. Now, let&#8217;s understand more about perceptron.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAbout Perceptron\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs discussed above multi-layered perceptron these are basically the hidden or the dense layers. They are made up of many neurons and neurons are the primary unit that works together to form perceptron. In simple words, as you can see in the above picture each circle represents neurons and a vertical combination of neurons represents perceptrons which is basically a dense layer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F708832021-07-19.png\" alt=\"About Perceptron ANN\" width=\"1296\" height=\"705\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F363503f3-4af4-479b-b3f9-2ebdbf6773fd\" alt=\"\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fintroduction-to-neural-networks-advantages-and-applications-96851bd1a207\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fintroduction-to-neural-networks-advantages-and-applications-96851bd1a207\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow in the above picture, you can see each neuron&#8217;s detailed view. Here, each neurons have some weights (in above picture w1, w2, w3) and biases and based on this computations are done as, \u003Cb\u003Ecombination = bias + weights * input\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (F = w1*x1 + w2*x2 + w3*x3) and finally activation function is applied \u003Cb\u003Eoutput = activation(combination)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E in above picture activation is sigmoid represented by      1\u002F(1 + e\u003Csup\u003E-F\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E). There are some other activation functions as well like ReLU, Leaky ReLU, tanh, and many more.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWorking Of ANN\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAt First, information is feed into the input layer which then transfers it to the hidden layers, and interconnection between these two layers assign weights to each input randomly at the initial point. and then bias is added to each input neuron and after this, the weighted sum which is a combination of weights and bias is passed through the activation function. Activation Function has the responsibility of which node to fire for feature extraction and finally output is calculated. This whole process is known as Foreward Propagation. After getting the output model to compare it with the original output and the error is known and finally, weights are updated in backward propagation to reduce the error and this process continues for a certain number of epochs (iteration). Finally, model weights get updated and prediction is done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAdvantages\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EANN has the ability to learn and model non-linear and complex relationships as many relationships between input and output are non-linear.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAfter training, ANN can infer unseen relationships from unseen data, and hence it is generalized.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUnlike many machine learning models, ANN does not have restrictions on datasets like data should be Gaussian distributed or nay other distribution.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EApplications\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are many applications of ANN. Some of them are :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EImage Preprocessing and Character Recognition.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EForecasting.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECredit rating.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EFraud Detection.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPortfolio Management.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECODING PART\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow let&#8217;s code and understand the concepts using it.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1. Understanding and Loading the datasets\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFirst Import Libraries like NumPy, pandas, and also import classes named sequential and dense from Keras library.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport numpy as np\r\nimport pandas as pd\r\nfrom keras.models import Sequential\r\nfrom keras.layers import Dense\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow here I am going to use the Pima Indians onset of diabetes dataset which is a standard machine learning dataset from the UCI Machine Learning repository and the link can be found below. This dataset tells about the patient medical record and whether they had an onset of diabetes within five years also it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EYou can download the datasets from here:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fraw.githubusercontent.com\u002Fjbrownlee\u002FDatasets\u002Fmaster\u002Fpima-indians-diabetes.data.csv\"\u003EDatasets\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow import the dataset using pandas and then let us understand more about the datasets and then split the datasets into dependent and independent variables.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edataset = pd.read_csv('pima-indians-diabetes.csv')\r\nX = dataset[:,0:8]\r\ny = dataset[:,8]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2. Defining the Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EModels in Keras are defined as a sequence of layers in which each layer is added one after another. \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EThe input should contain input features and is specified when creating the first layer with the input_dims\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E argument. Here inputs_dims will be 8.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003ENow a question arises that how can we decide the number of layers and number of neurons in each layer?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EIt is quite difficult to know how many layers we should use. Generally for this \u003Cb\u003EKeras tuner\u003C\u002Fb\u003E is used, which takes a range of layers, a range of neurons, and some activation functions. and then by permutation and combination, it tries to find which is best suited. But one disadvantage of this is it takes lots of time. You can refer to the documentation of it \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fkeras.io\u002Fkeras_tuner\u002F\"\u003EKeras Tuner\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for more details. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this example, a fully connected network with a three-layer is used which is \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Edefined using the Dense Class.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E The first argument takes the number of neurons in that layer and, and the activation\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E argument takes the activation function as an input. Here ReLU is used as an activation function in the first two layers and sigmoid in the last layer as it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel = Sequential()\r\nmodel.add(Dense(12, input_dim=8, activation='relu'))\r\nmodel.add(Dense(8, activation='relu'))\r\nmodel.add(Dense(1, activation='sigmoid'))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3. Compile Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhile compiling we must specify the loss function to calculate the errors, the optimizer for updating the weights and any metrics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this case, we will use \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E“\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ebinary_crossentropy\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E“\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E as the \u003Cstrong\u003Eloss\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument as it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere we will take \u003Cstrong\u003Eoptimizer\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E as “\u003Cstrong\u003Eadam\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E“ as it automatically tunes itself and gives good results in a wide range of problems and finally we will collect and report the classification accuracy through \u003Cstrong\u003Emetrics\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel.compile(loss='binary_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4. Fitting The Keras Model.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we will fit our model on the loaded data by calling the \u003Cstrong\u003Efit()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function on the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe training process will run for a fixed number of iterations through the dataset which is specified using the \u003Cstrong\u003Eepochs\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument. The number of dataset rows should be and are updated within each epoch, and set using the \u003Cstrong\u003Ebatch_size\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, We will run for 150 epochs and a batch size of 10.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel.fit(X, y, epochs=150, batch_size=10)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5. Evaluate Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe evaluation of the model on the dataset can be done using the \u003Cstrong\u003Eevaluate()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function. It takes two arguments i.e, input and output. It will generate a prediction for each input and output pair and collect scores, including the average loss and any metrics such as accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Cstrong\u003Eevaluate()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function will return a list with two values first one is the loss of the model and the second will be the accuracy of the model on the dataset. We are only interested in reporting the accuracy and hence we ignored the loss value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E_, accuracy = model.evaluate(X, y)\r\nprint('Accuracy: %.2f' % (accuracy*100))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6. Make Predictions\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EPrediction can be done by calling the \u003Cstrong\u003Epredict()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function on the model. Here sigmoid activation function is used on the output layer, so the predictions will be a probability in the range between 0 and 1.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Epredictions = model.predict(X)\r\nrounded = [round(x[0]) for x in predictions]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFinal Code Summary\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere we have learned how to create your first neural network model using the powerful Keras Python library for deep learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are six main steps in using Keras to create a neural network or deep learning model that are loading the data, defining the neural network in Keras after that compiling, evaluating, and finally making the predictions with the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECONCLUSION\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this article, we have understood the basic concepts of Artificial neural networks and their code. In the coding part, we have used the Pima Indians&#8217; onset of diabetes dataset. here we have understood in detail all six main steps to create neural networks. Apart from this many things have not been covered in the blogs and below I have provided the links of other blogs from which you can refer the topics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@zeeshanmulla\u002Fcost-activation-loss-function-neural-network-deep-learning-what-are-these-91167825a4de\"\u003EDifferent types of cost functions and their applications.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fan-introduction-to-gradient-descent-and-backpropagation-81648bdb19b2\"\u003EAbout Gradient Descent.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fkeras.io\u002F\"\u003EKeras Documentation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-buttons\"
