--\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"4cc87a44-b608-4050-8fff-c054570eb82e","created":"2021-07-18T02:01:39.039480Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:09.887417Z","resource_id":"82388","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Funderstanding-rnn-step-by-step-with-pytorch\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-17T14:05:59Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-17T14:05:59Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Understanding RNN Step by Step with PyTorch","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction In this article, we will learn very basic concepts of Recurrent Neural …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this article, we will learn very basic concepts of Recurrent Neural networks. So fasten your seatbelt, we are going to explore the very basic details of RNN with PyTorch.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E3 terminology for RNN:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EInput: Input to RNN\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EHidden: All hidden at last time step for all layers\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EOutput: All hidden at last layer for all time steps so that you can feed the hidden to next layer\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*afedyFSroI3YktHgwEgibg.png\" alt=\"RNN\" width=\"800\" height=\"442\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnidirectional RNN with PyTorch \u003Ci\u003EImage by Author\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the above figure we have N time steps (horizontally) and M layers vertically). We feed input at t = 0 and initially hidden to RNN cell and the output hidden then feed to the same RNN cell with next input sequence at t = 1 and we keep feeding the hidden output to the all input sequence. Implementation-wise in PyTorch, if you are new to PyTorch, I want to give you a very very useful tip, and this is really very important If you will follow I guarantee you will learn this quickly: And the tip is- \u003Cstrong\u003ECare more about the Shape\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAssume we have the following one dimension array input data (row = 7 , columns=1 )\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*GkxIOky_IrFsCMy5uJX6Ag.png\" alt=\"Data Type 1\" width=\"800\" height=\"252\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E                                                   Data Type 1 (\u003Cem\u003EImage by author)\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd we created sequential data and the label as shown above. Now we need to break this one into batches. Let’s say we take batch size = 2.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*gRpnjQyvsRwKNekl_A_nwQ.png\" alt=\"Batch1 and Batch2 RNN\" width=\"800\" height=\"178\" data-image-id=\"1*gRpnjQyvsRwKNekl_A_nwQ.png\" data-width=\"852\" data-height=\"190\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cem\u003E                                                                             Image by author\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EInput To RNN\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput data:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E RNN should have 3 dimensions. (Batch Size, Sequence Length and Input Dimension)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBatch\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Cstrong\u003ESize\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is the number of samples we send to the model at a time. In this example, we have batch size = 2 but you can take it 4, 8,16, 32, 64 etc depends on the memory (basically in \u003Cstrong\u003E2’s power)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESequence Length \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the length of the sequence of input data (time step:0,1,2…N), the RNN learn the sequential pattern in the dataset. Here the grey colour part is sequence length so our sequence length = 3.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have share market data on a daily basis (frequency = 1day) and you want that the network to learn the sequence of 30 days of data. So your sequence length will be 30.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Dimension or Input Size \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the number of features or dimensions you are using in your data set. In this case, it is one (Columns\u002F Features). Suppose you have share market data with the following features: High, Low, Open and Close and you want to predict Close. In this case, you have input dimension = 4: High, Low, Open and Close. We will see the input dimension in more detail.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPyTorch takes input in two Shape :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Type 1:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Sequence Length, Batch Size, Input Dimension\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Type 2:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Batch Size, Sequence Length, Input Dimension\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we choose Input type 1 our shape will be = 3, 2, 1\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we choose Input type 2 our shape will be = 2, 3, 1\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESeparate out the labels from input data because we only feed input sequences to the model, and then we will explore both of the Input shapes in detail. So we should move towards implementation. First I created a custom Dataset class that returns input sequences and labels. Here the input is a float array and seq_len is window size or the sequence length of input data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eclass MyDaatset(Dataset):\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E    def __init__(self, input, seq_len):\r\n        self.input = input\r\n        self.seq_len = seq_len\r\n    def __getitem__(self, item):\r\n        return input[item:item + self.seq_len], input[item + self.seq_len]\r\n    def __len__(self):\r\n        return len(self.input) - self.seq_len\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDefine sequence from 1 to 7 and convert it to PyTorch tensor\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Einput = np.arange(1,8).reshape(-1,1)\r\ninput = torch.tensor(input, dtype=torch.float)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow we can call MyDataset class to get the data\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eds = MyDaatset(input, 3)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs we have taken batch size = 2\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edl = DataLoader(ds, batch_size=2)\r\nfor inp, label in dl:\r\n    print(inp.numpy())\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1.]\r\n  [2.]\r\n  [3.]]\r\n [[2.]\r\n  [3.]\r\n  [4.]]]\r\n[[[3.]\r\n  [4.]\r\n  [5.]]\r\n [[4.]\r\n  [5.]\r\n  [6.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003EIf you observe carefully the very first dimension is 2 which is the batch size, next is 3 which is sequence length and the last one is 1 your feature or input dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we have shapes as 2, 3, 1 (BS, SeqLen, Input Dim).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have 2 input features for example feature 1 and feature 2\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*bTePppw267PduIgSiF2n5w.png\" data-image-id=\"1*bTePppw267PduIgSiF2n5w.png\" data-width=\"984\" data-height=\"107\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E                                                                           \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E   Data Type 2\u003Cstrong\u003E (\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EImage by author)\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThen the input data will look like below. the only thing is the third dimension changed to 2 (2 is the number of features).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1. 11.]\r\n  [2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]]\r\n [[2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]]\r\n[[[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]]\r\n [[4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]\r\n  [6.16.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUp to this point, we have discussed Input type 2: of shape (Batch Size, Sequence Length, Input Dimension). If we want to change this into Input type 1 we need to permute the input. To achieve this just switch batch dimension with sequence dimension in the input data, like below\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Einp.permute(1,0,2) # switch dimension 0 and dimension 1\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1. 11.]\r\n  [2. 12.]]\r\n [[2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]]\r\n [[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]]\r\n[[[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]\r\n [[4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]]\r\n [[5. 15.]\r\n  [6.16.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf you notice now the first dimension is 3, not 2, and it is our sequence length. And the second dimension is 2 which is batch size. And the third dimension is 2 which is the input dimension\u002F features. And our input shape is = (3, 2, 2) which is input type 1. If you are confusing a little bit then spend some time on this image-\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*x8xX-EUDJpFDkGF8aLIvLQ.png\" alt=\"RNN inputs\" width=\"689\" height=\"604\" data-image-id=\"1*x8xX-EUDJpFDkGF8aLIvLQ.png\" data-width=\"689\" data-height=\"604\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cem\u003E                                                                           Image by author\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EImplementation\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s implement our small Recurrent Neural Net class, Inherit the base class nn.Module. HL_size = hidden size we can define as 32, 64, 128 (again better in 2’s power) and input size is a number of features in our data (input dimension). Here input size is 2 for data type 2 and 1 for data type 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003EBidirectional true will make this RNN bidirectional this is very useful in many applications where the next sequences can help previous sequences in learning. If bidirectional is true the number of directions will be 2 otherwise it will be 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Ebatch_first=True means batch should be our first dimension (Input Type 2) otherwise if we do not define batch_first=True in RNN we need data in Input type 1 shape (Sequence Length, Batch Size, Input Dimension).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eclass RNNModel(torch.nn.Module):\r\n    def __init__(self, input_size, HL_size):\r\n        super(RNNModel, self).__init__()\r\n        self.rnn = torch.nn.RNN(input_size=input_size,\r\n                                hidden_size=Hidden Size(HS),\r\n                                num_layers=number of stacked RNN,\r\n                                bidirectional=True\u002FFalse,\r\n                                batch_first=True default is False)\r\n        # If you want to use output for next layer then\r\n        self.linear2 = torch.nn.Linear(#Direction * HS , Output_size)\r\n        # If you want to use hidden for next layer then\r\n        self.linear2 = torch.nn.Linear(HS , Output_size)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERNN returns output and is hidden.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EOutput\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOutput Shape:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E If we use batch_first=True, then output shape is (Batch Size, Seq Len, # Direction * Hidden Size). If we use batch_first=False, then output shape is ( Seq Len, Batch Size, No of Direction * Hidden Size)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose if we consider data type 2 as input where seq_len is 3, batch is 2, hidden size = 128 and bidirectional = False then our output shape will be: (3, 2, 1 * 128) for batch_first=False and (2, 3, 1 * 128) for batch_first=True.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHidden Shape:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E (No of Direction * num_layers, Batch Size, Hidden Size) which holds information about final hidden state. So most of the time we took hidden as an input in self.linear2.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ELinear Transformation after RNN:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E If you are doing regression or binary classification then the output_size in Linear Transformation should be 1, If you are doing multi-class classification then Output_size will be a number of classes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter __init__ you have to define forward class, this is the method of your RNN Class, which computes the hidden in the network. If you are using output (\u003Cstrong\u003Eout\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E in below code) as an input, then it means you will have hidden states for all time steps in the last layer, you need to select which time-step data you want to feed to the linear layer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edef forward(self, input):\r\n    out, hidden_ = self.rnn(input)\r\n    #out: Select which time step data you want for linear layer \r\n    out = self.linear2(out)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you want to use \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E as an input for the next layer just replace the last line with\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eout = self.linear2(hidden_)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this case suppose If you have num_layer = 2, num_direction =2 then for each batch you will have 2 * 2= 4 hidden in the first dimension of \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, as \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E shape will be (4, BS, Hidden Size). Now you can select your input for the next layer from \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_ \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E(the way you want). For example, you can use both forward and backward direction of last hidden state from you \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E like below.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*KWVy1bdL_z-06vvp2t65jg.png\" alt=\"Hidden tensors | RNN\" width=\"703\" height=\"450\" data-image-id=\"1*KWVy1bdL_z-06vvp2t65jg.png\" data-width=\"703\" data-height=\"450\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E                                                        \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E          hidden_ tensor (Image by author)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd we are done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEndNotes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat is all about RNN in PyTorch. If not clear I advise you to do practice with code I am sure you will have a better understanding.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv discretion.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n","image_url":{"full":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F72142deep-learning-vs-machine-learning-t.jpg","large":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F72142deep-learning-vs-machine-learning-t-850x421.jpg","medium":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F72142deep-learning-vs-machine-learning-t-360x206.jpg","small":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F72142deep-learning-vs-machine-learning-t-262x141.jpg","nano":"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F72142deep-learning-vs-machine-learning-t-100x72.jpg"},"categories":[{"id":"ee6ebb13-2def-4727-a21c-a1dea71c4c85","title":"Intermediate","slug":"intermediate","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"6c742415-95de-4a21-acd9-eb17e3fb259d","title":"PyTorch","slug":"pytorch","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"2b492840-0f55-4508-8508-200ab2904583","title":"Python","slug":"python-2","description":"","permalink":""},{"id":"35796ebb-ee58-49a1-bdb5-c157a85668a6","title":"Deep \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fa7bd8bf71278c039eee05d7549b7ce13?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fa7bd8bf71278c039eee05d7549b7ce13?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002Fa7bd8bf71278c039eee05d7549b7ce13?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"c3f90dc4-eeb3-4470-808d-09244014d22b","created":"2021-07-16T18:01:13.248484Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:10.110995Z","resource_id":"82349","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fconvolution-neural-network-better-understanding\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-16T12:42:37Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-16T12:42:37Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Convolution Neural Network - Better Understanding!","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction: In the world of Deep Learning (DL), there are many trending and …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EIntroduction:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn the world of Deep Learning (DL), there are many trending and advanced models are emerging, for making our life (researchers!) easy. One among them is Convolution Neural Network (CNN), in this article we are going to see in detail this model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EDeep Learning -The Evolution:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn today&#8217;s scenario, many people irrespective of their domain (degree qualification!) opt for the Data Science domain. There may be much reason but the ground reality is most of the IT giants and big organization, they are shifting towards DATA SCIENCE side with a small part (means along with the current speciality, they also include data science ) or as a full time. One of the main reasons is smartness and also its robustness irrespective of any domain. If you look into the history behind Deep Learning it is not the technology that happened before some five or ten years old. In 1943, Walter Pitts and Warren McCulloch created a computer model based on the human brain&#8217;s neural networks. They used algorithms and mathematics, called “threshold logic” to mimic the thought process. But the popularity gets faded in the middle years, you know because of two simple reasons,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. Availability of data (more and more data!)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Processor power (to run the loads and loads of data!)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F22939cnn1.png\" alt=\"deep learning \" width=\"1024\" height=\"742\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmachinelearningmastery.com\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EGeoffrey Hinton &#8211; Father of Deep Learning\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn simple terms, Deep Learning is used to mimic our very own Human Brain (On Processing! but not fully!) and to replicate, how well our human brain learns things faster and thinks with sense.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EStill need to read more about the DL approach, (\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.tango-learning.com\u002Fpost\u002Fdeep-learning-an-intuition-behind-the-technology\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003ETypes of Deep Learning:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are many different types of DL as per different sources prevailing in our internet ocean, but predominately, DL is classified as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. Artificial Neural Network (ANN)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Convolution Neural Network (CNN)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Recurrent Neural Network (RNN)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EArtificial Neural Network:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe discussed already Artificial Neural Network (ANN) in detail in the following article with python code. Please find the link for better understanding,  (\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F06\u002Fartificial-neural-networks-better-understanding\u002F\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EConvolution Neural Network &#8211; Understanding:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EBefore getting into the main topic, Convolution Neural Network (CNN). First, let us understand some basic clarity, so look into the below picture,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F638771 cnn.jpg\" alt=\"understanding Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"480\" height=\"480\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Google Image\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhat we inferred from the above diagram? Some say it as Men and some say it as Women and some say it as both!.. Because of the features that get picked by our brain while viewing the drawing. If you would easily differentiate the above picture, then view the next one, the below-mentioned picture,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F128852 cnn.jpg\" alt=\"image Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"500\" height=\"500\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Google Image\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIt&#8217;s actually a fusion of the male and female picture while viewing some thought as male and female. So above two examples illustrate to us how the brain works, that it processes certain features on these examples or whatever we see in real-life and it classifies that as such. So we are going to do the same process with Neural Network with CNN is almost very similar. It&#8217;s like how we are getting features from the above pictures, in the same way, the computers also going to process, sounds interesting right!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYann Lecun &#8211; Grandfather of Convolution Neural Network!\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EConvolution Neural Network &#8211; Layman Understanding:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs human psychology, when we sit or lie on a bed or in any position (when we are awake &#8211; condition applied!), we tend to observe and look at our surroundings with or without knowledge, our brain will be in an active state only and it keeps on processing and sometimes it keeps predicting too right!.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F28793CNN2.jpeg\" alt=\"understanding Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"1280\" height=\"960\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EJust look at the above picture, what we identified from the photo is some persons and some projects are present. After that what we analyzed are plates with some food not in particular and tumbler with water, then ID card, etc&#8230;Added in the emotional side if we observe means it&#8217;s a happy moment with friends and randomly enjoying some poses. Whatever mentioned above, are predictions by seeing the pictures,  so how is possible to predict? Then how you can find the objects and emotion predictions? Our eyes and our brain work in perfect harmony to create such beautiful visual experiences. The system which makes this possible for us is the eye, our visual pathway, and the visual cortex inside our brain.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F59628cnn3.png\" alt=\"visual \" width=\"900\" height=\"640\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: http:\u002F\u002Fmriquestions.com\u002Fvisual.html\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELights and colours on the retina are captured in our eyes. These signals cross the receptors of the retina to the optical nerve and are transferred to the brain for this information to be meaningful. The eye and the visual brain are extremely complex and hierarchical. In perceiving and understanding what we around us view, the full visual path plays a vital part. It is this mechanism inside of us that allows us to understand the image above, the text of this essay, and every other work we do daily. So these processes we are doing from our childhood and so we can predict and analyze through eyes and brain coordination.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo the same process, is that possible for computers? and the simple answer is YES!. computers can SEE the world but in a different way &#8211; through numbers. Like the picture below,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F69232cnn4.png\" alt=\"pixel view images | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"512\" height=\"296\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: http:\u002F\u002Fpippin.gimp.org\u002Fimage_processing\u002Fimages\u002Fsample_grid_a_square.png\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe importance of layers of neurons arranged in each algorithm is, each layer concentrates each pattern and its importance like firstly it observes simple patterns such as lines, curves, then some complex patterns like texts, objects, and face and more complex patterns present in the image or whatever inputs that we are analyzing. This process is almost like a human&#8217;s point of view when we are randomly visualizing or seeing anything our brain analyzes any input like this only but in a matter of very few seconds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo there are various steps to achieve this CNN algorithm, they are as follows,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. Convolution layer\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Activation function (ReLu layer)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Pooling\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4. Flattening\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5. Full connection\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EOn the whole, the below animation will explain how CNN works,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F82370cnn1.gif\" alt=\"neural network\" width=\"1500\" height=\"900\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fconvolutional-neural-network-cnn-and-its-application-all-u-need-to-know-f29c1d51b3e5\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Eanother interesting visualization,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F95577cnn2.gif\" alt=\"visualizing Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"660\" height=\"371\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fconvolutional-neural-network-cnn-and-its-application-all-u-need-to-know-f29c1d51b3e5\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s see one by one what the steps explain or conveys,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003E1. Convolution Layer:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe most important portion or segment in the CNN algorithm. The mathematical notation of Convolution is as follows,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F50164cnn5.png\" alt=\"convolution Layer | Convolution Neural Network \" width=\"957\" height=\"212\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: superdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Ehere in the above equation, we can infer that convolution is an integration of two simple functions (f and g). We have two terms, one is our input\u002Fdataset in matrix format and another one is feature detector or kernel or filters (it will be 3*3 or 5*5 or 7*7 matrix, depends on the architecture that we are using!) when compared to the input image matrix, this matrix is smaller but we can get deeper knowledge from this kernel part only.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EConsider an input and kernel matrix as\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F18756cnn6.png\" alt=\"filter \" width=\"868\" height=\"532\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe first step in convolution function is kernel matrix shown above figure, which slides through input image as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F875\u002F1*wpbLgTW_lopZ6JtDqVByuA.gif\" alt=\"working of kernel | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"875\" height=\"510\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn a static way, we can explain the above step as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F70180cnn7.jpeg\" alt=\"working of filter | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"760\" height=\"452\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf you note clearly, the value 4 in the output matrix, which depends on the 9 values of 3*3 matrix and another importance is the value doesn&#8217;t change if any position of the value of the input matrix changes too. This is the RECEPTIVE FIELD of this output value, meaning the importance of the neuron layer to find a particular object or text or anything. Each value in the output value or matrix is sensitive to only a particular region, and hence we need to use our kernel matrix wisely depends on applications.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn a more layman way, convolution process `like,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F494\u002F1*JdJdQmxiq1NkxF2nxwIeZA.gif\" alt=\"filter process \" width=\"395\" height=\"449\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFor a change, let&#8217;s consider handwritten digits for a little more understanding through some pictures (as I believe the picture speaks 1000 words!). So here, in the below figure, I need to concentrate only horizontal lines alone, so for this with the help of kernel matrix I can get the output matrix as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F25876cnn8.png\" alt=\"handwritten digit after kernel process \" width=\"747\" height=\"340\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn the same way, if I need to concentrate with respect to the vertical lines, in the same way by using kernel matrix, I can able to get the output values as,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F14498cnn9.png\" alt=\"image\" width=\"796\" height=\"360\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo from all the explanations above, what we infer from this CONVOLUTION block, extraction of important terms, or technically we call it feature extraction. So convolution block is used to achieve feature extraction from the given dataset by avoiding other unimportant features or dimming or avoiding useless information or feature in simple.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFilters play&#8217;s an important role in transforming the data (numbers\u002Fpixels), the resultant output we call activation maps, which means regions where features specific kernel to be detected from the input data. \u003Cb\u003EDimension of feature map = Dimension of filter\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F11178fil.gif\" alt=\"animation cnn\" width=\"610\" height=\"341\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fconvolutional-neural-network-cnn-and-its-application-all-u-need-to-know-f29c1d51b3e5\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn the case of an image, convolution layer works like, because of RGB format wrt image,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F59164cnni.gif\" alt=\"RGB format\" width=\"700\" height=\"393\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage source:  https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fconvolutional-neural-network-cnn-and-its-application-all-u-need-to-know-f29c1d51b3e5\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2. Activation Function:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo once the convolution process gets over for our input dataset (sliding process!), the next important step to proceed in the CNN algorithm is the activation function.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhen comparing with a neuron-based model that is in our brains, the activation function is at the end deciding what is to be fired to the next neuron. It takes in the output signal from the previous cell and converts it into some form that can be taken as input to the next cell. It’s a non-linear transformation that we do for inputs that we receive before sending them to the next layer or neuron. AF is also known as Transfer Function. For further information about AF visit the following link (\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F06\u002Fartificial-neural-networks-better-understanding\u002F)\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELet&#8217;s consider the same example as we have seen for the handwritten digit dataset, after the convolution process, we have passed AF (ReLU), then the output will be like,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F75891cnn10.png\" alt=\"relu \" width=\"833\" height=\"673\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESo what you infer from this AF process, the output that we got from the convolution process in general one means it has some or few unwanted information, depending upon the kernel filter or matrix that we used. Here in AF, useful information is passed on to the next process. It&#8217;s just transferring the information to the next process.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3. Pooling:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWe all know the importance of swimming pool right &#8211; stress buster, if we do swimming for an hour, whatever stress we have it will be gone, in the same way, Pooling process which means it reduces the dimensionality of our matrix. The main importance of pooling is to reduce overfitting and computation in our dataset. In a layman level, pooling can be explained by,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe main importance of the pooling layer is to detect the edges, corners and in application-like images, it can be used to detect facial features like nose, eyes by using multiple filters. It&#8217;s like filtering the feature map, because we get the feature map from the convolution process, and here in pooling we are going to apply it to the filter. Mostly the size of the filter is 2*2, which means in the pooling process feature map gets reduced by the factor of 2 (in simple reduced by half of the feature map dimension), intern it reduces each value in the feature map to one quarter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIt has two main types, Max-Pooling and Avg-Pooling.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F92473a1.png\" alt=\"Pooling\" width=\"955\" height=\"344\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F49776avg.png\" alt=\"average pool | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"1390\" height=\"492\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Eand some other types of pooling are as follows, firstly will see a minimum pooling,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F67065cnn12.png\" alt=\"minimum pooling\" width=\"1308\" height=\"697\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: towardsdatascience.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003Eand lastly adaptive pooling, herein the user doesn&#8217;t need to manually define hyperparameters, it needs to define only output size, and the parameters are picked up accordingly\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn a more understanding, let&#8217;s consider a cat image in a different position as like this figure,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F63001a3.png\" alt=\"cat image | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"1300\" height=\"614\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: images. google.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe importance of the convolution layer is to find the feature extraction or location of features through feature maps. But in the above figure if I apply the convolution it may get confused because the first half of the image is in reverse position, so here comes the pooling process, apart from the reduction process it also helps in Translational Invariance (ability to ignore the position shifts).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are some important terms to be noticed in the Pooling process,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F22314stride.png\" alt=\"max pool \" width=\"853\" height=\"402\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: medium.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E1. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003EFilter Size – Describes filters size like 2*2 or 3*3 or anything\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E2. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003EStride – describes the number of steps filter takes while traversing the image\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Padding &#8211; Sometimes filter size creates a border effect in the feature map, the effect can be overcome through padding.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fiq.opengenus.org\u002Fcontent\u002Fimages\u002F2020\u002F04\u002FConvolving.gif\" alt=\"Convolving\" width=\"1170\" height=\"849\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf you notice in the above figure, the filter size is 3*3, stride size is 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E4. \u003Cb\u003EFlattening: \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo the next layer after the pooling process is flattening, here in this process, we are going to make our matrix into a single column, basically, we are taking row by row numbers and put them into a single column.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F88334f.png\" alt=\"flattening\" width=\"875\" height=\"455\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fthe-most-intuitive-and-easiest-guide-for-convolutional-neural-network-3607be47480\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd the importance of making them into a single column is simple, the next step is to feed them to the neural network for further processing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFlattening\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003Eis converting the data into a 1-dimensional array for inputting it to\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nthe next layer. We flatten the output of the convolutional layers to create a\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nsingle long feature vector. And it is connected to the final classification\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nmodel, which is called a fully connected layer.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nIn other words, we put all the pixel data in one line and make connections with\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nthe final layer. And once again. What is the final layer for? The\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nclassification of ‘the cats and dogs’ or normal and abnormal, good or bad, or\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nany classification.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E5. \u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EFull Connection \u002F Fully Connected layer: \u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ELast layer, in which each pixel or each number\u002Fpoint is considered as a separate neuron just like a NN. The last fully-connected layer will contain as many neurons as the number of classes to be predicted.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F40523a.png\" alt=\"Convolution Neural Network Architecture \" width=\"850\" height=\"269\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fthe-most-intuitive-and-easiest-guide-for-convolutional-neural-network-3607be47480\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow that we have converted our input image into a suitable form for our Multi-Level fully connected architecture, we shall flatten the image into one column vector. The flattened output is fed to a feed-forward neural network and backpropagation is applied to every iteration of training. Over a series of epochs, the model can distinguish between dominating and certain low-level features in images and classify them.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThis layer assigns random weights to the inputs and predicts a suitable label\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EApart from these blocks, there are also some special blocks used for CNN,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F84815cnn3.jpeg\" alt=\"working of cnn \" width=\"625\" height=\"295\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fanalytics-vidhya\u002Fconvolutional-neural-network-cnn-and-its-application-all-u-need-to-know-f29c1d51b3e5\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EFully Connected Output layer:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe final layer of the CNN model contains the results of the labels determined for the classification and assigns a class to the dataset (input)\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003ESoftmax\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe reason why softmax is useful is that it converts the output of the last layer in your neural network into what is essentially a probability distribution. It is mainly used to normalize neural networks output to fit between zero and one. It is used to represent the certainty “probability” in the network output.\u003Cu style=\"font-weight: bold;\"\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F29782sm.png\" alt=\"softmax\" width=\"491\" height=\"393\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fdevelopers.google.com\u002Fmachine-learning\u002Fcrash-course\u002Fmulti-class-neural-networks\u002Fsoftmax\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EDropout\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe main idea behind using dropout is simple, to avoid overfitting. The most popular regularization method is used in Neural networks. Even if we are using a different model and achieve around 90% of accuracy, by using dropout we can able to achieve around 92% of accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EDuring training time, at each iteration, a neuron is temporarily “dropped” or disabled with probability \u003Cem\u003Ep\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. This means all the inputs and outputs to this neuron will be disabled at the current iteration. The dropped-out neurons are resampled with probability p at every training step, so a dropped-out neuron at one step can be active at the next one. The hyperparameter \u003Cem\u003Ep\u003C\u002Fem\u003E is called the dropout rate and it’s typically a number around 0.5, corresponding to 50% of the neurons being dropped out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F79151do.png\" alt=\"dropout | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"875\" height=\"443\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage source: image.google.com\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAlmost all state-of-the-art deep networks now incorporate dropout. There is another very popular regularization technique called batch normalization\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003ESummary of CNN:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. Provide the data\u002Fdataset (any format of data) into the convolution layer\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Take convolution with featured kernel\u002Ffilters\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Next apply a layer, Pooling for reducing the dimensions\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4 If you need a deeper understanding add these layers repeatedly.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5. Next step is to apply to flatten for a single column\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E6. Feed into a fully connected layer\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E7. Now lastly train the model with appropriate metrics and optimizer\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003ECNN &#8211; Different Architecture Models\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EBefore getting deeper into the models, let&#8217;s understand some basic terminologies,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. \u003Cb\u003EWider \u003C\u002Fb\u003E&#8211; means more feature maps (filters) in the convolutional layers\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. \u003Cb\u003EDeeper\u003C\u002Fb\u003E &#8211; means more convolutional layers\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. \u003Cb\u003EHigh Resolution\u003C\u002Fb\u003E &#8211; means that it processes input images with larger width and depth\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n(spatial resolutions). That way the produced feature maps will have a higher\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nspatial dimensions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F33343cnn.png\" alt=\"Convolution Neural Network different models \" width=\"938\" height=\"529\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Farxiv.org\u002Fabs\u002F1905.11946\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EBased on the architecture of layers that we have seen so far with some technical terms, CNN is categorized into different models, some of them are as follows,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E1. \u003Cb\u003ELeNet-5\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (2 &#8211; Convolution layer &amp; 3 &#8211; Fully Connected layers) &#8211; 5 layers\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F1400\u002F1*aQA7LuLJ2YfozSJa0pAO2Q.png\" alt=\"lenet5 | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"977\" height=\"249\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E2. \u003Cb\u003EAlexNet\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (5 &#8211; Convolution layer &amp; 3 &#8211; Fully Connected layers) &#8211; 8 layers\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*2DT1bjmvC-U-lrL7tpj6wg.png\" alt=\"alexnet\" width=\"1251\" height=\"248\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E3.  \u003Cb\u003EVGG 16\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (13 &#8211; Convolution layer &amp; 3 &#8211; Fully Connected layers) &#8211; 16 layers\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*_vGloND6yyxFeFH5UyCDVg.png\" alt=\"vgg16\" width=\"1439\" height=\"270\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E4. \u003Cb\u003EInception V1\u003C\u002Fb\u003E &#8211; 22 layers\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*KnTe9YGNopUMiRjlEr3b8w.png\" alt=\"inception v1\" width=\"1727\" height=\"1181\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E5. \u003Cb\u003EInception V3\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*ooVUXW6BIcoRdsF7kzkMwQ.png\" alt=\"inception v3\" width=\"2000\" height=\"1515\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E6. \u003Cb\u003EResNet 50\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*zbDxCB-0QDAc4oUGVtg3xw.png\" alt=\"resnet50\" width=\"1894\" height=\"542\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E7. \u003Cb\u003EXception\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*NNsznNjzULwqvSER8k5eDg.png\" alt=\"xception\" width=\"1451\" height=\"816\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E8. \u003Cb\u003EInception V4\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*15sIUNOxqVyDPmGGqefyVw.png\" alt=\"inception v4 | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"2000\" height=\"1518\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E9. \u003Cb\u003EInception ResNet V2\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*xpb6QFQ4IknSmxmgai8w-Q.png\" alt=\"inception restnet2 | Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"2000\" height=\"1115\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E10. \u003Cb\u003EResNeXt 50\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmiro.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F2000\u002F1*HelCJiQZEuwuKakRwDdGPw.png\" alt=\"resnext50\" width=\"1896\" height=\"734\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAll the pictures are taken from \u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fillustrated-10-cnn-architectures-95d78ace614d \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E11. \u003Cb\u003ESqueeze Net\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F557481_y87bqk95D-IndWdHM_K9-g.png\" alt=\"sqeeznet\" width=\"1021\" height=\"756\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Freview-squeezenet-image-classification-e7414825581a\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E12. \u003Cb\u003EDense Net\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F95299dn1.png\" alt=\"densenet\" width=\"875\" height=\"233\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fpaper-review-densenet-densely-connected-convolutional-networks-acf9065dfefb\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E13 \u003Cb\u003EShuffle Net\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F70725sn.png\" alt=\"shufflenet\" width=\"875\" height=\"482\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002Fsyncedreview\u002Fshufflenet-an-extremely-efficient-convolutional-neural-network-for-mobile-devices-72c6f5b01651\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E14\u003Cb\u003E ENet\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F33946en.png\" alt=\"enet\" width=\"1328\" height=\"717\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fenet-a-deep-neural-architecture-for-real-time-semantic-segmentation-2baa59cf97e9\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESome of the most famous model comparisons are shown below,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F87833cnn_archi.png\" alt=\"famous Convolution Neural Network\" width=\"873\" height=\"656\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003EImage Source: https:\u002F\u002Ftheaisummer.com\u002Fcnn-architectures\u002F\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EAdvantage of CNN:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E1. Automatically detects important features without any human supervision\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Computationally efficient (Convolution and Pooling process performs parameter sharing)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Weight Sharing\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4. High Statistical efficiency\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5. Translational Invariance\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDisadvantages of CNN: \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E1. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003EClassification of Images with different Positions (different angles, different backgrounds, different lighting conditions)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E2. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003EAdversarial examples (CNN takes an image along with some noise it recognizes the image as a completely different image whereas the human visual system will identify it as the same image with the noise)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E3. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003ECoordinate Frame (Coordinate frame is basically a mental model which keeps track of the orientation and different features of an object)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4. Slower due to functions like Maxpool\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5. As several layers are functional then the training process takes lots of time if our CPU doesn&#8217;t have a good GPU\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThese drawbacks lead to the formation of the Capsule Neural Network\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EApplication of CNN:\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C!-- [if !supportLists]--\u003E1. \u003C!--[endif]--\u003EDecoding Facial Recognition\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E2. Analysing Documents\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E3. Classification\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E4. Segmentation (Organs or any anatomical structures is a fundamental Image Processing technique for Medical Image Analysis)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E5. Detection (Common task for Radiologist is to detect abnormalities with Medical Images)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cu\u003EPython Coding with CNN\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EI hope you understand some bit about CNN from the above explanation and some visualization,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E Dataset: CIFAR 10 Image Classification\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#importing basic libraries\r\n\r\nimport tensorflow as tf\r\n\r\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\r\n\r\n#importing default dataset\r\n\r\nfrom tensorflow.keras.datasets import cifar10\r\n#loading dataset\r\n\r\n# setting class names from dataset\r\n\r\nclass_names=['airplane','automobile','bird','cat','deer','dog','frog','horse','ship','truck']\r\n\r\n#loading the dataset\r\n\r\n(x_train,y_train),(x_test,y_test)=cifar10.load_data()\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n#normalizing train data\r\n\r\nx_train=x_train\u002F255.0\r\n\r\nx_train.shape\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n#normalizing test data\r\n\r\nx_test=x_test\u002F255.0\r\n\r\nx_test.shape\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n#random check dataset\r\n\r\nplt.imshow(x_test[222])\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n#Building CNN model\r\n\r\ncnn_model=tf.keras.models.Sequential()\r\n\r\n# First Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=32,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\", input_shape=[32,32,3]))\r\n\r\n# Second Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=32,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\"))\r\n\r\n# Max Pooling Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2,padding='valid'))\r\n\r\n# Third Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=64,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\"))\r\n\r\n# Fourth Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=64,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\"))\r\n\r\n# Max Pooling Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2,padding='valid'))\r\n\r\n# fifth Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=128,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\"))\r\n\r\n# Sixth Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=128,kernel_size=3,padding=\"same\", activation=\"relu\"))\r\n\r\n# Max Pooling Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2,strides=2,padding='valid'))\r\n\r\n# Flattening Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Flatten())\r\n\r\n# Droput Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dropout(0.5,noise_shape=None,seed=None))\r\n\r\n# Adding the first fully connected layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(units=128,activation='relu'))\r\n\r\n# Output Layer\r\n\r\ncnn_model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(units=10,activation='softmax'))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ecnn_model.summary()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F56799Untitled.png\" alt=\"model summary\" width=\"683\" height=\"703\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EImage Source: Author\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#Model -compiling\r\ncnn_model.compile(loss=\"sparse_categorical_crossentropy\", optimizer=\"Adam\", metrics=[\"sparse_categorical_accuracy\"])\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E#Model - training\r\ncnn_model.fit(x_train,y_train,epochs=15)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F34014Untitled1.png\" alt=\"training\" width=\"1043\" height=\"623\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E#Accuracy and loss\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Etest_loss, test_accuracy = cnn_model.evaluate(x_test, y_test)\r\n\r\nprint(\"Test accuracy: {}\".format(test_accuracy))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F77439Untitled3.png\" alt=\"\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EFor full code\u003Cb\u003E \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Fgithub.com\u002Fanandprems\u002Fcnn\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cb\u003EEndNote:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fu\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDid \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"40cc4a39-d2b2-4a18-b031-412b48e2030c","created":"2021-07-15T10:01:32.972536Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:10.434554Z","resource_id":"82290","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Fface-key-point-recognition-using-cnn\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-15T07:40:49Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-15T07:43:26Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Face Key-point Recognition Using CNN","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Overview of the project: The goal of this project is to forecast the locations …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2095\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2095\"\u003EOverview of the project:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe goal of this project is to forecast the locations of key points on facial pictures. This may be used as a component in a variety of applications, including:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFace recognition in pictures and video.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe study of facial expressions.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFor medical diagnosis, identifying dysmorphic facial symptoms.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERecognizing facial key points is a difficult topic to solve. Facial characteristics differ significantly from one person to the next, and even within a single person, there is a lot of variances owing to 3D posture, size, location, viewing angle, and lighting circumstances. While computer vision research has come a long way in tackling these issues, there are still many areas where it may be improved.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETABLE OF CONTENT:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPrerequisites\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EProcedure and programming\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUseful applications of Facial keypoint detection\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAbout Myself\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EConclusion\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIntroduction:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThe marking of important areas of the face, such as the eyes, corners of the mouth, and nose, that are relevant for a variety of tasks, such as face filters, emotion recognition, and pose recognition, using convolutional neural network and computer vision techniques to perform facial Keypoint detection.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt entails forecasting the Facial Key points coordinates for a particular face, such as nose tip, the center of eyes, and so on. To recognize facial key points, we use a Convolutional Neural Network-based model using Autoencoders. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) has a deep structure that allows them to extract high-level information and provide better precision when identifying each important point. Convolutional networks are designed to anticipate all points at the same time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F59153facefilter.png\" alt=\"face key-points \" width=\"528\" height=\"378\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESource: https:\u002F\u002Fdeveloper.qualcomm.com\u002Fsites\u002Fdefault\u002Ffiles\u002Fattachments\u002Ffacial_expression_detection-08_0.png\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EPrerequisites :\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBecause neural networks frequently require standardized pictures, they should have a constant size, with a normalized range for color ranges and coordinates, and transformed from NumPy lists and arrays to Tensors and Keras(for PyTorch). As a result, some pre-processing will be required.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003EProcedure and programming:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI am taking the Kaggle dataset to train the model, You can download it by running the API command\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Ekaggle competitions download -c facial-keypoints-detection\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EImport the NumPy and pandas library :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport numpy as np # linear algebra\r\nimport pandas as pd # data processing\r\nimport os\r\nfor directoryname, _, filenames in os.walk('\u002Fkaggle\u002Finput'):\r\n    for filename in filenames:\r\n        print(os.path.join(directoryname, filename))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAny output that you write to the current directory is stored.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe next step is to set the path for each file of training and testing data,\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Etrain_zip_path = \"..\u002Finput\u002Ffacial-keypoints-detection\u002Ftraining.zip\"\r\ntest_zip_path = \"..\u002Finput\u002Ffacial-keypoints-detection\u002Ftest.zip\"\r\nid_lookup_table = \"..\u002Finput\u002Ffacial-keypoints-detection\u002FIdLookupTable.csv\"\r\nsample_Submission = \"..\u002Finput\u002Ffacial-keypoints-detection\u002FSampleSubmission.csv\"\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-19\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-20\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-21\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s use a zip file to unzip the zip files and then load the datasets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport \u003Ca name=\"kln-23\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ezipfile\r\nwith \u003Ca name=\"kln-24\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ezipfile.ZipFile(train_zip_path,'r') as zip_ref:\r\nzip_ref.extractall('')\r\nwith \u003Ca name=\"kln-26\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ezipfile.ZipFile(test_zip_path,'r') as zip_ref:\r\nzip_ref.extractall('')\r\ntrain_df = pd.read_csv('training.csv')\r\ntest_df = pd.read_csv('test.csv')\r\nidLookupTable = pd.read_csv(id_lookup_table)\r\nsampleSumission = pd.read_csv(sample_Submission)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-30\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-31\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca name=\"kln-32\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter loading the data sets, we can view the data frames by using the pandas&#8217; library and list the head of the data set.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Etrain_df.info()\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F26676out.png\" alt=\"train data | face key-point recognition\" width=\"490\" height=\"560\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFill the Nan values and Separate and reshape input values(x_train)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E train_df.fillna(method='ffill',inplace=True)\r\n\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESeparate and reshape input values(x_train) in the training dataset :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAn array is created using an image, &#8216;keypoints&#8217;: key points will be a sample of our dataset. Our dataset will accept an optional argument transform, allowing us to perform any necessary processing on the sample.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimage_df = train_df['Image']\r\nimageArr = []\r\nfor \u003Ca name=\"kln-39\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ei in range(0,len(image_df)):\r\n     img = image_df[i].split()\r\n     img = ['0' if x == '' else x for x in img]\r\n     imageArr.append(img)\r\n x_train = np.array(imageArr,dtype='float')\r\n x_train = x_train.reshape(-1,96,96,1)\r\n print(x_train.shape)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg
