for premanand17\"}}]},{\"@type\":\"Person\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#\u002Fschema\u002Fperson\u002F1c741133b52c682349facbe46753dda5\",\"name\":\"premanand17\",\"image\":{\"@type\":\"ImageObject\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#personlogo\",\"inLanguage\":\"en-US\",\"url\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"caption\":\"premanand17\"},\"mainEntityOfPage\":{\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Fpremanand17\u002F#webpage\"}}]}\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\n\u003C!-- \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F3c5122daf126b6774be5c206dae8ad1f?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"0a5666e2-1778-4ffc-951a-2ab969c4a2a2","created":"2021-07-19T16:01:16.116879Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:09.271366Z","resource_id":"82471","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Funderstanding-the-basics-of-artificial-neural-network-ann\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-19T10:29:40Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-19T10:29:40Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Understanding the Basics Of Artificial Neural Network","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon INTRODUCTION In this article, I will explain to you the basics of neural …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb id=\"spancomment2183\" class=\"comment-highlite\" data-commentid=\"2183\"\u003EINTRODUCTION\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this article, I will explain to you the basics of neural networks and their code. Nowadays many students just learn how to code for neural networks without understanding the core concepts behind it and how it internally works. First,  Understand what is Neural Networks?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003EWhat is Neural Network?\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENeural Network is a series of algorithms that are trying to mimic the human brain and find the relationship between the sets of data. It is being used in various use-cases like in regression, classification, Image Recognition and many more.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs we have talked above that neural networks tries to mimic the human brain then there might be the difference as well as the similarity between them. Let us talk in brief about it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome major differences between them are biological neural network does parallel processing whereas the Artificial neural network does series processing also in the former one processing is slower (in millisecond) while in the latter one processing is faster (in a nanosecond).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EArchitecture Of ANN\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F210362021-07-18 (2).png\" alt=\"Architecture Of ANN 1\" width=\"1305\" height=\"669\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Ftechvidvan.com\u002Ftutorials\u002Fartificial-neural-network\u002F\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA neural network has many layers and each layer performs a specific function, and as the complexity of the model increases, the number of layers also increases that why it is known as the multi-layer perceptron.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe purest form of a neural network has three layers input layer, the hidden layer, and the output layer. The input layer picks up the input signals and transfers them to the next layer and finally, the output layer gives the final prediction and these neural networks have to be trained with some training data as well like machine learning algorithms before providing a particular problem. Now, let&#8217;s understand more about perceptron.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAbout Perceptron\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs discussed above multi-layered perceptron these are basically the hidden or the dense layers. They are made up of many neurons and neurons are the primary unit that works together to form perceptron. In simple words, as you can see in the above picture each circle represents neurons and a vertical combination of neurons represents perceptrons which is basically a dense layer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-images\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fuploads\u002F708832021-07-19.png\" alt=\"About Perceptron ANN\" width=\"1296\" height=\"705\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Feditor.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F363503f3-4af4-479b-b3f9-2ebdbf6773fd\" alt=\"\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fintroduction-to-neural-networks-advantages-and-applications-96851bd1a207\"\u003Ehttps:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fintroduction-to-neural-networks-advantages-and-applications-96851bd1a207\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow in the above picture, you can see each neuron&#8217;s detailed view. Here, each neurons have some weights (in above picture w1, w2, w3) and biases and based on this computations are done as, \u003Cb\u003Ecombination = bias + weights * input\u003C\u002Fb\u003E (F = w1*x1 + w2*x2 + w3*x3) and finally activation function is applied \u003Cb\u003Eoutput = activation(combination)\u003C\u002Fb\u003E in above picture activation is sigmoid represented by      1\u002F(1 + e\u003Csup\u003E-F\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E). There are some other activation functions as well like ReLU, Leaky ReLU, tanh, and many more.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWorking Of ANN\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAt First, information is feed into the input layer which then transfers it to the hidden layers, and interconnection between these two layers assign weights to each input randomly at the initial point. and then bias is added to each input neuron and after this, the weighted sum which is a combination of weights and bias is passed through the activation function. Activation Function has the responsibility of which node to fire for feature extraction and finally output is calculated. This whole process is known as Foreward Propagation. After getting the output model to compare it with the original output and the error is known and finally, weights are updated in backward propagation to reduce the error and this process continues for a certain number of epochs (iteration). Finally, model weights get updated and prediction is done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EAdvantages\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EANN has the ability to learn and model non-linear and complex relationships as many relationships between input and output are non-linear.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EAfter training, ANN can infer unseen relationships from unseen data, and hence it is generalized.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EUnlike many machine learning models, ANN does not have restrictions on datasets like data should be Gaussian distributed or nay other distribution.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EApplications\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are many applications of ANN. Some of them are :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EImage Preprocessing and Character Recognition.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EForecasting.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003ECredit rating.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EFraud Detection.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EPortfolio Management.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECODING PART\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow let&#8217;s code and understand the concepts using it.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E1. Understanding and Loading the datasets\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFirst Import Libraries like NumPy, pandas, and also import classes named sequential and dense from Keras library.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eimport numpy as np\r\nimport pandas as pd\r\nfrom keras.models import Sequential\r\nfrom keras.layers import Dense\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow here I am going to use the Pima Indians onset of diabetes dataset which is a standard machine learning dataset from the UCI Machine Learning repository and the link can be found below. This dataset tells about the patient medical record and whether they had an onset of diabetes within five years also it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EYou can download the datasets from here:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fraw.githubusercontent.com\u002Fjbrownlee\u002FDatasets\u002Fmaster\u002Fpima-indians-diabetes.data.csv\"\u003EDatasets\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow import the dataset using pandas and then let us understand more about the datasets and then split the datasets into dependent and independent variables.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edataset = pd.read_csv('pima-indians-diabetes.csv')\r\nX = dataset[:,0:8]\r\ny = dataset[:,8]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E2. Defining the Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EModels in Keras are defined as a sequence of layers in which each layer is added one after another. \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EThe input should contain input features and is specified when creating the first layer with the input_dims\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E argument. Here inputs_dims will be 8.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003ENow a question arises that how can we decide the number of layers and number of neurons in each layer?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003EIt is quite difficult to know how many layers we should use. Generally for this \u003Cb\u003EKeras tuner\u003C\u002Fb\u003E is used, which takes a range of layers, a range of neurons, and some activation functions. and then by permutation and combination, it tries to find which is best suited. But one disadvantage of this is it takes lots of time. You can refer to the documentation of it \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fkeras.io\u002Fkeras_tuner\u002F\"\u003EKeras Tuner\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for more details. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this example, a fully connected network with a three-layer is used which is \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Edefined using the Dense Class.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E The first argument takes the number of neurons in that layer and, and the activation\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E argument takes the activation function as an input. Here ReLU is used as an activation function in the first two layers and sigmoid in the last layer as it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel = Sequential()\r\nmodel.add(Dense(12, input_dim=8, activation='relu'))\r\nmodel.add(Dense(8, activation='relu'))\r\nmodel.add(Dense(1, activation='sigmoid'))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E3. Compile Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EWhile compiling we must specify the loss function to calculate the errors, the optimizer for updating the weights and any metrics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this case, we will use \u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E“\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cstrong style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003Ebinary_crossentropy\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 14px; text-align: left;\"\u003E“\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E as the \u003Cstrong\u003Eloss\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument as it is a binary classification problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere we will take \u003Cstrong\u003Eoptimizer\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E as “\u003Cstrong\u003Eadam\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E“ as it automatically tunes itself and gives good results in a wide range of problems and finally we will collect and report the classification accuracy through \u003Cstrong\u003Emetrics\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel.compile(loss='binary_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E4. Fitting The Keras Model.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we will fit our model on the loaded data by calling the \u003Cstrong\u003Efit()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function on the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe training process will run for a fixed number of iterations through the dataset which is specified using the \u003Cstrong\u003Eepochs\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument. The number of dataset rows should be and are updated within each epoch, and set using the \u003Cstrong\u003Ebatch_size\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere, We will run for 150 epochs and a batch size of 10.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Emodel.fit(X, y, epochs=150, batch_size=10)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E5. Evaluate Keras Model\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe evaluation of the model on the dataset can be done using the \u003Cstrong\u003Eevaluate()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function. It takes two arguments i.e, input and output. It will generate a prediction for each input and output pair and collect scores, including the average loss and any metrics such as accuracy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Cstrong\u003Eevaluate()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function will return a list with two values first one is the loss of the model and the second will be the accuracy of the model on the dataset. We are only interested in reporting the accuracy and hence we ignored the loss value.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E_, accuracy = model.evaluate(X, y)\r\nprint('Accuracy: %.2f' % (accuracy*100))\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003E6. Make Predictions\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EPrediction can be done by calling the \u003Cstrong\u003Epredict()\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E function on the model. Here sigmoid activation function is used on the output layer, so the predictions will be a probability in the range between 0 and 1.\u003Cb\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Epredictions = model.predict(X)\r\nrounded = [round(x[0]) for x in predictions]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Ch3\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFinal Code Summary\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EHere we have learned how to create your first neural network model using the powerful Keras Python library for deep learning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EThere are six main steps in using Keras to create a neural network or deep learning model that are loading the data, defining the neural network in Keras after that compiling, evaluating, and finally making the predictions with the model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E\u003Cb\u003ECONCLUSION\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIn this article, we have understood the basic concepts of Artificial neural networks and their code. In the coding part, we have used the Pima Indians&#8217; onset of diabetes dataset. here we have understood in detail all six main steps to create neural networks. Apart from this many things have not been covered in the blogs and below I have provided the links of other blogs from which you can refer the topics.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Col\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@zeeshanmulla\u002Fcost-activation-loss-function-neural-network-deep-learning-what-are-these-91167825a4de\"\u003EDifferent types of cost functions and their applications.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\u002Fan-introduction-to-gradient-descent-and-backpropagation-81648bdb19b2\"\u003EAbout Gradient Descent.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fkeras.io\u002F\"\u003EKeras Documentation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fol\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"medium-insert-buttons\" for shubh_123\"}}]},{\"@type\":\"Person\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#\u002Fschema\u002Fperson\u002Fcd02a20f2c5c65d4e45f1ff4c7780d13\",\"name\":\"shubh_123\",\"image\":{\"@type\":\"ImageObject\",\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002F#personlogo\",\"inLanguage\":\"en-US\",\"url\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"caption\":\"shubh_123\"},\"mainEntityOfPage\":{\"@id\":\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002Fauthor\u002Fshubh_123\u002F#webpage\"}}]}\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\n\u003C!-- \u002F Yoast SEO plugin. --\u003E","avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\u002F\u002Fsecure.gravatar.com\u002Favatar\u002F1114f2127d6cb7da00fccc7ddee87447?s=96&d=mm&r=g"},"description":""}}}},"is_bookmarked":false,"extra_info":{}},{"id":"4cc87a44-b608-4050-8fff-c054570eb82e","created":"2021-07-18T02:01:39.039480Z","modified":"2021-07-19T22:01:09.887417Z","resource_id":"82388","resource_type":"article","resource_permalink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fblog\u002F2021\u002F07\u002Funderstanding-rnn-step-by-step-with-pytorch\u002F","resource_created":"2021-07-17T14:05:59Z","resource_modified":"2021-07-17T14:05:59Z","start":null,"end":null,"is_featured":false,"is_priced":false,"price_currency":"INR","price":null,"title":"Understanding RNN Step by Step with PyTorch","sub_title":"","description":"This article was published as a part of the Data Science Blogathon Introduction In this article, we will learn very basic concepts of Recurrent Neural …","source_description":"\u003Cp\u003EThis article was published as a part of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatahack.analyticsvidhya.com\u002Fcontest\u002Fdata-science-blogathon-10\u002FTrue\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EData Science Blogathon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EIntroduction\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this article, we will learn very basic concepts of Recurrent Neural networks. So fasten your seatbelt, we are going to explore the very basic details of RNN with PyTorch.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E3 terminology for RNN:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cul\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EInput: Input to RNN\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EHidden: All hidden at last time step for all layers\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003Cli\u003EOutput: All hidden at last layer for all time steps so that you can feed the hidden to next layer\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n\u003Cdiv\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*afedyFSroI3YktHgwEgibg.png\" alt=\"RNN\" width=\"800\" height=\"442\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnidirectional RNN with PyTorch \u003Ci\u003EImage by Author\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the above figure we have N time steps (horizontally) and M layers vertically). We feed input at t = 0 and initially hidden to RNN cell and the output hidden then feed to the same RNN cell with next input sequence at t = 1 and we keep feeding the hidden output to the all input sequence. Implementation-wise in PyTorch, if you are new to PyTorch, I want to give you a very very useful tip, and this is really very important If you will follow I guarantee you will learn this quickly: And the tip is- \u003Cstrong\u003ECare more about the Shape\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAssume we have the following one dimension array input data (row = 7 , columns=1 )\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*GkxIOky_IrFsCMy5uJX6Ag.png\" alt=\"Data Type 1\" width=\"800\" height=\"252\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E                                                   Data Type 1 (\u003Cem\u003EImage by author)\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd we created sequential data and the label as shown above. Now we need to break this one into batches. Let’s say we take batch size = 2.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*gRpnjQyvsRwKNekl_A_nwQ.png\" alt=\"Batch1 and Batch2 RNN\" width=\"800\" height=\"178\" data-image-id=\"1*gRpnjQyvsRwKNekl_A_nwQ.png\" data-width=\"852\" data-height=\"190\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cem\u003E                                                                             Image by author\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EInput To RNN\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput data:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E RNN should have 3 dimensions. (Batch Size, Sequence Length and Input Dimension)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBatch\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003Cstrong\u003ESize\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is the number of samples we send to the model at a time. In this example, we have batch size = 2 but you can take it 4, 8,16, 32, 64 etc depends on the memory (basically in \u003Cstrong\u003E2’s power)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESequence Length \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the length of the sequence of input data (time step:0,1,2…N), the RNN learn the sequential pattern in the dataset. Here the grey colour part is sequence length so our sequence length = 3.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have share market data on a daily basis (frequency = 1day) and you want that the network to learn the sequence of 30 days of data. So your sequence length will be 30.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Dimension or Input Size \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the number of features or dimensions you are using in your data set. In this case, it is one (Columns\u002F Features). Suppose you have share market data with the following features: High, Low, Open and Close and you want to predict Close. In this case, you have input dimension = 4: High, Low, Open and Close. We will see the input dimension in more detail.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPyTorch takes input in two Shape :\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Type 1:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Sequence Length, Batch Size, Input Dimension\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInput Type 2:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Batch Size, Sequence Length, Input Dimension\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we choose Input type 1 our shape will be = 3, 2, 1\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf we choose Input type 2 our shape will be = 2, 3, 1\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ESeparate out the labels from input data because we only feed input sequences to the model, and then we will explore both of the Input shapes in detail. So we should move towards implementation. First I created a custom Dataset class that returns input sequences and labels. Here the input is a float array and seq_len is window size or the sequence length of input data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eclass MyDaatset(Dataset):\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E    def __init__(self, input, seq_len):\r\n        self.input = input\r\n        self.seq_len = seq_len\r\n    def __getitem__(self, item):\r\n        return input[item:item + self.seq_len], input[item + self.seq_len]\r\n    def __len__(self):\r\n        return len(self.input) - self.seq_len\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDefine sequence from 1 to 7 and convert it to PyTorch tensor\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Einput = np.arange(1,8).reshape(-1,1)\r\ninput = torch.tensor(input, dtype=torch.float)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003ENow we can call MyDataset class to get the data\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eds = MyDaatset(input, 3)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EAs we have taken batch size = 2\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edl = DataLoader(ds, batch_size=2)\r\nfor inp, label in dl:\r\n    print(inp.numpy())\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1.]\r\n  [2.]\r\n  [3.]]\r\n [[2.]\r\n  [3.]\r\n  [4.]]]\r\n[[[3.]\r\n  [4.]\r\n  [5.]]\r\n [[4.]\r\n  [5.]\r\n  [6.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003EIf you observe carefully the very first dimension is 2 which is the batch size, next is 3 which is sequence length and the last one is 1 your feature or input dimension.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow we have shapes as 2, 3, 1 (BS, SeqLen, Input Dim).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose you have 2 input features for example feature 1 and feature 2\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*bTePppw267PduIgSiF2n5w.png\" data-image-id=\"1*bTePppw267PduIgSiF2n5w.png\" data-width=\"984\" data-height=\"107\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E                                                                           \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E   Data Type 2\u003Cstrong\u003E (\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EImage by author)\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThen the input data will look like below. the only thing is the third dimension changed to 2 (2 is the number of features).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1. 11.]\r\n  [2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]]\r\n [[2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]]\r\n[[[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]]\r\n [[4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]\r\n  [6.16.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUp to this point, we have discussed Input type 2: of shape (Batch Size, Sequence Length, Input Dimension). If we want to change this into Input type 1 we need to permute the input. To achieve this just switch batch dimension with sequence dimension in the input data, like below\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Einp.permute(1,0,2) # switch dimension 0 and dimension 1\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003E[[[1. 11.]\r\n  [2. 12.]]\r\n [[2. 12.]\r\n  [3. 13.]]\r\n [[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]]\r\n[[[3. 13.]\r\n  [4. 14.]]\r\n [[4. 14.]\r\n  [5. 15.]]\r\n [[5. 15.]\r\n  [6.16.]]]\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003EIf you notice now the first dimension is 3, not 2, and it is our sequence length. And the second dimension is 2 which is batch size. And the third dimension is 2 which is the input dimension\u002F features. And our input shape is = (3, 2, 2) which is input type 1. If you are confusing a little bit then spend some time on this image-\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*x8xX-EUDJpFDkGF8aLIvLQ.png\" alt=\"RNN inputs\" width=\"689\" height=\"604\" data-image-id=\"1*x8xX-EUDJpFDkGF8aLIvLQ.png\" data-width=\"689\" data-height=\"604\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cem\u003E                                                                           Image by author\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EImplementation\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet&#8217;s implement our small Recurrent Neural Net class, Inherit the base class nn.Module. HL_size = hidden size we can define as 32, 64, 128 (again better in 2’s power) and input size is a number of features in our data (input dimension). Here input size is 2 for data type 2 and 1 for data type 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003EBidirectional true will make this RNN bidirectional this is very useful in many applications where the next sequences can help previous sequences in learning. If bidirectional is true the number of directions will be 2 otherwise it will be 1.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003Ebatch_first=True means batch should be our first dimension (Input Type 2) otherwise if we do not define batch_first=True in RNN we need data in Input type 1 shape (Sequence Length, Batch Size, Input Dimension).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eclass RNNModel(torch.nn.Module):\r\n    def __init__(self, input_size, HL_size):\r\n        super(RNNModel, self).__init__()\r\n        self.rnn = torch.nn.RNN(input_size=input_size,\r\n                                hidden_size=Hidden Size(HS),\r\n                                num_layers=number of stacked RNN,\r\n                                bidirectional=True\u002FFalse,\r\n                                batch_first=True default is False)\r\n        # If you want to use output for next layer then\r\n        self.linear2 = torch.nn.Linear(#Direction * HS , Output_size)\r\n        # If you want to use hidden for next layer then\r\n        self.linear2 = torch.nn.Linear(HS , Output_size)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERNN returns output and is hidden.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EOutput\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOutput Shape:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E If we use batch_first=True, then output shape is (Batch Size, Seq Len, # Direction * Hidden Size). If we use batch_first=False, then output shape is ( Seq Len, Batch Size, No of Direction * Hidden Size)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuppose if we consider data type 2 as input where seq_len is 3, batch is 2, hidden size = 128 and bidirectional = False then our output shape will be: (3, 2, 1 * 128) for batch_first=False and (2, 3, 1 * 128) for batch_first=True.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHidden Shape:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E (No of Direction * num_layers, Batch Size, Hidden Size) which holds information about final hidden state. So most of the time we took hidden as an input in self.linear2.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ELinear Transformation after RNN:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E If you are doing regression or binary classification then the output_size in Linear Transformation should be 1, If you are doing multi-class classification then Output_size will be a number of classes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter __init__ you have to define forward class, this is the method of your RNN Class, which computes the hidden in the network. If you are using output (\u003Cstrong\u003Eout\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E in below code) as an input, then it means you will have hidden states for all time steps in the last layer, you need to select which time-step data you want to feed to the linear layer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Edef forward(self, input):\r\n    out, hidden_ = self.rnn(input)\r\n    #out: Select which time step data you want for linear layer \r\n    out = self.linear2(out)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf you want to use \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E as an input for the next layer just replace the last line with\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cpre\u003Eout = self.linear2(hidden_)\u003C\u002Fpre\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this case suppose If you have num_layer = 2, num_direction =2 then for each batch you will have 2 * 2= 4 hidden in the first dimension of \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, as \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E shape will be (4, BS, Hidden Size). Now you can select your input for the next layer from \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_ \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E(the way you want). For example, you can use both forward and backward direction of last hidden state from you \u003Cstrong\u003Ehidden_\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E like below.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003Cimg loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fcdn-images-1.medium.com\u002Fmax\u002F800\u002F1*KWVy1bdL_z-06vvp2t65jg.png\" alt=\"Hidden tensors | RNN\" width=\"703\" height=\"450\" data-image-id=\"1*KWVy1bdL_z-06vvp2t65jg.png\" data-width=\"703\" data-height=\"450\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cfigcaption\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E                                                        \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E          hidden_ tensor (Image by author)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd we are done.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003EEndNotes\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat is all about RNN in PyTorch. If not clear I advise you to do practice with code I am sure you will have a better understanding.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv
